40825819.review: As someone who loves puzzle games, this is a great one. It brings me back to my days of writing programs in BASIC on my calculator, but it's much more restrictive, and that's the challenge. They do well to introduce concepts in an easier setting before requiring you to use them in a difficult one, and there are many opportunities to resuse old code as the basis for a new level rather than write it all from scratch. Some of the optimization challenges are very difficult, starting with "Multiplication Workshop," but they're pretty satisfying once you figure out what you were missing. Only thing I think it's missing is community levels.

40647089.review:
Don't let the welcoming interface fool you, this game is a bitch to play. Here's why:


- Writing a comment in your code is like writing on a stamp with a board pen...

- Looking for errors in your code involves clicking your way through each... line... of code... starting either from where your code starts or where it first fucks up

- Actually debugging your code resets the whooolllle thing

- Testing your code can take upwards of 3 minutes on the maximum speed

- The game won't tell you why you're wrong or how to fix your code. It will just silently produce inputs that bring out the bugs in your code while you struggle on.


I really don't know how the developers, being programmers themselves, made a game that is a dick to programmers.
While there are redeeming features, as detailed in other reviews, I also don't know why 94% of all reviews are positive. So here's a negative one.

40633087.review:
一款很久以前就想尝试的集编程、益智、解谜于一体的好游戏。     测评（10/10分）

###  回忆（10分）###
虽然才玩了短短一个多小时，但是玩这款游戏当初大一学习C语言的日子仿佛就在昨天……
那是一段多么美好又烧脑的回忆啊。
解决了一个具体的问题后那种无法言表的成就感，太棒了！
时而又会绞尽脑汁的冥想一个点，
我们当时真是太拼了。
语法类似汇编，但是游戏中的指令非常简化；

###  音效 （3分）###
个人非常不喜欢游戏的背景音乐，过于单调；当在思考的时候，单调的旋律就显得有点碍手碍脚了；

### 难度 (8分) ###
虽然有学习过编程语言，也写过R、MATLAB程序；但游戏的玩法还是有些陌生，有一定上手难度，但游戏设计的非常棒，难度随着问题的复杂层层递进；

### 趣味性 （9分） ###
游戏中将会循环遍历、乘法器、除法器、串操作、排序、链表等算法方面的具体知识，学习与娱乐相结合；

### 自省性（10分） ###
游戏单纯！ 合理！简单又易懂！又充满乐趣！ 许多关卡都会有两个灯——“代码长度的挑战”和“程序复杂度的挑战”不断激发自我对于程序简化的思考，不断的去优化程序以达成最优。
一款非常棒的游戏！

40625514.review:
我们学习加法的日子仿佛就在昨天。
那是一段多么美好的回忆。。。
我们当时真是太拼了。

——第20关，乘法研讨会。


进度：前19层全两星。
看到这句话的时候真是感慨万分【。

————————————————

这游戏里的Jump是我见过最恶心的跳转方式，没有之一。
它能把你清晰的思路搅成一团浆糊，然后让你怀疑自己是个白痴。
发自真心感谢高级语言。

————————————————

只要不嫌又臭又长，你总会通关的。
然而那两个小灯才是游戏真正的意义所在。
沉迷优化，不能自拔。

————————————————

进度：前28层全两星。
在探索最小体积的道路上，我们又一次印证了那个真理：
复制之前程序的结构进行修改，永远是效率最高也最妥善的办法。

————————————————

进度：全成就达成。

开场白、跟老板对话、休息楼层以及结尾的剧情，到处都充满了程序员式的自嘲。
对于外行来说半路弃坑或许可以理解，毕竟那些题目算法离他们的生活过于遥远。
但是对于程序员来讲，后面几关或许不算很难，不过想做到两星还是需要花些心思。
所以这些题目带给你的思考，并非毫无意义。
最后，对于那些一边自称程序员，一边打开几分钟就嚷嚷着无聊的人。
我只能默认你或许对你的工作并没有多少热情和兴趣。

40624120.review:
Good game overall. Just two gripes:
1) Needs a way to turn off the sound. Why would any game not have this?
2) It makes unconditional jumps count against your performance. This means you can get some small gains by unrolling your loops and it's a tedious requirement for a few of the optimization challenges. This is supposed to be a puzzle game; I expect to get points for cleverness, not for copy-pasting.

40624076.review: Cool concept, but it got old very quickly.  If you have any experience with programming, you may get frustrated by the small number of available commands, the teenie little space you have to work with and see your commands, and the lack of some other standard conveniences.  I love puzzle games where figuring out the solution is the hard part.  In this game, figuring out the solutions/algorithms is too easy, and it's the implementation/"optimization" of those solutions that is the real goal.  If you are into that kind of thing, you'll enjoy this game.  Unfortunately it got boring and frustrating for me before I even got through the whole game.

40015055.review:
The game is alright, but just feels inferior to TIS-100 (despite having a far more welcoming interface).  

It seems like the game was designed for mobile devices: everything is drag-and-drop, to the point that you never use your keyboard at all.  My biggest irritation here is that you have absolutely no data literals: if you need a zero, you have to grab a zero from somewhere in the puzzle's memory.  

You start with a very basic set of instructions that does grow over time, but the list never grows to more than what fits comfortably on the screen.  Your programs are typically between 8-15 lines long, and while there are a few levels near the end that get into the 20's, that's still a pretty short line count for a programming puzzle.  I finished the game feeling like my solutions probably look very, very similar to everyone else's.

All in all, if you're trying to decide between this game and TIS-100, I'd recommend TIS-100.  If you've already finished TIS-100, this won't explore much new territory for you.

39859686.review:
About a year's worth of a degree course in computer science - for a fraction of the price!

A Zachtronics game with a Visual Studio overhaul, instead of animated paperclips you get little Kyles bossing you around.

Everything you need to know to be programming in Assembler, BASIC etc is taught gently within this game and with NO TYPING. It's point and click and doodle, you can even use a Steam Controller and Get Gud in your bed.

Some of the very advanced puzzles will be easier if you take the Boss' hints to do research on Wikipedia - look for algorithms used by ancient Greeks, not the latest quadratic quantum versions! Those would take 8 billion humans to understand and you are just One. One productive happy worker, right?

39853386.review:
Human Resource Machine is a small game about programming. It offers some really tough challenges for even those who code for a living, using only the simplest( aaand a bit outdated) programming concepts.

You have a bus, and an array with a specific size in each level. You can use basic commands to read an index from that array into your bus, or write that bus into an index within your array. You can read, write, add, subtract, increment and decrement. You can read your input into your bus, and write your bus onto the output. Every operation is done with your bus. Your task is to take input from the inbox conveyor, process it according to the protocol provided with each level, and output the result onto the outbox conveyor. As simple as that. But it is always worth it and results in extreme satisfaction when I nail the solution. (Joy of Thinking)

In the game, you climb this enormous office building, slowly progressing through more and more complicated tasks, and small cutscenes that tell a fun story about three of your colleges, mostly during "coffee break". All three of which ignore the news on the TV where you will see the city slowly turning into a world where machines do all the work.

The third "era" in this game is the most exciting. After a dramatic cutscene, your bosses tell you that big changes are coming. It is a plot twist. The story takes a very sharp turn. At the same time, you unlock the last, and most powerfull upgrade in your arsenal of commands. One that really changes everything.

In the case you were wondering, amongst the toughest challenges offered are sorting, prime factoring, and duplicate filtering. They are hard because of the lack of memory space, and the lack of control over the flow of your code. You don't just have to know programming, you need to master it. You can only branch your code by testing if your bus is zero or negative, so subtract to compare numbers. If you fail, the game laughs at you, your boss at his desk get mad( as errors), and you can feel very clueless about some of the mistakes you made. I am talking about my Father who teaches C++ in university. Unlike me, it took him one hour to give up on writing a code for the prime factoring level. He was overwhelmed by a simple math puzzle for which I wrote a (not OCD) code in ten minutes, fixing it up to be fully optimal in about 20 extra minutes.

I let more than one person other than myself try the game, and surprisingly enough, they mostly failed near halfway through. They got stuck in different levels, but to the point that they are "guessing" when they modify their code. They recognise, say that they put a specific command in the wrong place, but they "guess" when they try to move it elsewhere. Some told me that they don't even know what their code is doing anymore. It's like not being able to read your own writing.

A lot of negative reviews complain about the fact that the tools are not powerfull. They are half wrong. It makes for a great challenge, but yes, it can be frustrating if you can't part with your precious "for" loops, and advanced mathematical operations for the sake of the game. After all, in a game of optimisation puzzles, multiplication and division are way overpowered the same way something else can be owerpowered and decrease the fun the player has in a lot of games. Developers tend to make the most optimal way to play the most fun.

And then there are the Optimal Completion Distinction (AkA: OCD) challenges. There are two for each level if you are really into programming. There is the size challenge, which you complete by staying under a given number of lines. And the speed challenge, which is the "average number of steps" your worker has to take, tested against a number of deterministically generated inputs.

And here is what I dislike about this game:
-Incorrect and sometimes misleading translation( at least, to my native language). First playthrough was in english, then I switched to my native language which is rarely supported in games.

39672775.review:
Welcome to assembly programming 101. I found most of the puzzles really easy, although some of the later ones did make my brain churn for a bit to solve them. Things will get messy, assembly programming is messy in all but the simplest of programs, so don't feel bad that it looks horrible. If it works, it works.

I do have a few complaints. The commenting system is horrible. You have to draw on a small piece of 'paper', on which you have nearly no space to write anything but a short word or two. Being able to type would go a long way. I ended up not using comments because of this, since I wasn't sharing my 'code' with anybody and as long as it worked and solved the puzzle in the end, it's fine, but it would have definitely have helped in some of the later puzzles to help me keep my bearings.

There is also very little in the way of a tutorial. New concepts are more or less thrown in your face and explained in a sentence or two. In the beginning, with relatively simple instructions like 'add', 'sub' and 'jmp', this works, but when you have 15 instructions to keep track of, and you get another one, which isn't explained very well, and you're required to use it in a relatively complicated way, I could easily imagine people getting stuck if they weren't all ready familiar with how they work. Don't feel bad for looking up an instruction on Google, or look for an example program, or just try to mess around with new instructions so you can familiarise yourself with them on your own terms.

Also, some of the longer programmes you're required to write in the later puzzles take a really long time to run. You can speed up how fast programmes are run, but they don't run quickly enough, even at the highest speed, during the late game, since the programmes take so long to run.

Otherwise, it's a fun little exercise, and even if you don't complete it, you'll have familiarised yourself with one of the most fundamental parts of programming (doesn't get much closer to the metal than asm!).

38655085.review:
Human Resource Machine - это не пособие по обучению программированию, но великолепный тест и наглядная реализация работы машины.

Игрок управляет персонажем не напрямую, а складывает программу из очередности команд. И это не банальные пойти влево - вправо, повторить, как у многих аналогов, а максимально приближенные к настоящим команды. Да, похож на ассемблер (язык программирования), но понятный каждому, в игровой форме, хорошей стилистике, с описанием и примерами (задача всегда описана сверху, а дополнительную информацию можно спросить у начальника). Персонаж буквально становится седым из года в год бегая по карьерной лестнице, осваивая новые команды и решая задачи. Данный вам набор команд копирования, чтения, вычитания, сложения, перехода с условием и ссылка - скромный, но количество задач решает - неимоверное множество.

Веселый стиль и диалоги отлично разбавляют серьезность происходящего. Сложность нарастающая, - сначала вас знакомят с новой командой, а далее ставят условия для выполнения задачи. Уже после трети игры задачи требуют много времени для выполнения, а последние уровни прямо рвут волосы на голове. Игру не нужно обманывать - подставив программу под конкретный набор данных, она отшутится и предложит новые данные на вход. А в качестве "звездочек" уровня - подсчитывается количество команд в программе и количество шагов за которое она выполняется. Часто чтобы "выбить все звезды" нужно спроектировать 2 варианта программ - одна с минимум команд, другая с минимум шагов - вот вам и основы оптимизации (когда код читается хорошо или работает быстро). Наиболее сложные задачи расположены на другой ветке и не обязательны для прохождения.

В целом игра отлично показывает как можно только лишь складывая и вычитая выполнять умножение и деление, сравнивать, сортировать, шифровать и многое другое. Для программистов эта игра не лучший вариант развлечения - чувство "из одной работы в другую" настигнут вас быстро, но некоторые чувства ностальгии все же нахлынут. Задачи, действительно сложные - терпения и усидчивости на все у меня не хватило (интернет подсказки прохождения), но она хорошо проработана, красива и уморительна.

7.5/10

38514750.review:
Assembly programming with lots of registers and indirect addressing.  Does that sound fun to you?  If so then you'll love this.  If it doesn't sound fun then.... well, you might still love this if you enjoy logical puzzles, experimentation and creativity.  It's quite user friendly and nicely paced.

Drag and drop makes it nice and easy to rejig your code when you decide that something else might work better.  Or might work, period.  Each challenge will track your most compact solution and your fastest solution, so even after you've bodged your way through to the end you can still get some extra life from trying to optimise things.

If you enjoyed TIS-100 and you appreciate the mood of World Of Goo or Little Inferno then I think you'll be very pleased with this.  So go buy it.

38073988.review:
带非专业的你切身体验一下当程序员


大学选错了专业，如果选择了计算机专业，我现在也是月薪过万了，生活在大城市，也应该有了女朋友。以上是我的白日梦，没学过计算机的我现实只是工地民工，几天前在appstore看见有Human Resource Machine这款游戏，为了体验一下当程序员的感觉，在steam 上下载了这款游戏，就开始了闭门造车之路，没有查任何攻略，最后通关。

总的来说这款游戏的难度不是太高，不需要你会任何编程语言，都是一些基础的数学知识，加减法转化成乘除法，比较大小，排序，斐波那数列，删除重复项的问题。玩这个游戏的当时想不出来的问题，可以在你干别的事的时候慢慢想出来，只要有了灵感就可以在后来把算法写出来。其中对于我个人来说最难的一关是英文词典排序题目，卡了两天，花费六七个小时才过了这关，它的题目是任意输入两个英文单词，输出词典里面比较考前的那个单词。后面的关卡我都过关，但算法体积和速度的优化不够，没学过程序的我能通关就很满意了。优化的难度太高，还是留给专业程序员。

说一下玩这个游戏的几点感悟：

1当全身心投入到一个题目里时，思路出现，程序运行成功的时候真的会有很大的成就感。

2你有了正确的解题思路也不一定能够让程序正确运行，可能因为你输错一个代码，或者是因为你思维的局限性，调bug真的是很痛苦的一件事。

3复杂的关卡，在你写程序时，一定要写注释，如果不写注释一是回过头来你也看不懂你写的什么，二是后面修改调整代码你会找不到修改的位置。

4从一般事件模型中发现规律，这样就有了思路，后面再查漏补缺考虑特殊的情况。

5复杂的关卡，可以先分为几个不同的模块，先一个模块一个模块的编写调试，最后再总体调试，这样比直接总体调试更容易发现问题的所在。

6当遇到障碍卡了壳，重新梳理自己的算法结构流程，看算法是否有新的解法，重新改变算法流程，然后再重新编程。

7审题一定要审清除，不要会错题意。你实现的功能与题目要求的功能不一致是很浪费时间的。

8解决一个问题的解题思路是最重要的，而程序语言是次要的。

Ultimately, this is just a game where you program in assembly language. I finished the game in one sitting, expecting to get to the "twist". Spoiler: there's no twist.

If you're new to assembly, playing the game might be an OK introduction. You're going to run into some steep hills to climb that the game in no way helps with. You're going to have to do some research on how strings work, how computer multiplication works, and basic sorting in order to finish the main line.

The overall theme and graphics of the game are great, it just seems like the first third of an interesting game.

I'd recommend any of the Zachtronics games if you liked this.

Mikrocomputer-Programmierung spielerisch erlernt.

Wer im Informatikunterricht probleme mit Assembler, Johnny und Microcomputer-Programmierung hatte, das Konzept dahinter aber trotzdem verstehen und auch noch spielerisch erlernen möchte, der ist bei "Human Resource Machine" richtig aufgehoben.
Eine flache Lernkurve mit ziemlich hohem Ende ermöglicht es so gut wie jedem, die Grundkonzepte zu verstehen und die nach und nach eingeführten Befehle zur Problemlösung einzusetzen.
Dass es Sprungkommandos wie "Sprung wenn nicht negativ" oder die Möglichkeit des Setzens von Carryflags nicht gibt, stört dabei nur die Hardcore-Programmierer - und selbst die haben viel Spaß am Spiel.

Definitv sein Geld wert.

36604346.review:
i loved this game just as much as I hated it. the game is cute except in the harder levels where f*cking with satan's own IDE re-writing your 10,000th nested loop statement dragging-and-dropping individual less-than assembly instructions with no subroutines is 90% of the gameplay

I'm honestly not sure if this game is made to just to fuck with programmers or not. becuase if it is it does it with absolute aplomb. registers are annotated by literally scribbling on a post-it note **with your mouse**. the debugger gets annoyed with you if you don't solve the problem in one go, and takes literally minutes to go through a single run of the problem before you can step backward through every step of the program (no breakpoints!!) to where the error occured -- and then if you modify your program the debugger suddenly loses all runtime state and you need to re-run it from the beginning

the game culminates with a huge 'fuck you' boss problem that is at least twice as hard as every level before it combined. it literally took me 4 hours to complete every level other than the last, and 2 hours to give up on the last problem for 6 hours total gameplay

ugh, it's so frustrating because it felt like the game had so much potential -- if they just added basic quality-of life features like having separate files, or subroutines, or reusable code, much of the frustrations of the harder problems would be removed. I was expecting that to happen! I was expecting to reach a stage where I was writing code for multiple people in parallel but it ends with a pansy sort problem only made difficult by having to implement it in the least sane possible way

36554048.review: An excellent and fun programming-esque game with Tomorrow Corporation's trademark dark humor. I particularly like that it sets optimization goals rather than relying on your friends list to tell you how well (or not) you're doing.

36496333.review:
Laut meinen Anweisungen muss ich jetzt ein Review schreiben.

Human Resource Machine ist ein kleines Spiel, wo man Anweisungen befolgen muss. Man bekommt bestimmte Vorgaben von seinem Chef und muss diese dann mit den zur Verfügung stehenden Mitteln lösen. Das ganze läuft im Prinzip darauf hinaus, dass man ein wenig programmiert, jedoch ohne zu coden. Man schiebt die Befehle einfach in die richtige Reihenfolge und definiert, wo der Arbeiter etwas hinlegt. Die Level sind dabei am Anfang sehr einfach, werden aber von Level zu Level schwieriger und am Ende sehr knifflig. Wer zudem eine weitere Herausforderung haben möchte, der optimiert seine Anweisungen so, dass sie möglichst wenig Befehle beinhalten oder eine kurze Laufzeit haben.

Grafisch ist das Spiel stimmig gestaltet. Es hat einen gewissen Humor und das wird eben auch im Grafikstil bewusst. Es ist keine High-End-Grafik, aber das muss es ja auch nicht. Soundtechnisch ist das Spiel auch nett, mit passenden Effekten und einem, meiner Meinung nach, nicht nervig werdenen Soundtrack.

Die Story ... nun so wirklich was mit Story hat das Spiel nicht zu tun. Man arbeitet sich eben von Etage zu Etage, um dann am Ende ... Na das findet ihr bestimmt selbst raus. Alles im Allem also ein kleines nettes Spiel. Wer Programmieren doof findet, sollte die Finger hiervon lassen. Wer die Basics kennt und schauen will, was damit möglich ist, der kann sich das anschauen, wenn auch nur für den Angebotspreis, denn den Vollpreis würde ich nicht nochmal zahlen.

36467833.review:
[h1]Rating[/h1]
[b]7/10[/b]

[h1]Worth it?[/h1]
Yes, especially if you like a good puzzle. 
Or if you're a programmer and want to test your skills.

[h1]Playtime[/h1]
It took me about 13 hours to get 100% completion. 
But I did get stuck for a while on a couple of levels.

[h1]Comparison[/h1]
Visually it's similar to World of Goo and Little Inferno, simply because it was made by the same team (2D BOY / Tomorrow Corporation). 
But in terms of gameplay, nothing comes to mind, it's pretty unique.

[h1]Plot[/h1]
You start at the bottom of corporate ladder and you need to solve puzzles to move up. 
It's not a plot-driven game, so that's really all there is to it. 

[h1]Look...[/h1]
Very similar to World of Goo and Little Inferno. It's pretty and cartoon-ish, with a dark twist. 
The tasks, the menus, and the available set of tools are clear and easy to understand.

[h1]... and Feel[/h1]
Mostly it's just efficient for what it is. You instantly know what you need to do on each level and what tools are available to do it. Figuring out how to actually do it is the difficult part. 

[h1]Music[/h1]
Completely insignificant. 
It's there in the background, but the authors must've known it's nothing special, because on every level there's a big button to turn it off. I ended up playing other music instead. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
This is the good part! 
It's about solving puzzles. Programming puzzles. Creating a set of instructions that will process input data and generate correct outputs specific to each assignment. There are some basic tools that you can use - add, subtract, jump, copy, etc. At the beginning it's simple, just to get you familiar with what's available and how it all works. But then it gets to the juicy bits. And it gets difficult. Very difficult. But was good fun trying to figure it out, even if my brain hurt sometimes. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It's a very good game. 
Especially if you're into programming, then you should consider it a personal challenge.
But don't judge this game just by looking at screenshots. They don't give it justice. 


[h1]Pros[/h1]
- fun puzzles
- easy to learn
- hard to master

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- irrelevant music
- hurt my brain

36409520.review:
this is a really disappointing review to make, especially considering how much i loved and still love little inferno, and also how much i loved the first few hours of human resource machine. but honestly, i'm super frustrated at this game and its potential and it ultimately fell flat on its face just a few hours in.

let's start with the first problem. this game is marketed for a generic audience, which in of itself suggests that you will need absolute zero experience with programming to play this game. this is one hundred percent false. the last few puzzles of the game are so complex that if you have no experience in programming, like i do, you will be stumped indefinitely until you look up hints or answers. it fails at introducing new ideas in any way; in fact, it somewhat reminds of the witness, as both have this artificial difficulty - the developers THINK that you can just figure out on your own what you need to do, but in fact do nothing whatsoever to ensure that that is the case. there are these super arrogant programmers here who are like "this was so easy!", which makes more people who do not have programming experience more inclined to buy the game - so i just wanted to get that out of the way and warn those people.

the worst part about human resource machine is its story. it tries and completely fails at implementing the previous success of little inferno's storytelling - a cycle of gameplay, some tidbits of story, and then more gameplay, etc., to entice the player to keep playing. except these tidbits of story here are so sparse and hard to achieve in the later portions of the game that it made the story completely worthless, and it would honestly i feel be the e x a c t same game if the story was taken out altogether. especially when i thought that i would enjoy this game because of its story. this is also so very different from little inferno as the concluding story is short and ultimately very inconclusive, in comparison to little inferno's wonderful and decidedly conclusive ending. this really aggravates me. a  l o t.

i want to say that i didn't hate human resource machine. i just didn't end up enjoying it either. the first 20 puzzles were interesting and complex, but that sudden difficulty spike around the halfway mark left me genuinely angry. the story was interesting but ultimately not worthwhile. if you're into programming, you'll probably like this, but if you're not, i warn you to stay away.

The gameplay is great and functions well.
I like how the "programming" is based on really basic Assembly. The game is kind of small and would be really cool if it would expand to a bit more advanced Assembly, for example "jump to pointer" (call (push the current instruction pointer, and jump to location), ret (pop the pushed instruction pointer and jump to it)) and the whole deal with CMP operator.

9,99€ is a nice price for a game like this and I finished the main story in about 5 hours and did some side missions as well after that.

36094170.review:
Это шедевр для любителей программирования вроде меня.

Вот плюсы:
1. Любимая графика, атмосфера и музыка от любимых разработчиков
2. Русская локализация!
3. Задачи по алгоритмированию, программированию и сплошные goto, goto, goto в которых можно запутаться легко. А точнее тут эта команда называется jamp.
4. Нету полноценных циклов, функций, операторов и библиотек (например математической функции для вычисления модуля). Всё нужно писать на низком уровне программирования. Что значительно усложняет читаемость кода.
5. Маркеры и комментарии. Ну это очень полезная вещь. Спасибо что до таких мелочей дошли разработчики.
6. Гениальный дебагер. Конкретно указывает где и какую ошибку совершил. 7. Замечательная история. Продолжение вселенной Little inferno. Хоть я и не доиграл пока до конца игры и решил срочно написать обзор, но думаю концовка будет такая же шикарная как и в Little inferno. Я тут не сомневаюсь. Разработчики красавы.

I've had this game sitting in my library before trying it out, but now that I did, I just love it.

It is a game about programming. That said, I imagine that neither professional programmers nor people who don't like that kind of mental exercise would enjoy it ... though the programmers at least might, but then as an easy passtime.

For people who are interested in programming, but never have done so, people who want to try programming to find out if it could be for them and people with a little programming experience, it is just a great puzzle game. After the initial levels, such players need to put some thinking in solving the levels, and solving both challenges to each level will often prove difficult (but still fun).

I normally do not play more than one or two levels every time, so I am way from completing it, let alone solving all the challenges. I guess, I would get annoyed if I did too much of at in one run, but as I do it, it will provide me with some fun and challenge every day for quite a while, and I love it!

The one thing that is really annoying is that you can click to switch the music off in the levels - but you have to do so every time. There is no way to switch music off completely or to switch sound off at all ingame.

34762407.review:
An assembly programming game.  Very comparable to TIS-100, and prettier, but simpler.

Puzzles start out trivial (just copy input to output), and get comparatively harder (factor this number into primes) as the game goes on.  

The instructions available are, if anything, even /less/ complete than TIS-100 -- copying data from one spot on the floor to the very next spot takes 4 steps at minimum -- but is ignorable except when trying to go for the size or speed challenge ratings.

If you're a low level coder, C or similar, this game will be easy, although some of the size/speed optimizations can still be challenging.  If you like logical puzzle games (like Spacechem), you'll also enjoy this game.

It is not a "learn to program" game, though; it is a "think logically" game.

Some things are weird, and point at a tablet base for the game -- comments are drawn, not typed. You can only copy entire programs, you can't copy a selection.  Things like that.  It can still be annoying at times, especially when you want to write a long comment.

终于100%了！Steam上第一个全成就！( ° ▽ ° )

类似程序设计入门的解密游戏，有着一些基本概念的引入和阐释，还能引导玩家几乎自觉地形成某些高级的概念。行数优化谜题不错，抠得非常之细，蓝色和绿色的分支优化都很不错，破解后带来巨大的成就感。但不少步数优化则非常拧巴，违反逻辑（某题码了160+行），有的甚至让玩家产生了很深的误解。交互似乎是为移动设备设计，PC上操作不便。总体来讲值得一玩。

======================================================================

（差几关还没玩完。）编程入门类模拟小游戏，只有基础的I/O、内存读取、加减操作，没有复杂的条件语句和循环，许多高级语法都需要借助jump来实现。游戏也很好的利用了这一点，将一些复杂的命令本身转化为谜题，尤其是斐波那契数列一关，Size Challenge很出色。Step Challenge则非常违法逻辑：本身编程应该多通过循环等来减少代码重复从而减小工作量和错误可能性。但游戏中jump语句本身占有step，多次使用来优化代码却会使表现变差，反而将多重循环复制成一份份来写这样违反逻辑的解决方式才是最优，非常令人气愤。另外游戏交互对于PC玩家也不友好，添加拖拽类型而非鼠标点击，很累人。注释条很难看，而且要手写输入而非打字，除非万不得已不会用吧。总的来讲还是值得一玩。

34666966.review:
From the developers of World of Goo and Little Inferno, here comes Human Resource Machine. In this game, we play as an employee of Tomorrow Corporation, the strange company that also showed up in their previous two games. Our role is quite simple: we'll receive a series of inputs, and we must write a program to obtain the desired outposts. It sounds (and is) simple at first, but as you progress through the game, you'll get more and more challenging puzzles to solve, including some optional ones that are really difficult.

I must admit, I had great difficulty with some of the latter puzzles. After all, programming has never been something I'm good at, but even then, this game is good to learn some basic skills. It's also interesting to see the logic behind some of the "programs" you build, how a series of simple commands can perform complex operations, like building a Fibonacci sequence up to the number you receive, or being able to take a number and output the digits that form it.

As far as the story goes, it's quite minimalistic in this game, even more so than in their previous games. There's a few cutscenes, plus dialogue from your "bosses" on each level that give you some insight into their lives, but nothing really elaborate. Not that it's a bad thing; even though the story in Tomorrow Corporation's games is fun and thought-provoking at times, it's always played a secondary role to the gameplay. The artstyle is the same we've seen in their previous games, and the soundtracks feels similar as well; again, that's not a bad thing, as their style always feels unique and quirky.

To conclude, I'd say that this is a fairly enjoyable game, one that I recommend to everyone who wishes to learn some basic programming, or who enjoys Tomorrow Corporation's quirky games.

It promises exactly what it delivers: It's a simple assembly-based puzzle game with a unique little artstyle. All the puzzles are genuine, something you'd find in an introductory programming textbook.

Although the exercises do get more complicated, there's not a whole lot of them, and it ends just about when it starts to get difficult. If a challenging puzzle is what you want, you'll find longer, more advanced programming-based games for the asking price of 10$.

34533304.review:
Un jeu de puzzle dans lequel on arrange du code qui sera lu par notre personnage pour effectuer les diverses actions nécessaires à remplir les objectifs de fin de niveau. Par les développeurs de [I]World of Goo[/I] qui m'avaient tellement déçu avec leur [I]Little Inferno[/I] (qui est un non-jeu en même  temps...) que je n'avais même pas daigné m'intéresser à leur nouveau jeu avant qu'un pote me conseille d'y jeter un œil.
Alors bon, graphiquement je trouve toujours ça extrêmement laid, cette espèce de design-dessin-tim-burtonesque, ça marchait à peu près sur les bestioles informes de [I]World of Goo[/I] mais sinon, c'est clairement pas ma came. Pas emballé non plus par le semblant de scénario ou les quelques dialogues, du même tonneau que le design graphique... Heureusement, ce n'est à priori ni pour les dessins ni pour le scénar' qu'on joue à des puzzle-game et je dois dire que je suis pour le coup plutôt satisfait de la partie jeu, la difficulté est progressive et bien amenée. Je ne sais pas si ça a un vrai intérêt pour des développeurs réguliers, mais pour moi que le sujet intéresse sans que je me sois jamais lancé dans des vrais projets, j'ai pris un vrai plaisir à établir mes "listes d"instructions" et à les voir être lues et exécutées par la machine.
Il me reste tout de même à finir la dernière "branche optionnelle" du jeu (il y a 3 niveaux - je crois - optionnels par monde), ce que je ferais certainement bientôt. Il faudrait aussi que je me relance dans les défis d'optimisations qui m'avaient bien intéressés au début mais que j'ai lâché vers la fin. Il faut dire que, outre la difficulté, la présentation du jeu fait que plus on avance, moins on a une vue d'ensemble sur son code et les petites options de "tags" ne suffisent pas à rendre ça beaucoup plus clair pour moi... En gros j'aurais pouvoir lire et retravailler mon code dans Notepad++ :p
Au final je suis plutôt content et même si je ne trouve pas qu'[I]Human Ressource Machine[/I] soit aussi intéressant que l'était [I]World of Goo[/I] à l'époque, je me suis réconcilié avec les développeurs de ces jeux et je jetterai tout de même un œil à leur prochaine création

Hru jednoznačně doporučuji všem přemýšlivým, programátorům a těm co by chtěli nahlédnout pod pokličku počítačů. Sestavení programu pro triviální až náročné úlohy je řešeno přístupným grafickým způsobem. Zpracování hry nelze nic vytknout.

+ výborný český překlad

[h1]DĚJ[/h1]
Nový zaměstnanec u firmy sídlící v budově se čtyřmi desítkami pater jde první den do kanceláře prvního patra této budovy, a pokud se mu podaří sepsat postup své práce pro svého šéfa, tak po roce bude povýšen do dalšího patra, kde na něj čeká sepisování dalšího postupu. Dokáže tento pracant vyšplhat až na vrchol budovy?

[h1]JAK SE HRAJE[/h1]
Hra "STROJ LIDSKÝCH ZDROJŮ" má uložení pozice pro tři hráče a obsahuje celkem 36 levelů. V každém je jedna úloha, pro kterou je potřeba "napsat" program podle zadání. Vždy se jedná o vytvoření výstupních informací na základě těch vstupních. Pro lepší pochopení je k dispozici i příklad vstupních informací a jaké z toho mají být výstupní. K dispozici je od 2 až po 11 příkazů. Ty jsou postupně představeny, takže hráč nemusí mít žádné zkušenosti s programováním. Pokud má program limit na počet příkazů nebo počet skoků v programu, tak mně se ho nepodařilo dosáhnout. Hra hráče nenutí k náročným postupům a tak dokončit level není až takový problém. Zkušenější a ti kteří se chtějí potrápit, mají možnost zkusit i levely, které jsou nepovinné a také pro všechny úlohy jsou připraveny nepovinné výzvy. Výzva je na velikost kódu (počet příkazů programu) a na rychlost kódu (průměrný počet vykonaných příkazů na úlohu). Rychlost kódu se zkouší na různých vstupních informacích, proto je výsledek průměrem všech. Takže nestačí jen vytvořit program pro konkrétní informace. Na to že je něco špatně je hráč upozorněn. Takže pokud je výstupní informace špatně, tak je běh programu zastaven a je mu oznámeno jaká informace byla očekávána. Pro ladění programu je k dispozici i krokování vpřed i vzad, což výrazně usnadňuje hru. Také lze program zkopírovat do schránky a editovat jeho textovou podobu mimo hru. Vložit zpět do hry jde samozřejmě také. Pro každý level je možné vytvořit a mít uložené až tři programy.

34439160.review:
[h1]来自码农朋友的安利[/h1]

[h1]总体感受[/h1]
小学学的Logo，初中学过几年Pascal，水平一般，就初一混了一次三等奖。今天一个码农好朋友推荐我玩这个。
游戏很棒，过程是蛮有意思的，但是玩得我也是心力交瘁的。

[h1]游戏设定[/h1]
这是一个被BAN了if for while，只能用条件磕碜到抠脚的goto的算法游戏。（分 无条件，等于0，小于0三种）
我只能说，太他娘蛋疼啦！
这感觉好比你打球的时候，规定不准运球，不准跳，不准跑……你就老老实实传球、投篮、卡位去吧……

[h1]游戏体验[/h1]
想当年老师三令五申，“不是特殊情况，不许用GOTO！！！”，这次自己算是切身体会到了，这语句真是反人类，思路真的好难整理，复查修改时候也特别不方便……
一开始有一关我还妄想画流程图，结果特喵的画完一个菱形，想起来根本没法用if的时候，感受到了深深的蛋痛。
哭给你看……

当你欣喜发现，你程序跑对了过关了，然后就发现无论是步数还是行数都不符合要求。那种抓狂的感觉，阿西吧。
让人深深回忆起当年计算机竞赛时候，各种运算超时的恐惧……

还有一些关卡，行数和步数是不能同时满足的，你得重新换个完全不同的思路。感觉脑子都快打起来了。

[h1]优缺点与评价[/h1]
+ 画风清新可爱，起码还挺提神。
+ 难度适中。
+ 点亮双灯的时候，还是挺有成就感的。 
- 音乐初听不错，听多了开始感到烦躁……不知道是不是我一个人的感觉。
- 可能不接受这类游戏的人，是很难安利出去的。

评分：8.5/10

34033127.review:
[Summary/TLDR at the bottom.]

Human Resource Machine is a graphically cutified, [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assembly_language]assembly-language[/url]-simulating and thus educational logic puzzle game. You are given the task of formulating solutions to problems based on transforming a sequence of digits and/or letters to another one using very basic instructions like copy from here to there, add, subtract and more. Your avatar will then act as a processor in human form and execute your orders stubbornly as given, either leading you to the expected result or total mayhem.

If this sounded weird or complicated to you – well, it is getting more complicated the further you get into the game, but don't worry: Human Resource Machine does a great job of introducing players to instructions and their combinations step by step without the need for any experience in programming (read the additional information at the bottom of this review concerning this rating). This also happens in a humorous and casual way with lots of irony and social criticism.

At the end of the game you might have an idea of the typical workday the little fingernail-sized chip that is hidden somewhere in your computer has to go through.

[b]Target Audience[/b]:
[list]
[*] people interested in programming (e.g. who want to try it out or get to know it)
[*] people who like logic-based puzzle games
[*] people who study programming or plan to do so
[/list]
[b]Pros[/b]:
[list]
[*] Cute graphics and animations.
[*] Slim, but humorous story.
[*] Good introductions and explanations that make the game suitable for people without any programming experience.
[*] Programs can even be copied to or pasted from a text editor.
[*] Intuitive and well-designed mouse-only controls.
[*] The game auto-saves everything so you can come and go whenever you like.
[*] For each level you have three slots for your program so you can try out different solutions and backup your original solution before attempting to optimize or change your strategy.
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]:
[list]
[*] [spoiler]The whole scene seems to permanently slightly move in a floating way, which is in my opinion rather irritating and probably shall simulate the movement of skyscrapers due to the wind. It didn't give me motion-sickness, but I'd say it has the potential to. I couldn't find an option to disable this effect.[/spoiler] (This is [b]not[/b] a spoiler, but you cannot un-see/un-know this and maybe you never notice, if you don't read it and thus have a better experience in the game. It is probably a relevant contra point, if you are a very sensitive person.)
[/list]
[b]Additional Information[/b]: I myself am a programmer, so I can only guess that this game also introduces people without programming experience well. Without hurrying and with very little AFK-time I enjoyed this game for around 13 hours until 100% completion. I got this game in the [i]Humble Freedom Bundle[/i]. I finished the game one day before this review after playing it on several days.

33710543.review:
[h1] What is this game? [/h1]
In a nutshell, Human Resource Machine is an introduction to programming logic. You are tasked with creating autonomous instructions for your corporate slave/minion to follow such that he/she can complete various mundane tasks. These instructions come in the form of copy and paste commands, loops (called jumps), addition and subtraction operations, and more. There is no prior programmer experience required, as the game does a great job of slowing introducing its various concepts and gives the player tons of feedback along the way.

For those who are a little more familiar with programming, each stage has optimization challenges that ask you to find solutions with either the fewest commands or the shortest number of steps. On top of that, there are optional challenge stages that are much more advanced than their main-game counterparts.

[h1] You Should [b]Buy[/b] This Game If: [/h1]
[list][*]You're interested in learning basic programming logic
[*]You like logic puzzles and are a very meticulous thinker
[*]You like that feeling of doing something productive[/list]

[h1] You Should [b]Skip[/b] This Game If: [/h1]
[list][*]You don't like programming or have no interest in it
[*]You want a fast-paced, action-oriented game
[*]You'd rather not do something that feels like homework[/list]

[h1] My Personal Opinion (Recommendation Reflects This) [/h1]
I had a very mild exposure to programming prior to this game, so I fall more into the "new person interested in programming" category. For someone like that, I believe that Human Resource Machine is a great, fun and intuitive introduction. While starting out very basic, HRM's puzzles become extremely challenging and encourage you to think creatively to solve a variety of problems. This game actually gave me a new appreciation for programming, as even the simplest of tasks can require a ton of steps. Defintely not a game for everyone, but if you're at all interested in getting into programming, this is a great start!

33685116.review:
I both love and hate this game at the same time...

It is well made with 41 challenges in total and the difficulty begins ramping up past around level 15. On top of just completing the challenges you also have two optimisation goals which are least number of steps taken and least number of lines used, I found I could mostly beat both of these with one solution but its not always possible.

What to expect if you buy this game:
- A selection of challenging logic puzzles
- You WILL sit there for long periods of time trying to figure out the later puzzles, especially when optimising
- You WILL begin confusing yourself and getting a headache trying to solve the logic puzzles
- You WILL feel amazing when you finally complete them.

If you dislike difficult puzzle games and hate the idea of spending an hour trying to figure out a single logic puzzle then I suggest you move along otherwise I highly recommend this game.

33431851.review:
Human Resource Machine은 프로그래밍을 해 본 적이 없는 사람도 시작해 볼 수 있는 프로그래밍 게임입니다. 플레이어는 회사의 직원이 되어 주어진 여러 과제를 해결해야 하며, 이를 위해 어셈블리어와 유사한 게임 내 언어로 명령의 묶음(프로그램)을 작성해야 합니다. 처음 몇 개는 아주 쉽지만, 나중에는 쓸 수 있는 명령의 종류가 많아지면서 점점 복잡해집니다.
 개인적으로 느낀 장단점을 나열하면서 구체적인 내용에 대해 적어 보자면

[b] 장점[/b]
[list]
[*] 잘 만든 그래픽 - 회사원이나 박스 등 여러 게임 요소가 전반적으로 귀엽게 표현돼 있으며, 한편으로는 프로그래밍에 방해되지 않게 각 요소가 시각적으로 잘 분리돼 있습니다. 다른 알려진 프로그래밍 게임인 TIS-100이나 Shenzen I/O 등을 보면 이게 얼마나 예쁜지 알 수 있죠. 적어도 좀 게임같이는 생겼다고 할 수 있겠네요.

[*]  친절한 진입 장벽 및 인터페이스 - 프로그래밍을 전혀 모르는 사람을 위해 각 요소를 꽤 친절하게 설명해 주며, 처음 몇 레벨을 통해 뭘 어떻게 해 봐야 할지를 알게 해 줍니다. 또 프로그램이 잘못되면 뭐가 틀렸는지를 설명해 주고, 원한다면 한 단계씩 돌려 볼 수도 있습니다. 실제 어셈블리에 비해 훨씬 편하고 친절해요.

[*] 도전 요소 - 깨고 난 뒤에 코드 수 줄이기나 실행 속도 늘리기 등의 요소를 통해 파고들기를 할 수 있습니다. 후반 스테이지들은 이게 꽤 어려워서 다 깬 뒤에도 게임을 계속 할만한 동기부여가 조금 됩니다.
[/list]

[b]단점[/b]
[list]
[*] 콘텐츠 분량과 난이도 문제 - 누군가가 이 게임을 두고 "입문자용 요소가 완전하지 않은데 숙련자용으로 충분히 어렵지도 않다"고 했는데, 저도 비슷한 느낌을 받았습니다. 초반부 레벨은 꽤 쉬운데 중반 이후 어느 시점부터 해야 하는 일의 난이도가 확 뜁니다. 컴퓨터 전공자인 저에게는 큰 문제가 없었지만, 초심자에게는 엄청 낯설 개념이 많았어요. 한편 제 기준으로 깨는 것 자체가 아주 어려운 문제는 딱히 없었습니다. 최적화 문제는 있지만 이건 푸는 것과 별개의 영역이라... 전반적으로 중간 난이도 콘텐츠랑 끝판왕 콘텐츠가 모자라다고 느꼈네요.

[*] 속도 최적화 - 게임의 도전 요소 중 속도 최적화는 유저에게 잘 안 보입니다. 코드 간의 상대적인 빠르고 느림은 어느 정도 짐작할 수 있지만, 평균 몇 회의 지시사항이 쓰일지는 전혀 예측할 수가 없죠. 이게 프로그램 실행에 최소한의 애니메이션 재생 시간이 걸려서 빨리빨리 테스트를 못 해 보는 문제와 맞물려서 꽤 귀찮습니다. 다소 불편한 점이에요.
[/list]
 위 단점과 별개로 왜 하필 초심자가 할 수 있는 게임인데 어셈블리어를 모티브로 했을까에 대한 의문도 있지만, 게임 자체와는 별개니까 이건 넘어갑니다.
 전반적으로 프로그래밍 경험자 및 초심자 모두가 시작하기에는 무난한 게임이지만, 중반 이후 게임의 적성에 맞을지는 다소 갈릴 게임입니다. 정가에 살 게임은 아니고, 60~75% 세일 정도에 한 번 사서 해 볼 만한 게임이라고 할 수 있습니다.

若非这款游戏对于程序运行的直观展现实在是对我等编程白痴太过友好，我是不会选择花那么多时间去解锁它的全成就的，不得不说这就是它的最大魅力所在。

[spoiler]对于我个人而言，有几关的思维水平的确是我所不能及的，在此也跟想要入坑的同好们提个醒：第20年和第28年的平均步数挑战，以及第三阶段（绿色路线）的整个副分支（即第36、38和40年，其中第38年的程序体积挑战还算比较简单，我也有幸得出了应该是目前为止玩家分享出的最优解法），还有最后一关，即第41年。[/spoiler]

评分：9/10

寓教于乐的好游戏，希望以后能够在计算机程序教学中见到更多与之相似的教学手段，帮助学生们更好地理解编程思想和硬件作用。

33010895.review:
El juego consta de 41 niveles de los cuales 6 Son Escenas cinematicas, Dando lugar a 35 niveles Jugables, Con una duracion aproximada de 7-8 Horas Para quien recien lo empieza a jugar de principio a fin e incluyendo Logros de Steam, Aunque podria subir a 10 o 12 horas, dependiendo de la mente que este jugandolo.

Mi experiencia con el Juego:

Yo Debo confesar que deje de jugarlo aproximadamente en el nivel 12 o 13 Por la gran dificultad que me conllevaba resolver los puzzles o programas, Solo pude cumpletarlo mirando tutoriales para cada uno de los subsiguientes niveles, Intente resolverlos hasta aproximadamente el 23 o 24 y luego directamente copie los programas y saltie todo hasta el final debido al crecimiento exponencial de dificultad que terminaron teniendo.

Lo mejor del Juego:

Los dialogos estan geniales, Muy bien hechos, tipico de un juego de Kyle Gabler, como World of goo y little inferno, ese tono sarcastico, esa forma de presentar a los personajes con su toque especial, esta muy logrado y con poco material.

Los graficos son espectaculares, con esa tradicional aura caricaturesca medio noir y new school mezclados que es tipica de los juegos de Kyle Gabler, El inicio con el cartel de empleado y el progresivo envejecimiento del personaje (cambia a Adulto de mediana edad y luego ya mayor edad solo el pelo) son algunos detalles, junto con los cambios en la habitacion y los 6 cortos cinematicos hacen que saques sonrisas y le pone diversion a un juego donde mas alla de ese tipo de interacciones, solo se utiliza la logica pura y nada mas.

Los menues son simples y faciles de usar, las ayudas que dan los personajes tambien, la descripcion del desafio
me parece copado e ingenioso que den 3 tabletas para  crear diferentes formas de llegar a la misma solucion 
El ejecutador de comandos tambien, y sobre todo que tenga funciones de copiar, cortar y pegar son muy buenas para intercambiarlas con otras personas

la musica es estupenda, envuelve en todo momento, Aunque siento que falta algo de variedad habiendo solo 17 canciones que rotan en diferentes momentos del juego y son bastante cortas.

Lo peor del juego:

Los comandos son dificiles y hechos especialmente para gente que sepa bastante de logica, programacion y matematica, igual lo son los desafios y por ende, Algunos logros.

No posee Steam cloud: Creo que no hace falta mas explicacion, pero hoy en pleno 2017 es una vergüenza que un juego no posea dicha caracteristica, he visto varios juegos de estudios indies y demas implementar esta funcionalidad (tengo entendido que deben pagarle a steam para tenerla) y realmente dudo que pesen demasiado los archivos, como para no implementarla, sobre todo limitandose a 3 perfiles maximo.

Que se puede mejorar: 

Faltan niveles, el juego es demasiado corto, ya que esta hecha toda la base de programacion, podian haber agregado varios niveles mas, como los de secuencia de fibonacci y otros

Modding: Permitir que gente agregue niveles y comandos y cualquier cosa que se les ocurra, tambien podria haber un competitivo contrareloj o algun otro modo entre jugadores para competir o cooperar, etc.

Mas idiomas: Idiomas como el Urdu, Japones o Suajili No figuran en la lista de idiomas, Hay poco texto para traducir y no vendria mal agregar mas idiomas para que haya mas publico

El precio: Quizas de 10 a 8 dolares, por el tema de duracion.

Consideraciones finales:

El juego pide poquisimos requisitos, pesa solo 200 megas, asi que anda en cualquier computadora sin mayores complicaciones.

No lo compre, salvo que sea un Experto en matematica, Logica y programacion (idealmente, en estos 3 campos) ya que afrontara dificultades Muy altas hacia el primer tercio del juego o hacia la mitad, en caso de tener algunos conocimientos mas que yo, pero el juego Dista mucho de ser lo que parecen las fotos, Es pura resolucion de problemas y son bastante dificiles, Aunque lo vea en oferta, no se deje llevar por sentimentalismos, Sea racional (yo lo compre por que como me gustaron todos los otros juegos de Kyle Gabler, pense que este no me decepcionaria bajo ningun punto de vista, lo compre ciegamente y algo de decepcion me trajo).

No lo disfrute mucho, Pero no quiere decir que sea un mal juego, todo lo contrario, Aunque deberia venir con una etiqueta que diga ADVERTENCIA!! Solo para entendidos.

32802305.review:
This game is actually fantastic at teaching proceedural coding techniques, and some of the basics about how the inner workings of computers work (this reminds me a lot of what I learned when I was coding in Base C during my semester of Data Structures and Discreet Mathematics in College when I was getting my BS in Computer Science). The code structure itself reminds me of the Basic coding language, though the commands aren't the same names (GOTO is called JUMP, and there is an arrow you use to indicate where). 

Other than the coding stuff (which is completely taught to you in-game, so you don't have to already know it), it is also just a really good puzzle game, with "optimization" challenges that push you to not just solve the puzzle, but to have the best possible solution. Even if you are familiar with programming, the challenges and puzzles can sometimes get the best of you, and I poured 8 hours into this game my first weekend with it (this weekend). 

Absolutely love this game, and recommend it to programmers and non-programmers alike.

32642656.review:
終於全破啦!爽!

Human Resource Machine，中譯為人力資源機器，是一款以編程作為解謎要素的小遊戲。
想體驗程式猿的生活，玩這款就對了!包括以下內容:
為什麼卡bug了!到底哪裡錯了!
我成功讓這串數字排列了，可是為什麼下一段行不通!
為什麼我的上司只會坐著耍嘴皮子!
我不想管優化了!我只想讓程式運行成功!(瘋狂的拉Jump到各種地方，把程序搞得臃腫又難看)

以上，幸好我不是程式猿(被打)

整體來說，是一個相當良心的小遊戲
搭配著有點可愛又有點詭異的風格，以及一股獨特的黑色幽默
還有看著工人高速移動排序時，真紓壓啊~~

但我還是得說，這遊戲後期難度還真不小啊....
到了乘法器就開始讓我頭疼了，在19關之前我還能邊玩邊搞定優化，但是怎樣都搞不定後我就放棄了，開始朝向臃腫程序之路直奔而去
在主線裡(後面的支線都被我跳過了)第41關排序樓層好難啊!超頭痛!
橫跨了將近一個禮拜的思考時間，我才在入睡前得到了啟發，終於在隔天搞定
我甚至還看到有人說難度偏簡單，對此我只能說，我果然沒有編程的才能啊~~~ヽ(●´∀`●)ﾉ

推薦給對程序有一點興趣，想要來點動腦難題，以及想體驗一下程式員感受的玩家遊玩。

32623202.review:
I highly recommend this game to people with some programming experience.

If you know some programming, you'll probably speed through 2/3rds of the game.
However, the green levels are all about real world applications.
The editor purposefully limits the commands you are able to use, and It's very fun trying to create a modulus operator without using division, or creating a sorting algorithm without comparison.

I had programming experience coming into this game, but I imagine that those who are not experienced will take longer on the first half of the game and learn the concepts. The game has a very well formed difficulty curve, and eases you into the levels nicely.

By far the best part of this game are the optional levels. Be sure to play those.

While It took me ~4 hours to finish the game, but those were 4 hours of 100% quality.
However, I don't think the game is worth $10. I would wait for a sale.

32587576.review:
Один из монологов в игре: "Вы тоже любите свою работу? Хм, как странно... между прочим эти уровни не обязательны для выполнения, но разве достижение идеала - это не то, ради чего мы стараемся? Что может быть лучше чем идеально выполненная работа?.. Кстати, именно поэтому я частенько задерживаюсь до поздна... Когда же я последний раз была дома? 15... 20 лет назад?" Так вот, подобные саркастично-ироничные монологи придают игре особую атмосферу, которую я даже не могу описать! Однако, как бы интересно вам не было читать эти забавные комментарии ваших игровых начальников, главной особенностью игры как многие уже догадались является - правильно геймплей. Начинаем нашу работу в Tomorrow Corporation!

1) Геймплей. Поистинне уникальная находка среди всех товаров в Steam! Что может быть интереснее создания математических алгоритмов для выполнения множества самых разнообразных операций от самых легких до комбинированных, где вам придется применить всю проницательность ума, стойкость ваших нервных клеток и... немного Интернета. Да, возможно метод не из самых честных, но порой приходится составлять весьма огромные программы в 100+ команд, где трудновато уследить за своим ходом мыслей и поиском решений. К слову говоря, разработчики предусмотрели это, добавив функцию подсказок: просто попросите начальника рассказать больше о данной операции, чтобы вы знали примерный алгоритм действий. Не говорю уже о надписях которые можно повсеместно прикреплять к программам, дабы слегка облегчить работу. Но, как я и говорил дополнительные уровни могут вас изрядно потрепать: Числа Фиббоначи, Умножение на 8 (сложно уложится в несколько шагов). Однако, решение всех этих головоломок принесет больше радости чем страданий!

2) Сюжет. Еще одна уникальная в своем роде деталь. Наполненная черным юморком, загадками и естественно тоннами пасхалок из Little Inferno и World of Goo. Действительно рай для настоящего фаната игр Tomorrow Corporation! Ничего рассказывать не буду, иначе появится гора спойлеров. Сюжет полностью построен вокруг занимательной жизни нашего работника в рабочее время и так, как катсцен немного в них рассказывается вся история достаточно подробно!

3) Графика. По скринам можно заметить, что игра не выделяется какими-то новшествами от других проектов Tomorrow Corporation в графическом плане. Тот же самый Little Inferno в разы красивее из-за своих спецэффектов при взаимодействии с предметами. Она в меру проста и по-своему красива. Скорее графика была заточена под слабые компьютеры, чтобы не взирая ни на какие преграды игроки могли насладиться процессом решения головоломок. Я считаю, что курс был выбран правильно, ибо как мы знаем отличная графика грешит множеством багов (привет Ubisoft'у).

4) Саундтрек. Ну вот тут как-то не очень вышло... Как говорится "маловато будет". Да, он тут конечно есть, но всего 3-4 мелодии, насколько я помню. Как раз то, что надо для приятной и спокойной игры, но все равно хотелось бы побольше мелодий.

32466158.review:
Cool intro if you want to get into some programming.
 
[h1]Story:[/h1]
There’s a little something charming about the robopocalypse but it doesn’t really matter. Solve the programs

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
The entire point of the game is to code basically. You have a limited instruction set where you can add, subtract, jump, jump conditionally, and combinations of those. You use these primitive instructions to solve problems ranging from dividing to sorting. Overall, the game is a lot easier to get into compared to something like TIS-100. A drag and drop system with an easy system to get help really goes to making this really friendly for people not familiar with programming. For people that are, it’s similar to a programming in a SUPER basic assembly and the challenge comes from making the programs run as efficiently as possible with the fewest instructions. If you’ve done any programming in the past, you’ll probably be able to solve the problems without many issues and the efficiency is the difficulty. If you’re into low level stuff, great but I was kind of hoping for functions or the ability to put a number in a register but sadly those aren’t there. However, I can understanding wanting to stick to a limited instruction set.
 
[h1]Graphics/Performance: (with a 970, 4790K, 16GB of RAM, SSD)[/h1]
Cartoonish visuals and it ran great. No issues
 
[h1]Final Thoughts:[/h1]
Overall, it’s a good way to get familiarized with programming and is pretty new programmer friendly.

32197634.review:
This is an absolute cracker.

The simplest way to describe Human Resource Machine is as a game that "gamifies" writing computer code. Each level is essentially a particular computational task that you need to complete. Easy to begin but gets VERY tricky. Many of the hard achievements, which comprise of among other things requests to optimise your code, were certainly beyond me! 

It has the same surreal, Tim Burton-esque feel of the developers earlier title, World of Goo (which is a classic) but it's a totally different game. It has great music, whacky graphical style, and being set in a large corporation, takes potshots at modern office life in a most amusing way. 

Recommended to anyone who loves great puzzle games (and anyone tempted to minimise the skill required to optimise computer code).

To preface this, I won this on steamgifts.com.

This is a awesome game to learn the basics behind programing.  It is a puzzle game that uses common algorithms known in the programming world as levels in it's game to help the player visually see how an algorithm functions.  It is very capable and accessible, but the levels towards the end get rather complex.  I would say as a Software Engineer, if you don't know how to program this is a pretty good introduction to the thought processes programmers have to make on a day to day basis.  

But on to it being more of a game... I really enjoyed it for what it was.  It is a hard complex puzzle game that will have you taking your time solving relatively difficult puzzles.  The game itself functions well and has everything you would need including debuggers and a way to import programs. 

I would give this a 4/5.  It is pretty fun, a bit frustrating at times when you can't figure out a solution or an optimal solution.

Human Resource Machine is one of the greatest educational puzzle games that I do recommend checking out!

Even though educational games can be boring and uninteresting, Human Resource Machine isn't as it teaches coding, which is what the main game's all about, the fun and simple way. There's none of those complex binary, brackets and sub-levels as it's easy as INBOX and OUTBOX, toning the level of coding down into the simplest level possible.

Add that with a thrilling, yet somewhat suspenseful, story and a learning curve that starts off easy with the basics before easing you in with difficult and mind-scratching puzzles, it'll keep you coming back for more to suit your coding needs!

31915853.review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review [/h1]

Human Resource Machine is a game developed and published by Tomorrow Corporation, the same peoople behind Little Inferno. So much so, this game takes many of its satirical humour and art style from Little Inferno and implements it into Human Resource Machine

This game reminded me of SpaceChem or more precisely trying to do basic programming in Java

The game consists of 41 levels. The first half dozen levels are extremely simple and are best thought of as a tutorial to teach you the rules of the later levels. You are inputted a string of letter or numbers and need to do certain things to them. Such as sort in order from lowest to highest

You have a limited number of commands to use and each level has a challenge of size and speed. Which is how few commands you need and how few steps you need to finish your program

Overall, I slightly enjoyed the game and had fun tweaking my programs to meet the size challenges but as opposed to Little Inferno, not everyone will like Human Resource Machine because of its basic programming game mechanics...

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

31833483.review:
Human Resource Machine is a fun game where you progressively learn to do more and more complicated programming exercises, but done exclusively in an instruction set that is very reminicent of assembly language. You're basically writing assembly for the entire game.

This might sound boring, but it's quite the challenge. There are optimal solutions for both speed and instruction size, so figuring out the correct way to solve each level (sometimes requiring different solutions for both of the challenges) presents a whole slew of goals to overcome while completing the game.

I'm a programmer, so playing this was actually a lot of fun. Assembly was never my favorite language to write in, but playing Human Resource Machine did kind of instill some appreciation for how much fun it is to optimize your code to the highest degree possible.

31445894.review:
I have a love-hate relationship with this game.

As you can gather from other reviewers, this is a game about programming (which is something I know almost nothing about). Getting something from input, interacting with it as the challenge requires, and then sending it to the output. 
From what I do know about programming, for the most part, it's very logical. It might take some figuring out how to get around a problem, but it's almost always doable (not always elegantly mind), and that is something I love about this game. It's possible to take awhile, think things through, and have a realisation as to what you need to do. 

The problem I have with the game is when it deviates from this (and I would say it only does in the later levels). I don't know if it deviates from this because I don't know enough about programming to understand why it doesn't work the way I want, or if it's the game just being a douche (I expect a mixture of the two). For example, you're able to subtract letters from numbers, but not add them together, nor letters to letters. This makes it possible, but the game never really explains /why/ I could do one, but not the other (beyond giving a 'bad output, you can't do this'). 

Quite a lot of the problems I have with the game seems to stem from the game not giving you a 'check if' tag, to check if a space is occupied, or has a specific number on it, or something, anything. Of course, this might make the levels a lot easier, but it's this that I feel is where it deviates away from the programming aspect just to be a douche. 

Another issue I have - not with the game so much I guess - is that while I want to complete the game on my own steam, if I don't know what to do, or don't understand what it wants (nor the help it gives you in game), I'm pretty much SOL. The only help online offers a 'this is how to beat it', rather than a 'this is the way you need to think' or 'this is what it's asking'. I asked a few programming-minded friends of mine to help, and even they weren't able to give me hints about what I was meant to do (not that I'm blaming the game for THAT, they just might not understand because of something previously explained in the game that they don't understand themselves). 

I've done most of the game as is (two levels short of the main 'campaign', and four or five levels short of the extra challenges), but your play time will vary depending on your programming experience, and how fast you can understand and twist these concepts to your own whims. 

Do I recommend this game? That's hard. Yes, and no. If you enjoy programming games? Hell yes. Do you enjoy logical games? Yes. Do you enjoy difficult games? Eh, I guess it can be. If you like all of them? Buy this without hesitation. It's awesome.

31445007.review:

At no point does the game ever explain anything to you, or even give you a hint. That could be okay, except for the insane jumps in difficulty. All of a sudden at level 20 you have to multiply two numbers, but there's no multiplying. All you can do is add and subtract. And you can't even tell it to do that any specific number of times. And apparently if you do it absolutely flawlessly, it takes 15 steps. 15 steps to multiply two numbers. 

The game expects you to leave the game and find programming lessons and then come back to it. And the game is just a series of practice problems with cute characters. There isn't anything "cool" to do that requires you to do programming stuff, like a Zachatronics game. So what's the point?

This game reminded me of SpaceChem, or more precisely programming in Basic 30 years ago.  The game consists of 41 levels.  The first half dozen levels are extremely simple and are best thought of as a tutorial to teach you the rules of the later levels.  You are inputted a string of letter or numbers and need to do certain things to them.  Such as sort in order from lowest to highest etc.  You have a limited number of commands to use and each level has a challenge of size and speed.  Which is how few commands you need and how few steps you need to finish your program.  Overall, I enjoyed the game and had fun tweaking my programs to meet the size challenges.  I did get discussion board hints on a handful of speed challenges to get the final achievement.

打完通关的一刻，我长吁一口气——多年的编程没白学。

通关的CG里，老板拿出计算机和我说“你被辞退了”。

心里忽然泛起一丝难以描述的情感，既彷徨又激动。

中国的计算机行业发展得算是很好了，但是真正给计算机科学奠基的是欧美的科学家们。

有人调侃这游戏是一个“汇编入门”教程，让我们体会到了超小指令集和存储空间带来的各种不便利。

完成一个简单的数学任务，需要大量繁琐的指令，如果放到现在，会不会有人说“你这有什么用？”

却没想到就是前人孜孜不倦地完成了许许多多没有用的工作，才在往后的日子里发挥了巨大的作用。

早期的计算机，存储单元少，就想办法减少指令。

早期的处理器，运行频率低，就想办法优化时间复杂度。

那段时期的计算机科学家造出了无数的“轮子”

解放了无数做着重复劳动的人，从而去做更多有意义的事情。

你可以去做“人”该做的事情了，

这是游戏结局，老板的一句话。

我们是受益者。

谢谢你们！

评分 10/10

명령어와 사람 하나와 바닥의 빈 공간만을 이용해서 각종 문제를 풀어나간다.
클리어를 위한 마지막 문제는 정렬이고 심화문제 마지막 문제는 소인수분해하기다. (알고리즘 공부를 했다면 비교적 빠르게 풀 수 있다)
엔딩 보는 건 어렵지 않게 가능하다. 문제는 최적화 도전인데 정말 별별 아이디어를 다 짜내야 한다. 개인적으로 숫자 3개 정렬하는 문제가 가장 힘들었다.
최적화 도전 팁을 주자면
[b]공통[/b]
[list]

[/list]
[b]사이즈[/b]
[list]
[*]속도는 신경 쓰지 말자
[*]최대한 겹치는 코드가 없도록 jump를 잘 쓰자

[b]속도[/b]
[list]
[*]명령어 개수 신경 쓰지 말자
[*]불필요한 연산을 하느라 시간 쓰지 않도록 하자
[*]루프 내부에 명령어가 최대한 적게 있도록 하자
[*]필요하면 중복 코드를 만들자 (루프 풀어버리기라던가)
[/list]
이렇게 했을 때 목표를 초과달성하면 쾌감을 느낄 수 있다.

Gran juego de puzzles!

Empiezo por el principio: Soy programador. Paso horas escribiendo código, que funciona... Normalmente.
Llevo ya años en este oficio, y me gusta mucho, pero tengo otros hobbies. Así que verme fuera de horas de trabajo
usando papel y lápiz para optimizar una tarea, como si estuviese otra vez aprendiendo a programar, ha sido un placer inesperado. Porque de eso va este juego, de programar en un pseudo lenguaje similar al ensamblador, básico pero capaz de hacer cosas muy potentes.

Para los no programadores, aconsejo que no tengan miedo, porque empieza muy poco a poco, los tutoriales son geniales, y tiene un sentido del humor muy particular y efectivo. Critica las grandes organizaciones con maestría, de una forma suave pero sin cortarse. El estilo gráfico es desenfadado, funcional y cuidado. Personalmente me encantan los muñecotes y la voz amorfa que te habla para darte la información de cada pantalla.

Súper recomendable para quien le guste pensar delante de la pantalla, hay que tener un punto de paciencia, pero tampoco es desesperante. A menos que intentes cumplir los retos de optimización, que ahí ya hay que darse mucha caña. Personalmente sólo he realizado algunos, mi biblioteca de Steam es demasiado grande para pasarme otras 10 o 15 horas con el juego (tardé aproximadamente eso en pasar todos los niveles de forma básica y con algún reto suelto), pero para los completistas estoy seguro que les dará el doble de horas sin duda.

Totalmente recomendado!

30222083.review:
We've had opportunity to unleash HRM on a range of different experience levels and everyone has enjoyed it.  I had the pleasure of watching a 14 year old, never exposed to programming before, write a sequence reverser in about 30 seconds.  I've watched groups discuss what cards the employee will be carrying at each point and what order the instructions should go in.  I've even stayed up late trying to get all the optimisation challenges!

It's a fairly comprehensive game - you get 42 challenges.  There's a little bit of story as you climb the corporate ladder, which breaks up the game nicely.

The language you program in is quite simple, but I was impressed that it covered indirection.  You can read from offsets on the carpet.  Also, because you're dragging instructions around, there's no way to write an invalid program.  All programs run, they just might not do anything useful.  You can label variables and instructions, too.

In terms of being an introduction to thinking like a programmer (in the small), it feels about right.  Unlike some of the other games, there are no bizzare restrictions that exist to give you 70's nostalgia, your programs can be as long as you like and you usually have some scratch space.  The values are typed, and you will be told off if you overflow, or try to subtract a letter from a number.

30215980.review: Wish there could be real Traditional Chinese.

30202020.review:
Bei dem Spiel lernt man spielerisch eine einfache (fiktive) Assembler-Programmiersprache. Durch die Visualisierung des Programmablaufs kann man ganz einfach nachvollziehen, was das eigene Programm gerade tut.

Wie funktioniert's?

Der Spieler bekommt eine Aufgabe präsentiert. Dabei gibt es ein Förderband, auf dem Pakete herein und ein Förderband, auf dem Pakete heraus transportiert werden. Eine Aufgabe kann beispielsweise sein, nur das größere von zwei aufeinander folgenden Paketen auf das Ausgangsförderband zu stellen.

Auf der rechten Seite kann der Spieler mit verschiedenen Befehlen wie Lesen, Schreiben, Addition, Subtraktion oder Sprungbefehlen ein Programm grafisch erstellen. Das "Programmieren" erfolgt dabei per Drag'n'Drop.

Sobald das Programm erstellt ist, kann man es ablaufen lassen. Dabei wird einfach und verständlich auf visuelle Weise dargestellt was genau passiert. Die Geschwindigkeit des Programmablaufs kann variiert werden und auch ein schrittweises Durchgehen ist möglich um Fehler zu finden.

Für wen ist das Spiel geeignet?

Wer noch nie Assembler programmiert hat, und es gerne lernen will, sollte sich an das Spiel wagen. Die, die Assembler schon mal gesehen haben, können hier einige neue Aufgaben lösen und vor allem Optimierung lernen. Für echte Assembler-Profis der alten Schule wird das Spiel wohl zu einfach sein. Aber auch für Programmierer, die bisher nur Hochsprachen wie Java gesehen haben, kann es durchaus zur Herausforderung werden, wenn man noch einen Befehl einsparen soll. Möglicherweise können Eltern auf diese Weise auch ihre Kinder an das Programmieren heranführen. Der Schwierigkeitsgrad ist am Anfang einfach genug und steigert sich mit jeder Aufgabe.

30186736.review:
Human Resource Machine is all the fun of coding in Assembly, only instead of a text editor you have a cute/odd cartoon character.

Nothing captures the feeling of starting at compiler errors quite like having a tiny cartoon avatar literally throw away the data you're trying to output, causing it to shatter on the ground.  And like an actual computer, your miniscule tormentor will follow your instructions down to the letter, causing you to curse at your own stupidity while they infinitely add two numbers together because you forgot to include a way to break out of the loop.

I'd recommend this game, but I feel like the difficulty ramps up a little too quickly, and it's very easy to become frustrated with, although that's honestly part of the charm.  I imagine it would be a fun way to get introduced to computer logic.

30166571.review:
As someone who does a bit of computer science education, I'd be happy to recommend this to high school students, or even early university students, as a way of getting their heads around assembly language and practising their skills. Having a gradual introduction of more operations, and multiple levels of success with the extra challenges, means that it can be used with students with a range of ability levels and keep them engaged for longer.

As well as the ease of constructing programs in the click-and-drag manner, it's nice to be able to use the cut-and-paste features as well: being able to copy your source code into a text editor and hand-craft sequences can be a real time-saver on some of the challenges (especially time-based challenges, where you're trying to avoid the extra overheads of looping).

It's got some useful feedback features for learning - one I was especially impressed with was that it can tell you if you've made a program that works for your current input, but will fail for other inputs. It's a good encouragement to recognise the value of a general solution, rather than only solving the problem that's in front of you right now.

I also like the whimsically dystopian setting and art style, and the fact that there are female options for your employee avatar. Some of my colleagues and coworkers will appreciate a game that believes they exist :-)

30101382.review:
Very nice programming/micro-optimization asm game. The graphics and animation let you forget you are programming and they nicely visualize what actually happens in your program. And seems that non-coders can enjoy it too.

The instruction set you have in game’s programming language are very assembly-like, and the ‘employee’ you program with the office are a nice model of a working CPU – with floor representing general purpose registers (or memory cells), the employee themselves the accumulator, and the inbox/outbox the memory (accessed as a queue).

The interface may be (as indicated by many other reviews) a little bit cumbersome at later stages, the puzzles are totally not like a typical modern programming challenge, but it is enjoyable, let’s you learn/revisit some math, and understand some things about the computer’s machinery.

It won’t teach you programming. It won’t teach you good programming practises. It will teach you microoptimizations – eg. it’ll force you to unroll a loop to make your program faster.

Overall it is an enjoyable, math puzzle and low-level programming game.

30071578.review:
This simulates coding in a very basic machine language, starting with LOAD, STO, and JUMP and moving on from there.  If you do software for a living, you'll find it annoying, because you'll keep mentally reaching for constructs that aren't available, such as, in an early example, being able to store a chosen constant instead of the contents of the input buffer.  Basically, either (1) you already routinely code in machine, in which case you'll be bored; (2) you routinely code in any higher-level language, in which case you'll constantly be thinking of a better way to do it; or (3) you don't know how to program at all, in which case I don't know how you'll react.


I would say that programmers should move on, charming though the drawings are.

30039625.review:
Sorti en 2015, Human Resource Machine est un jeu de réflexion qui est toujours intéressant à jouer en 2017. Le principe du jeu est simple. Vous avez une tâche à effectuer, un panel de commandes, et vous aurez pour objectif de combiner ces commandes afin de réaliser la tâche. Le but est d'utiliser le moins de commandes possible pour réaliser cette tâche. Autrement dit, vous devez fabriquer un programme optimisé. Si le principe est très simple, plus vous avancerez, plus les tâches à effectuer seront complexes et demanderont du temps et de la réflexion. Il reste néanmoins toujours quelques astuces afin d'optimiser ses programmes.

Les graphismes sont assez simples mais adaptés. Une légère trame a été intégrée dans le jeu, que vous pourrez découvrir à travers les niveaux de "pause café". Elle reste cependant, elle aussi, simple. Ceci dit, elle reflète plutôt bien notre époque. Vous avez, en tout, 41 tâches différentes à réaliser, une dizaine de niveaux étant facultatifs. Au début, un seul programme est possible mais, plus vous avancez, plus le nombre de possibilités croît. 

En somme, Human Resource Machine est un jeu extrêment enrichissant à jouer, vous allez apprendre beaucoup de choses au fur et à mesure de votre avancement. Il met à rude épreuve votre logique, il vous faudra aimer passer des dizaines de minutes bloqué sur un niveau pour apprécier le jeu. Je dois avouer que je suis allé voir une fois ou deux des solutions sur internet, n'ayant absolument aucune idée de ce que je devais faire (en particulier pour le niveau 40).

30038739.review: This is an excellent game that explains how RAM and CPU register work. The programming style is so similar to assembly that I would even recommend this as a teaching material, and the game has animation to help you understand how the programs are running. Some of the optional challenges are painful to finish, but the rest of them are very well designed. I completed the game and all the challenges in about 10 hours and had a lot of fun playing it.

30031564.review:
[b]Human Resource Machine[/b] est un bon jeu de réflexion. La difficulté est équilibrée, on a à notre disposition autant des challenges simple pour suivre l'histoire principale, autant des challenges plus complexes comme la suite de [i]Fibonnacci[/i]. 

Le jeu permet d'aborder un compromis entre de l'assembleur "simplifié" tout en retirant des outils de l'assembleur, d'où l'intérêt; les néophytes et les initiés s'amuseront autant sur ce jeu. Les challenges de rapidité et de taille du programme sont une bonne idée. L'interface de jeu est appropriée car beaucoup moins austère qu'un programme en assembleur. Seul défaut dans cette interface : les commentaires. Pourquoi ne pas avoir mis une option pour écrire au clavier nos commentaires et pouvoir les lier directement avec les [i]jump[/i] ? Les programmes produits sont très vite illisibles alors, tant qu'a rester dans cette optique minimaliste, proposez au moins cette option.

L'aspect graphique est plutôt sympa, quoique un peu triste. Pour les musiques elles sont sympa 15 min, correspondent a l'ambiance du jeu, mais après elles déconcentrent pour faire les puzzles; elle prend une trop grosse place a mon goût, même si on peut la retirer, une musique plus effacée qui correspond autant à l'ambiance aurait été plus appropriée.

Human Resource Machine est assez court, comptez 4h pour le finir, et même si j'ai recu ce jeu gratuitement, le prix reste assez élevé par rapport au temps de jeu nécessaire pour le finir, quoique restant dans le raisonnable.

Ce jeu, malgré ses quelques défauts, reste très bon : je le recommande

however: there are a LOT of puzzles that require you to compare something, but you don't have "equal", "greater than" "lesser than". Try this: a given number (12), output: all fibonacci numbers except the given number. That's 1,1,2,3,5,8.
