29938539.review:
Puzzle games, in my opinion, require two main ingredients to work: good puzzles (duh…) and distraction-free environment to solve them.

The puzzles themselves here are nice. The game starts really easy; the first 20 or so levels offer no challenge and are put there solely as a gentle tutorial. It picks up the pace in the later part though, achieving that difficult balance, offering a rewarding challenge without being annoyingly difficult. At least, the annoyance doesn’t come from the puzzles themselves—that’s what the user interface is for. Far too much brain power must be spent on dealing with it, as you feel like you are working against it rather than using it to your advantage.

It’s a programming game, so you’d expect a keyboard-driven interface, but no. It is mouse only, you compose your programs by dragging commands with your mouse. It is colour-coded, but it doesn’t do different colours for different loops—forcing you to trace the arrows to know what’s going on. Commands take only a little part of the screen, most being taken by ultimately useless graphics, leaving you with a small window for at most 15 lines of code; when later challenges require up to twenty-five, requiring you to scroll and making arrow following so much more aggravating…
You can’t copy-paste parts of the code, you can only copy all of it and pasting will replace everything. You can’t create breakpoints, so debugging require either good reflex to pause at the right moment, or clicking through literally hundreds of steps, until you get to the part you wanted.
All in all, you get the feeling that you fight the game more than you fight its challenges.

It is also a very short, one-shot game. There are two optional objectives for each mission plus some extra puzzles, but nothing else. There is no global ranking for players (TIS-100 style) and the puzzles themselves don’t really have nearly as many possible solutions for it to be meaningful.

Programming games are few, but they are not that uncommon. Go play something else instead, unless you really need another fix.

29935021.review:
Assembly meets BASIC, with a Logo-esque visualization. 

That might be enough to send some of you screaming off into the night, and that's okay. For my part, having only ever dabbled in QBASIC and C++ years ago, Human Resource Machine was a fun refresher course on programming techniques like the Bubble Sort, while also introducing me to an equivalent of pointers and memory addresses (though these could also be described in terms of variables and arrays).

If you already have programming experience, you might be interested in the optimization challanges - one for speed, one for size. But the toolset is extremely limited - Even something like a FOR() statement has to be broken out into a lot of different commands, and the commenting is kind of atrocious.

If nothing I said above makes any sense to you, then you're in luck, because Human Resource Machine is, in many ways, a visualization of what a computer is and how it works, alongside an introduction to programming. At its core, the game is presented as a series of logic puzzles of increasing complexity. If you like logic puzzles, you will probably enjoy this game and maybe learn something about programming in the process.

29700358.review:
Games about programming are definitely a niche genre. Games about assembly language program are a bit of an extreme niche genre. This one tries to smooth that out with goofy graphics. It sort of works.

To clarify: the game works, the softening of the extremeness is the part that sort of works. By the end of the game you might (as I did) wish you could turn that part off and focus on the puzzle at hand. This is ironic because the graphics did play a small role in attracting me to the game in the first place. It's an easier sell than say, TIS-100, because of them, but after 20 puzzles or so, they feel in the way.

Fortunately, to some extent, you can turn them off, or at least avoid or mitigate them. The easiest method is by adjusting a slider that changes the speed at which code is executed. Ok, it just makes the little dude move faster--at the fastest, his existence is obviated, but you might want to turn off the sound effects.

Unfortunately, that settting doesn't persist from puzzle to puzzle, so once you start doing that, you'll never stop doing it. It's a small niggle, but imagine if every time you loaded up a game you had to adjust the sound settings. Sometimes the smallest conveniences turn out to surprisingly large inconveniences in absentia.

The other place where the friendly interface ultimately gets in the way, is the coding itself. This is a great game for getting budding programmers to realize how tedious and limiting a drag and drop interface is for programming. It's very usable, and has some features that seem nice in the beginning, but much like learning to use keyboard shortcuts in an application makes you resent the inneficiency of using a mouse to do the same actions, you will ultimately find the nature of the interface slows you down, and the way the code is presented starts to feel increasingly...murky. And that's not just because assembly language is inherrently spaghetti code.

For simple programs, like those for about half to three fourths of the puzzles, it's no big deal. The fact that jump commands have arcs and landing pads to help you keep track of where they lead is useful. But if you get into something more complicated, those arcs can be distracting.

The worst feature though, is the commenting. Firstly, because of how delayed it is in being added to your repertoire, but mostly because it's so badly implemented in a misguided attempt to keep everything looking just a little kooky. Comments are done by simulated masking tape, but to write on it, you draw with your mouse. Basically, all your comments will look like crude MSPaint drawings. On the one hand, the ability to go symbolic and use non-standard images to organize things is neat, but the inability to just type a comment, and the added time burden involved because you have to draw your comments, limits their desirability and frankly, discourages using them even when they would be really really useful.

I wanted to use comments, but I refused to use the commenting system provided because I didn't see value in investing the time necessary to learn to write using a mouse. If you have a digitizing tablet, you'll find commenting much less of a nuisance. That said, I know this because I have a digitizing tablet, but it was still too much of a nuisance, too much of a break from the programming, to do. I guess, in a way, it should help me be more empathetic to other programmers that don't bother commenting their code... but only slightly. (Seriously, comment your code IRL if not in this game. Everyone who reads it later will be glad you did.)

Fortunately, it's possible to code in an external text editor and import the code to the game... but there's something a little off about that to me. I'd have preferred the option to switch between text input and mouse input within the game itself. While I dig programming games, especially assembly programming games, I'm not too keen on the idea of games that are best played by using a completely different (and not included) program to do most of the uh... gameplay.

I admit, "gameplay" is a word whose meaning is strained by this genre, but I'm holding to it.

The other criticism I have is that the progression is surprisingly uneven. I realize that with this sort of thing, it's quite difficult to predict what order will be best to present the puzzles in, because people have different backgrounds and different ways of looking at things--what is immediately obvious to one person might be opaque for quite some time to another, and they might well switch places with only a minor tweak to what the puzzle is asking for. But, I found the leaps in difficulty to be dizzying at times--especially at the end where I blew through five or six puzzles in a row (mostly fully optimized on the first try) only to smash into how to implement a bubble sort (or selection sort) using the limited instruction set. The difficulty is in the sudden increase in the minimum amount of bookkeeping required. 

Recommended for casual programmers, programmers curious about assembly languages (this is simpler than diving into MIPS) and programmers that would love to take a break from fuzzy ambiguous demands and just sit down and code for a well and clearly stated problem. For the non-programmers reading this: yes, that is recreational and relaxing--by comparison.

29650673.review:
First, I generally like programming games. And in the genre, this one brings a unique perspective that might seem positive at first glance. The simple graphics and the approach to animating the algorithm in progress certainly would seem to allow for the game to be a good introduction to programming for younger players. The programming puzzles themselves start fairly basic, which again seems like a good teaching mechanic.

But that perspective is completely undermined by the story, which revolves around a bored, and boring, lifetime employee of an unforgiving corporation. The work undertaken by this employee is meaningless, futile, and despite the efforts of the game designers to add Office Space-style dark humor, horribly depressing. The clear message to younger players is that this is the corporate life facing them if they take up programming. There is a hint of a side plot in cut scenes, but it never adds up to anything.

For players who already know programming, the puzzles become hard enough at some point to become interesting, but they don't have any cognitive connection to the earlier puzzles - the solutions don't build on each other. So it feels like a hard cliff dividing those that know programming from those that don't. In addition, the harder puzzles become very annoying to solve because of the interface, which doesn't allow for typed input even for things like labels. Copying and pasting into an actual text editor, then copying and pasting back, is possible, but extremely annoying.

In summary, the game falls short due to some fundamental design decisions. It's unfortunate because the game has some promise. But it would take a reworked main storyline, redesigned UI, and puzzle rebalancing pass for it to reach its full potential.

29371250.review:
I am torn whether to recommend this game or not. I encourage you to look at some gameplay videos first. And I recommend buying it only in deep sale. The reason I am torn is because it's a nice concept and video games are a great way to introduce people to programming. But the implementation isn't up to par.  As a software engineer who loves coding, I find this game utterly annoying. Programming in the real world is much easier for the same level of complexity.  

Basically, this game gives you items in your inbox (the input set) and each level gives you instruction on what to do with those items. And once you're done what you're asked to do, you have to put the results (output) in the outbox. Sounds like a fun idea and the game is fun, at least initially. But as you progress to higher levels, the flaws in the game starts to overshadow the fun part of the game and a fun programming puzzle game turns into a frustrating and tedious chore. 

One of the most glaring problems of this game is not letting us set breakpoints, which would have made life so much easier! When you're writing a lengthy program in the real world, and you think there is a problem (bug) in your program at a certain point, you can set a breakpoint there and the program will stop when it reaches that particular point. So now you can continue investigating where the problem is. But in this game you can't do that. So if you're trying to find out any problems in your program, you have to click on the "next step" button till you get to the step where the problem happens. This was a minor annoyance in the beginning but as the program becomes longer it becomes a big headache. 

The second most annoying flaw of the game is when you stop your program, it scrambles the input set. So now if you made any progress in figuring out where the problem lies, you have to throw it out the door and start anew because in this new set you will face problems at a different point. When you program, you can debug using the same inputs till you figure out the problem but here you can't. Again, initially not a problem but as the level of complexity of the programs increase, it becomes unbearable. 

These are just two of the many problems. The game doesn't even let you use conditional statements, another thing that makes life of a programmer a lot easier. 

If you don't have experience programming, then rest assured real life programming is much easier than playing this game. The tools available to you as a programmer makes your life much easier and those aren't available in this game. There are many levels which are really fun so it is worth getting it on sale.

29317491.review:
I'm a big fan of these programming style games, particular Spacechem. As these games are currently both £6.99 I will be drawing a lot of comparisons between the two.

HRM isn't a BAD game. I certainly enjoyed it for most of the time I played it. It's very open with the coding aspect, where as games like Spacechem and Infinifactory disguise their programming so users don't realise they're doing it, HRM feels more like an educational game.

The UI is the main problem with the game. There is no form of copy and paste, the insertable comments are obnoxiously large and you can only see a small portion of the more complicated programs meaning doing the optimization challenged can be very frustrating. A minor note is the game forgets whether you muted it or not so you have to remute it every time you start it up. You can also only mute it from within one of the levels.

The game is also very bare. 41 levels, each with two optimisation challenges but if you have some experience with these kinds of games you'll complete both challenges with your first solution on 80% of the levels. That's it. There's no sandbox, no bonus missions, no other stages, no Steam Workshop. That's your lot. I thought the game might expand, perhaps adding additional workers or additional rooms but it doesn't.

Spacechem has 53 story missions, many of which consist of multiple "rooms", 3 bonus missions and an additional 255 Research Net missions.

I can't recommend HRM for either experienced programmers or newcomers to this excellent genre. It feels more like a free flash game than a title worth £6.99.

Quite fun! If you have any sort of background in programming, this game should be pretty interesting to you. If not, it's a great way to learn the basics (of the basics). Starts off easy, but some of the later levels are quite difficult, and the Optimization Challenges really up the difficulty sometimes. Also has a stunning soundtrack and humor sprinkled throughout (just World of Goo and Little Inferno which were made by at least part of this dev team).

There are several negative reviews in here talking about how some aspects of the game (particularly commenting and evaluation speed) are laborious or not user-friendly, but I feel like they're kinda missing the point. This game is not meant to be a full-fledged, highly-optimized IDE; it's a silly game with a silly aesthetic and those aforementioned "problems" are part of that aesthetic. The setting and dialogue of this game is clearly set in the past (however long ago, I don't know; I don't really know the history of programming very well) as indicated by the old-fashioned character outfits and mail tubes and the basic numerical operations and background story of machines taking over. You don't play this game to write professional software or learn a new programming language or experience a state-of-the-art rendition of the latest programmatical advances, you do it for the fun of solving the game's challenges. Part of those challenges is working within the constraints of the game and its stricter Optimization Challenges.

By all means, take all the reviews into consideration, but remember this is a game first and a programming environment second.

29001276.review:
This is an awesome game! Yet so simple.

If you're a programmer - by day or night, this game is for you. If you're not, after playing this game you will be - or at least have the skills to become one.

This game is about writing lists of instructions to get your cute little office worker to achieve certain tasks. Plenty of amusing, desaturated graphics and cutscenes, and an upbeat soundtrack keep things light and funny while you decide how to get your employee to achieve the tasks set before him.

This game starts out super easy and then builds to being a challenge even for the seasoned, persistent, puzzle solver. It also has several fun achievements to go back for after you complete the basic levels (or if you need a break from the straight forward puzzle solving).

Of course, the flip side to that is *this game is a long series of puzzles.* If you don't like solving puzzle after puzzle, this game is not for you. There are breaks to keep things interesting and avoid monotony, but it still boils down to just a lot of puzzle solving.

However, if you're on the fence, give it a shot. There's no long intro or steep learning curve so worst case scenario is you play it for an hour and you find out you don't like it and return it. Best case scenario is you have a BLAST and maybe develop skills you didn't even know you could develop.


P.S. If you're looking to get into programming, software development, etc., buy this game now! It will help you develop (or test) the skills you'll need in that field while having some fun.

I think this game should be in every elementary school computer lab - it's that good at developing programming skills without being boring.

I am hesitant to leave a negative review, but I feel like I should because of the overwhelming positivity the game has in its reviews. Props to the developers for taking low-level programming concepts and turning it into an interactive gaming experience. This game has immense potential, but ended up leaving me disappointed by the end. 

Past about level 20, the game became dull. I love the animation style and game concept, but the puzzles just became cumbersome to optimize instead of difficult. The commenting feature is pretty unusable, as you can't type comments, only draw them with the mouse, and more complex problems were annoying to step through or run multiple times. The pain of trying to optimize with poor comments and a drag-and-drop interface made the game lackluster for me. That style of command interface and comments would work best with less intensive puzzles and weighed it down. 

Overall, great concept, atmosphere, and design to a point. However, in the latter half of the game, the design doesn't work as well. This game is still adorable and worth your time, but I want to be clear that it does have its drawbacks.

28527136.review:
tl;dr: the reason only 3% of players have the "Green Optimization Award" achievement isn't because the game is hard, but because the game becomes unplayable in the end.

This is a good programming puzzle game that is badly let down by some trivial, but intensely irritating, flaws. I actually don't want to leave a negative review, but I can't ignore its glaring problems. Since the positive reviews outnumber the negative ones, I'm leaving this review to add some constructive criticism.

Programmers will breeze through the puzzles in no time, about a single-digit number of hours to complete. The game only gets interesting when you try the optional optimization challenges (get your program under a certain size or speed). Programmers need to do these optional challenges otherwise there is no point in even playing this game. They are interesting challenges, but they're also where things go bad: the bad UI makes things unplayable. Here's why:

1) You can add comments to you code, as well as labelling memory locations...but it's done in the most annoying way possible. You don't type in your comments with the keyboard, instead you "write" with the mouse. Oh, and the field you get to draw/write into is very small, and the pen you draw/write with is very thick, so you can barely write anything. A comment such as "P is prime" hardly fits. Really infuriating. I've seen some awful programming environments, but this is the first one I've seen that actively discourages you from commenting your code.

2) The maximum program run speed is far too slow for some of the more advanced optimization challenges. One of the puzzles will take 3:30 to run at max speed (although you can get it down to about 2:20 when you optimize it). That's too long, and will become an unnecessary test of your patience.

This isn't a petty complaint. Let's put that 3:30 into perspective. 3:30 means you can only run your solution 17 times an hour. That's 3:30 of waiting, maybe about 20 seconds to apply a fix, then another 3:30 to see if it worked. Rinse, repeat, get frustrated. That means you can only try about 15 things (trivial stuff like small fixes) an hour, so that particular puzzle becomes dragged out to a ludicrously painful extent. You spend a lot of time just waiting for the puzzle to run, and hardly any time working on your solution. Imagine if your favourite IDE did that. You get the picture.

As an aside, that particular puzzle also trolls you by supplying the single-item list as the final input (after the 10 item list that accounts for most of the 3:30 runtime), so if you have a bug that happens with the list-of-only-one-item (an edge case, that's why they test for it) then you're going to have to wait 3:30 for that bug to appear, then additional multiples of 3:30 to test each of your fixes.

3) Dragging and dropping program instructions is needlessly laborious. The maximum HRM program length is 255 lines (although I think the longest HRM program I wrote is about 70 lines). Let's just say, without spoiling anything, you **might** get near the 255 line limit while trying to solve some of the optimization challenges. That's a lot of dragging and dropping! If you double click an instruction the game appends it at the bottom, which isn't helpful as most of the time you are likely to be working on an inner loop. Instead of adding it to the bottom, double clicking should have inserted the instruction after the last one you added. That would have been a big improvement.

These complaints may sounds trivial, but they aren't. The big optimized programs have lots of jumps, etc and it quickly turns into a mess of spaghetti code (that's ok, it's just what happens with asm code). You can only see about 16 lines of code at a time, so it becomes very easy to lose track of things. You could add some labels, but the labels are painful to add! You're bound to make mistakes as a result of the UI, and then the UI punishes you for those mistakes by making you to wait 3:30. Now you see how the game itself becomes the biggest problem. These problems only start to make themselves apparent when doing the optimization challenges. At that point you have to wonder why you're even bothering with HRM. You can find loads of programming challenges/golf/puzzles out there, just do one of those instead in your favourite development environment where you can add comments with your keyboard, don't have to wait 3:30 for a trivial program to run, and you can see more than 16 lines of code at a time. Go pick something off Project Euler instead, and challenge yourself mentally instead of challenging your patience or your ability to draw text with the mouse.

A saving grace is that HRM supports copying and pasting programs. It's often less frustrating to copy your code into Notepad, work there, and copy it back into HRM. Shame the comments/labels don't go across in a way that's readable, but that's because they're mouse strokes not text.

28431120.review:
Wow, this game is purely about the worst aspects of programming. Seriously.

I don't even mean it as a negative against the game - that's what the game set out to do, it's about the programming *itself*.

It does not present any of the possibilities of programming, where you could actually do and find cool stuff. Instead, it gives you a very, very limiting set of rules where you have to go several miles around the problem to solve it, instead of tackling things directly.

Some people like the "challenging" aspect of programming. If you're one of those, give this a shot! (This generalizes easily - if you're someone who likes the challenge for its own sake, and not using the challenge to get somewhere "new") 
I really don't find it too enjoyable.

I'll give it a recommendation, though, since the problem is not on the game itself. The game conveys the message (the specific type of programming, not talking about the story) fairly accurately, and that's good enough, for me!

28274554.review:
The game represents programming as it was in the very beginning – when a kilobyte of memory costed thousands of dollars, and an hour of machine running time cost more than a programmer's paycheck for a month (while computing speed of a computer the size of a building was several [i]orders of magnitude[/i] slower than any modern "weak" laptop), they went to ridiculous lengths to optimise away [i]any[/i] kind of inefficiency they could. And there are actually two criteria to work on, depending on what you need more (that is, what your hardware limits you to).

This game gives you a bunch of mostly trivial tasks (starting from "pass input to output" and up to "calculate prime factors for each given number") and asks you to "instruct" yourself in how to solve them (which is basically equivalent to writing a program in a very limited version of Assembly – about a dozen most primitive operations). Initially you only have "input" and "output" operations, but you'll get a new operation whenever it's needed for solving the task at hand. After you reach the first "milestone", you'll be introduced to the optimization challenges – "preferred" length and average run time values for your programs (personally, I found that moving the last part of a loop body before its beginning is a surprisingly effective technique). You'll also get "optional" branches with more interesting (but also trickier) problems to solve; though the main branch also gets quite tricky later on (I found it quite funny, that on the last problem, whenever I tried optimising for time, I somehow ended up also reducing program size, on every step).

In short, it's a neat game with several hours worth of fun brain exercise, that also makes you struggle with doing simple things enough to appreciate the fact that no one actually [i]has to[/i] (and definitely shouldn't) program this way for at least half a century.

Curti esse jogo assim que bati o olho. É um jogo que, com uma fórmula muito simples, transforma o jogador num “programador”, resolvendo problemas (alguns simples, outros nem tanto) com uma série de instruções simples, que lembra uma linguagem assembly BEM simplificada. Novas ações (ou comandos) vão sendo adicionados à medida em que o jogador progride, assim como os problemas a serem solucionados vão aumentando em complexidade. Os traços do jogo são familiares a quem jogou “World of Goo” ou “Little Inferno”, pois esse game foi feito por desenvolvedores desses jogos. Assim como “World of Goo”, esse jogo também tem uma leve crítica social embutida paulatinamente como historinha de background. Joguinho bem competente.

NOTA: 9/10

26678036.review:
[h1] 9.9999/10 [/h1] 

Прежде чем начать, скажу, что пройдя все игры от Tomorrow Corporation (некоторые в пиратке, потом купив) я стал фанатом этого разработчика до мозга костей. Ни одна игра не разочаровала, и эта не исключение.

[h1] Начнем [/h1]

Мы играем за офисного рабочего, поступившего в кру-у-у-упную компанию и продвигающегося по карьерной лестнице целых 42(!) года. Наша задача - писать программы, по которым действует рабочий, проходить уровни и продвигаться по этажам. Программы эти составляются из очень небольшого списка команд, из которого напрочь убраны большинство самых удобных и полезных, чем игра и отличается от настоящего языка программирования.

[h1] Картинка и саундтрек [/h1]

Игра выполнена в высшем качесте. Это заметно с первых секунд - продумана каждая мелочь, каждый вздох, картинка нигде даже не думает резать глаза и постоянно доставляет удовольствие. Тоже самое скажу и про звуковое сопровождение - каждый звук идеально дополняет картину происходящего, а саундрек хочется переслушивать и переслушивать.

[h1] Игровой процесс [/h1]

А теперь про само программирование. В кажом уровне тебе дается набор чисел или букв, которые тебе надо обработать так, как этого требует уровень, и вывести на конвеерную ленту. Самая большая трудность, и, одноременно, фишка Human Resource Machine - это отсутствие нормальных команд. Ты не сможешь просто так взять, и умножить какое-либо число, допустим, на 4.  Но ты можешь прибавлять одно данное вначале число к другому, создать цикл, делающий это бесконечно раз, сделать условия выхода из цикла, поместить множество ничего не значащих прыжков из одной части кода в другую, чтобы, наконец, умножить какое-либо число на 4. Игра никак не учит программированию, но игрок, который прошел все уровни, обретает дзен и равновесие с миром, ведь он смог, мать вашу, распутать комок из бесконечных прыжков и команд и выполнить условие уровней.

[h1] Сюжет [/h1]

Сюжет подается на блюдечках в форме небольших забавных (или нет) видеороликов, открыть которые ты сможешь после прохождения нескольких уровней. Этот самый сюжет довольно-таки интересный, а качество выполнения кат-сцен позволяет погрузиться в него с головой. Концовка, которую игрок будет воспринимать как награду за пипец-какие-тяжелые-уровни в конце, очень хорошая и выполняет роль победного приза, пусть и небольшого. В каждом уровне также присутствует небольшой диалог с твоим боссом, а он, кроме того что хорошо шутит, дает еще и ценные подсказки.

[h1] Сложность [/h1]

Игра, которая кажется очень простой сначала, после заставляет мозг вытечь из каждой дырочки в голове и не только. А если вам этого будет мало, то вы можете пройти дополнительные головоломки, которые даже ваш босс иногда не может решить. А если вы вообще отбитый на всю голову мазохист, то обязательны к ознакомлению "Испытания Оптимизации", доступные для кажого уровня.

[h1] Итог [/h1]

Наиграв много часов на другом аккаунте я решил купить эту игру и на этом, потому что она определенно стоит своих денег. Оригинальность в исполнении, интересные задачи и продуманность мелочей заставляют молиться разработчику за новые игры. 

P.S. Мой мозг вытек.

Dieses Spiel gibt dem nicht-Programmierer einen Einblick darin, wie kompliziert und fehleranfällig der Programmcode für einfachste Lösungsstrategien ausfallen kann!
Man muss seinem kleinen Büromännchen eine Befehlskette zusammnebauen, damit dieses die In- & Outbox richtig verwaltet. Das geht natürlich beim kleinsten Fehler schief.
Zwar motiviert diese Fehlersuche einen fast permanent dazu, endlich die Lösung zu finden. ABER...

...das bedeutet auch permanenten Stress und viel Gehirnschmalz. Ich spiele gerne Puzzle- und Rätselspiele, nur dieses hier lässt mich dann doch nach wenigen Minuten aufgeben, bis erst am nächsten Tag der Kampfeswille wieder groß genug ist.
Leider nimmt das Spiel einen sehr wenig an die Hand bzw. fehlen einem die gut geübten Grundlagen und eventuelle Tipps, um sich routiniert eine Lösung schaffen zu können. Mir ging es so, dass ich jedesmal wieder sehr angestrengt nachdenken musste, ich konnte kaum auf hilfreiche Grundmuster zurückgreifen.
Zusätzlich muss man eine gute Vorstellungskraft haben, auf welche Weise sich die Reihenfolge der teilweise etlichen Programmzeilen auf das Agieren des Büroangestellten auswirken.

Wem es anders geht, also wer sich besser in diese Materie einfindet oder sogar Programmier(grund)kenntnisse hat, der wird hier seine wahre Freude haben.

Ich gebe dem Spiel "trotzdem" eine positive Bewertung, weil ich Darstellung und Idee wirklich gelungen finde :-)
Dass es mich persönlich etwas überfordert, soll nicht das Problem dieses Spiels sein ^^

26139429.review:
I like this puzzle game.
I find it helps me keep my (day job) high level coding and logic trim and efficient. The language presented is quite brutal and the goals are very challenging.  This is a good exercise and puzzle program for dealing with low level assembly style language.  As a benefit, several of the techniques can be applied to higher level languages IRL.

I agree with other reviewers that the game does not offer much hand holding, leaving you to leverage external learning resources or previous experience.  No sample code is provided in the game, however you do start with a very limited instruction set which is added to as you move along, so in that regard it does provide a learning path.  While it does introduce you to the verbs, it does little to suggest grammar or logic structure, but maybe that is part of the exploration aspect of the game.  

At the time of this review, 2 hours into playing, I am starting on level 20 and I have completed the all the side challenges available to me. There is much more to the game and mechanics than I have been exposed to. every level up to this point has introduced new challenges and concepts on structure and most every other level introduces a new verb.

The polish on this game is great, the mechanics work excellent.  The interface is quick and easy to work with.

The developers should be proud of this software.

One thought for those playing this game is to consider what the game's coding would look like now that you have been introduced to assembly; how the game draws itself on the screen, registers input, etc... it's a good mind fuck,
Thank goodness for C.

25981628.review:
I have finished the main part of this game a few days ago, and it was great, so i thought id be nice to put up a recommendation.
First of all, before you look at the store page and disgustedly turn away because theres programming involved, dont worry about that. You need no prior programming knowledge to understand and play this game, nor do you need any of it to have fun with it.
However, there are two "courses" in the game, plus a bonus challenge:
-The regular, linear puzzle path that starts at a difficulty of "add these numbers together and send the result. You did it!"
-The more advanced puzzle path that actually needs a lot of thinking and planning to grasp and finish. There are some really hard puzzles here, even if you did some programming in your free time.
-There are also some optimization challenges, However, be aware: those are *REALLY DIFFICULT*. I was only able to optimize the first third of the game, and after that, i found myself blankly staring at my screen for 10 minutes, wondering how i ended up with 20 commands instead of 5.

So basically there are three types of people that would enjoy this game, based on the two paths and the bonus:
1. People that enjoy logic puzzles and doing cool things with numbers. AKA people that would enjoy any other puzzle game just as much.
2. People that not only like solving logic puzzles but also are interested in programming in general; The way of thinking that would usually help you solve a coding problem will also help you here. Also do try this path if youre type 1; The game might convince you to go on.
3. Mad insane people that want to get the best results humanly possible and strive for maximum efficiency. This game will consume your life and stay in your head until you beat the requirement for optimization. This is a last warning. It is not too late to turn back.

That being said, the logic curve is really gentle; the first third of the game operates on knowledge that a preschooler would have. So yeah, dont worry. Even the final puzzle of the main path was not that hard to conquer. With enough time and the will to not give up, you will be able to solve the whole thing easily. This is not a crazy Zachtronics game where halfway through the game your brain explodes in a billion shreds and you regret everything. It's actually quite a relaxing experience. And for 10€, it would be silly not to try and give it a go.

Positive things:
The graphics and soundtrack are lovingly crafted, the game eases you into the more difficult puzzles, and unless youre going for 100% efficiency, just solving the whole thing wont be too much of a hassle. Although this might not be a casual game, it does not involve any crazy mental hoola-hoops just to have fun with it, unlike something akin to TIS-100. TIS-100 is the kind of game that will inevitable make you feel like youre the most stupid human on planet earth. (However, if you are smart enough, which im not, TIS-100 will give you just what you need)
This game will make you feel smart while also being an actual fun game you will want to sink your free time into.

Negative things:
The programming language youre given is the most low-level thing ever. You are given very basic mathematical operations throughout the whole game. This might work for what the game asks of you, but i feel like if the thing progressed more and gave you more high-level programming stuff to work with, you would be able to ask much more cool and interesting things; as a result of the kind of programming you use, even the hardest challenges seem bland. Even the hardest thing in the enire game - finding prime factors - still is a basic task. The only hard part is that youre only given subtraction, addition, and memory management, so in the end it feels like carving a statue out of stone with your bare hands. Which just isnt fun. Other games like spacechem make difficult tasks feel exciting and cool, this one not so much.
Also the UI is a bit slow sometimes.

In the end, even if it doesnt look like it, the games really cool! I definetly recommend it if you have any interest in puzzle games whatsoever. Go play it! The positives outweigh the nitpicks i have by a lot, and the 12 hours i spent with it were a lot of fun. Im also definetly going back to optimize my messy code. I might not come back alive.

25833065.review:
Human Resource Machine is a game where you use a very basic assembly-like instruction set to write simple programs.

Each program has a series of inputs, an expected series of outputs, and a limited number of availalbe memory locations where you can store values.  In the begining, you work with solely numerical inputs but later on you have to deal with character manipulation as well.

My opinion of this game is a little biased as I program professionally.  I feel like some of the harder puzzles probably take a pretty big leap in difficulty that may prove frustrating for player who are not familiar with certain assembly-level ways of thinking.

That being said, I really enjoyed the puzzles, and even though the game isn't terribly long, its a really interesting and unique experience, and I found it worth what I payed just for that.  The challenge objectives can also add some length on to the game with some of the challenges being trickier than even the hardest puzzles normally.

Small gripes I had with the game is that the difficulty curve feels all over the place. Sometimes programs are feel really tricky or really trivial compared to those around it and even some of the alternate track levels seemed much easier than those around them.  Also, there is kind of a back story with cutscenes that happen occasionally, but they feel really pointless and kind of take you out of the experience of the game.

Ultimately, I recommend this game to people with programming experience looking for some fun little puzzles that require you to take a step back and work within limitations or people who have an interest in programming or learning programming and want some practice in solving those types of problems.

25811340.review:
Human resources machine is odd, so odd in fact that I’m not even sure that I can call it a game. This game attempts to target two very different audiences by having the main simple track for puzzle enthusiast and the complex track for experienced programmers. As such I will be splitting my review in two so you can better decide if this game is for you.

[b]To the puzzle enthusiast:[/b]
This is a logic and mathematic puzzle game that you not only have to solve yourself but you have to write a program to solve for you. If you’ve never programmed before the game walks you through everything you need to know in order to play. It gives good instructions and hints to help you get along. I think it strikes a good balance between teaching the player different concepts without handing the answer to the player. The puzzles can compound on each other as the knowledge of the answer from the previous puzzle might be vital to discovering the answer to subsequent ones. If you get to the end of this game then you will have learned some basics of simple programming. 
If you enjoy cross words, logic, and/or mathematical puzzle games you might find this game enjoyable.

[b]To the programmers:[/b]
This game adds an artistic overlay of a man executing a series of simple, low level, or assembly like commands. (i.e. add, jump on zero, etc). Every level you are presented with the challenged to create a specified output with a given input and your job is to create a function to achieve those requirements. I played this game on a PC but I think it would be easier on an iPad or tablet. Everything is controlled by the mouse and you even have to drawl your notes to keep track of things. (no option to type your notes in.) I’ve solved most of these puzzles in school assignments when working with assembly.
The only challenge they have for programmers is that they have two challenges for the advanced levels. Create the function using the fewest number of commands and create the function using the fewest number of steps. You can’t always do it both was at once. I never have trouble creating the functions to complete the given task.
If you have always wanted to see a compiler where a little man runs around executing your commands than this is literally the game you’ve been waiting for. If that doesn’t appeal to you there is really no reason to get this game.

[b]5/10[/b] Would I recommend this game? That’s not a straight forward answer. I would recommend this game to someone who likes puzzles and is interested in learning what low level programming might be like. I would not recommend this to anyone else. Because the people I would recommend this game to is such a small niche I’m giving the review a thumbs down.

25586384.review:
There are a handful of programming games out there, and this is by far the most fun I've played so far. In the game, you assemble commands for a minimalistic CPU with a deliberately limited instruction set to accomplish various given tasks, such as finding the smallest number, counting and comparing null terminated strings, or finding prime factors. The presentation of Human Resource Machine is amazing. The workings of the CPU are visualized by means of a tiny office worker, your avatar, who executes your commands and walks around, picks up boxes and changes numbers. It has a cute graphic style and there is some mild storytelling with sweet and short cutscenes and lots of good humor.

I recommend this game to anyone who is even remotely interested in programming. If you are like me and just have to complete all the extra achievements and bonus levels, I found them to be challenging, but never unfair. Not once did I get the too familiar feeling of an artificially inflated difficulty to make the final achievement needlessly hard to get. So I finished all 16 achievements within two days of playing the game. I wish they would add something beyond the campaign, such as a daily or weekly challenge (which I realize would be a lot of work) or at least a sandbox mode, but the game deserves a full recommendation the way it is.

25559537.review: Thoroughly enjoyable! Really liked the level of difficulty -- quick and fun to build out an initial implementation, and an interesting challenge to hit all of the optimization thesholds; nothing was too tedious to not be a good time. After hours of playing, I had to find the music volume setting in a config file, in order to disable the single music track and listen to my own music -- aside from that, I think the game was very polished for what it is. I especially appreciated all of the verification tests that were run in the background, to provide useful test cases for debugging. I'd recommend this for parents who want to expose kids to programming.

Я в IT хочу войти. Отличная игра для тех кто хочет научиться программировать. Мы мелкий сотрудник огромной компании, и нам ставят задачи, если мы их выполняем то мы продвигаемся по карьерной лестнице, а если нет  - то нет. 
   Язык напоминает ассемблер. Сначала нам дают простенькие задачи - например взять данные на входе, сложить их и вывести на выходе. Интерфейс в игре простой имеем столбец где входные данные, ячейки памяти куда можно занести число или промежуточный результат, столбец вывода данных, окно кода где мы будем писать код и сам сотрудник который этот код будет исполнять.
   В начале каждого уровня нам ставят задачу, например, взять данные на входе, и вывести лишь те пары данных, сума которых равна нулю(или не равна). Также можно узнать дополнительные задания, на оптимизацию кода. Процесс написания кода состоит из перетаскивания кодовых блоков и составление программы. Есть даже отдельный блок с комментариями. В игре огромное количество элементов - сложение, вычитания, деления, умножение, метки, метки. Отдельно хотелось бы сказать про метки. Их тут целая туча - переход если результат отрицательный, если 0, если не 0 и т.д. 
   Также в игре есть помощник , который расскажет про нужную команду, покажет пример того что вам нужно сделать и даже можешь рассказать какую-то историю.
  
  Так что вперед к программированию. Забавно что обзор я решил написать именно на день программиста  (◕‿◕).

A fun, open-ended puzzle game. This game is far more approachable than [i]TIS-100[/i] for a few reasons: Player programs in [i]Human Resource Machine[/i] advance sequentially and don't have a length limit. Also, the game includes polished music and character animations. Even my non-techy family enjoyed this game.

On the other hand, [i]Human Resource Machine[/i] is rather short, and its interface is very touch-oriented. I'd recommend playing on a tablet unless the developer adds better keyboard shortcuts.

The more difficult puzzles touch on some computer science favorites, including [spoiler]arrays, pointer arithmetic, linked lists, Fibonacci numbers, prime numbers, and sorting[/spoiler]. Zachtronics tends to avoid so explicitly referencing computer science fundamentals in its games.

非常好玩！有一股内核编程的味道：
1.你的存储空间非常有限：手上一个（寄存器），地板上最多20个（内存）。
2.你的指令集很坑爹！你只能使用一系列基本的指令，并且几乎没有［函数］的概念。也就是，你必须抛弃模块化编程[spoiler]，享受一把A bowl of spaghetti编程的快感[/spoiler]。
3.你需要完成一系列优化目标！这也是整个游戏中最具有挑战性的部分。如何减少一两次平均执行指令数？如何用更少的命令达成相同的目标？这都是需要大量思考，并且很难达成的部分。我没有接触过汇编编程，但我想这部分与汇编编程的思想是相通的。

祝大家享受游戏，关关两灯！

25280118.review:
A fun game and an excellent way to introduce people to low-level programming. It even gets the point across that optimising for speed can sometimes make programs bigger, and vice-versa (although it does so in a slightly annoying way, by limiting which instructions you have access to, when it could have made the same point in more realistic ways, like optional loop unrolling).

The UI could use a couple of improvements (like dragging instructions directly to memory "tiles" instead of having to do it in two steps, or having a way to adjust the sound and music volume, etc.), but overall it's decent. Definitely worth the 1€ I paid for it, and easily worth up to 5€ or so. For 10€ (the current list price), I really would expect that extra UI polish.

Makes a great gift for kids who are just starting to learn how to code and for people who [i]think[/i] they'll never learn how to code. Might be wasted on experienced programmers, though, as a) it will feel a bit like work, and b) they'll probably solve most levels on the first try.

25083687.review:
That was a blast! It was quite refreshing to play a less-than-hardcore programming puzzler for once.

You new job is at an old-timey skyscraper. Since computers haven’t been invented yet, the engineers solve problems by running letters and numbers around on tiled floors. Given an inbox full of stuff, your task is to write a small set of instructions that give the bosses exactly what they want, in the precise order they want it.

What the game doesn’t explicitly tell you is that you’re writing some of the simplest useful algorithms in assembly code, such as multiplication, sorting, and alphabetizing, using logic that’s very similar to what you’d use if you were doing it for real. And it’s all presented in a clean, responsive interface and Tomorrow Corporation’s signature creepy cartoon artstyle. It does a wonderful job of presenting the art of writing algorithms as a series of simple, elegant puzzles.

And just like Little Inferno and World of Goo, it has an unexpectedly beautiful, haunting soundtrack.

I give the game an 8.5 / 10. Why the points off? Mainly, it’s due to the limitations of the interface, some of which are seriously disappointing. It’s clear to see that Human Resource Machine was meant to be played on a touchscreen, and it sticks to it to a fault. The only way to comment your code is to write awkward, messy, hand-drawn notes with a paintbrush – you can’t type comments at all.  And the code editor itself, while perfect for 90% of the game and its simplistic puzzles, starts to show some frustrating weaknesses as the game pushes the envelope on complexity near the end: there’s no zooming, no indenting. You can’t bulk select any code, so if you want to duplicate a block, you have to re-create it line by line. If you want to delete a code block, you have to drag every single line away.  Copy/paste is limited to the [i]entire program[/i] at once, which is nearly useless.

Some of the problems with the editor can be alleviated because you can copy and paste code into external text editors, but then there’s another serious problem: you can’t read any of the comments, since they’re encoded as 2-color images. The entire comment system is shamefully awful and deserves an entire point off of a nearly perfect game. Why not allow text input? I mean, most devices with touchscreens also have on-screen keyboards, so what’s the big deal?

A few other nitpicks:

- Steam leaderboards would have been nice.
- A few extra puzzles, perhaps about 10, would have been nice. The game only has about 36 of them.
- A sandbox mode would have also been nice.
	
Programming games tend to have some hardcore difficulty, requiring nearly just as much planning and effort as a legitimate programming project. Finally, with Human Resource Machine, we have one that’s suitable for newcomers. If you’re interested in programming puzzles but thought SpaceChem or TIS-100 got too hard, this may just be the game for you. On the other hand, if you already have a background in programming and are looking for a challenge, try getting 100% completion in this game without a guide, and you probably won't be disappointed in the level of difficulty either.

24988218.review:
Wow.  I have done programming work as part of my profession, I have a bachelor's in CS, I've been programming for over 20 years, and this game is amazing.

Firstly:  If you are new to programming or not even new yet, great!  This game is a great introduction.  Just IGNORE THE OPTIMIZATION MILESTONES.  Focus on finishing all the levels, then you can worry about that.

If, however, you are like me a professional programmer at times, this game's optimization challenges can still provide a great challenge.  I just spent what felt like 2 hours (probably more like 1 to 1-and-a-half) trying to optimize the runtime of Level 20 (multiplication) and half the time my program didn't even work correctly, let alone optimally.

Protip: The program doesn't end until you go to the Inbox while it's empty.  Doing so before a jump, rather than after, can make the difference in optimizing number of steps taken.  Also, it's not literal steps -- it's number of instructions followed, so which floor mat locations you use doesn't matter.  Jumps count as a step but jump targets do not.

24929124.review:
A well made, full fledged tutorial for TIS-100.

Kidding aside, the only con of the game is a big one: Its interface is designed with compatibility with mobile in mind. This works mostly, in the first two thirds of the game. Nearing the end, when length of the codes goes up to 50 lines, a single misclick results in erasing everything since complexity does not allow for good bug finding.

You cant use keyboard for writing codes, or editing them. This really slows things down and makes it prone to misclicks. There is a copy&paste function, but it only copies ALL of the lines and copies into by erasing what was there before, rendering it useless. Especially in some parts which required division, I had to rewrite some of the code I had written 3-4 stages before, and it felt like a chore.

Stage monologues and backstory was well designed, with a hint of critique of automation observed in all industries. Missions were also well designed, although I found optimization targets a bit too tight, especially for the beginners. I completed the game in 6 hours without caring about the optimizations first. My wife is more of a beginner in programming and she is in her 13th playtime hour, still playing the game, getting frustrated sometimes since it is either you found the algorithm, or not. The game does not give you 5 quests and let you solve them with the order you want, it is all linear.

To sum up: Even though I mostly talked about its negatives, I throughly enjoyed it. Like I said, it helped me to solve some puzzles in TIS-100, which is also a positive :) If you enjoy learning about programming, and cant stand the presentation of the other game in the genre, you must give this a try.

24714480.review:
[h1]揭秘为什么编程会上瘾的游戏[/h1]
[u]本评测为非程序员或编程爱好者视角[/u]
以前，我一直很苦恼，在我的印象中编程明明是一个很枯燥无聊的事情，为什么会出现各种编程的爱好者以及为什么会经常出现编程天才十几岁就破解某某大型公司网站的新闻。
现在，我终于明白，原来编程是这么有趣。本游戏就是将编程简单化，形象化而创作的游戏，让普通人领略编程的魅力，在不断简化程序的过程中感受程序之美。
其实，买这个游戏，完全是因为制作组是曾经制作过粘粘世界和小小地狱之火的那个制作组。这个游戏依然延续了他们非常有特色的画风，不过难度绝对是比这两作都要高的。不过，游戏内容有点少了，如果再多加一点关卡，多加一点命令，可能就能引导更多的人走向编程这条道路（笑）。

A stejně jako Little Inferno, hra vypadá, že se bude dobře hrát i na tabletu, přeci jen Little Inferno byla primárně hra pro mobily, ani zde se nic nemění očividně.

24640037.review:
This is a probably well-meaning game that fails to deliver to the audience most interested: the newbie programmer. The game has a charming premise, which is underdeveloped. Although your character is moving upward through a dystopian corporation, this is less fleshed-out than the world map in early Mario games. The sound design is suitable and unintrusive, but nothing to write home about. More importantly, the game design suffers from expert myopia. It's essentially a teaching game (or to use the 90s buzzword, an edutainment game). While it could be a fun way to learn visual programing, in reality the teaching game genre is merely used as a framework, and is entirely neglected. There are no actual hints for a stumped player. The coding language the player uses is artifically hobbled by a lack of the most basic functions fundamental to languages handling maths. The player must execute relatively simple programming tasks with elaborate contortions of unsuitable functions, like determining if numbers are equal without an actual comparison function of any sort. The newbie codemonkey will feel it is cheating to look up answers or even hints, likely unaware that porgrammers pull code from documentation and github all the time.

For experienced coders, this will be a fun puzzling romp with a robot apocalypse skin. For aspiring programmers and those with less than perfect math scores, it will quickly devolve into an exercise in frustration. 

*I have not reviewed it for accessibility. This is a single-mouse-click based game. Keyboard controls are not available. Audio is not required to play. Color is not required for understanding and playing - it is mostly sepia with some arbitrarily red or green items.

24620645.review:
[h1]Description[/h1]
Human Resource Machine is a puzzle/programming game by the devs behind World of Goo and Little Inferno.
It makes you code not with the fancy sophisticated constructs of programming languages, but with a very limited set of instructions the likes of which your processor really understands. It is basically a very cute, very graphical introduction to assembler languages and to programming in general.
The game starts with simplistic problems and an extremely limited set of instructions, but the difficulty ramps up quite a bit until you finally tackle typical programming problems like Fibonnacci and prime numbers, sorting and so on.
Besides all the programming puzzles, the game also tells you a story that I will not dare spoil here, even though it is not, by any means, a story-driven game.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*] Amazingly cute graphics (who woulda thunk assembler code could be so pretty???)
[*] Balanced difficulty curve (aside from optional problems and some optimization goals)
[*] Good amount of content for the price (unless you are a computing genius... or a cheater)
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*] Interface gets frustrating at times
[*] Coding complex programs with so few instructions is hard (and now you know why programming languages were invented in the first place ;) )
[/list]

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
If ever a programming game could be accessible to non-coders, this would be it. At the same time, behind its cute graphics and visual gimmicks, it really is a programming game.
If you're a coder, you should give this one a try, if only to afterwards go back to your favorite language and sigh in contentment for all the syntactic sugar making your coding experience so much more comfortable.
If you've ever wondered how computer actually compute data, this is the game for you.
If you're a big fan of puzzles and brain teasers, this will probably give you a headache in a good way.
If you fit in none of those categories, I would only advise getting this game on sale, as you might go into anaphylactic shock ;)

24447684.review:
This game started out as a fun little assembly programming puzzle but got tedious pretty quickly.

The story and style are exactly what you'd expect from a 2DBOY /  Tomorrow Corporation game (World of Goo, Little Inferno). Kind of cute and whimsical, but with a story utterly disconnected from the gameplay without much of a cohesive plot.

If you've never done any sort of assembly programming this game could serve as a nice introduction to it; a bit of a  challenge while teaching some of the basics.

However, if like me you have done some programming you'll probably find yourself getting annoyed with it pretty quickly. It has:

-No boolean operators (AND, OR, NOT, etc.) which seriously limits the scope of what puzzles can be in the game.

-No "branch on positive result" operator, despite there being negative and zero variants. This doesn't stop you from solving anything, but it forces you into writing some really inelegant solutions in order to work around this pointless omission.

-Comments and labels that need to be drawn letter by letter. You aren't required to use them, but if you do hopefully you have good handwriting using a mouse.

-No ability to set constants; you have to use whatever the game provides you. This means you pretty much have to solve the problems how they expect you to, no creativity allowed.

-A run time that even at the fastest setting will take a few minutes of sitting and waiting for some of the longer puzzles to complete.

All in all I think this game fails pretty hard, as its core audience is people with some interest / experience in programming but it doesn't respect that audience. It wasn't even all that challenging, I found I spent more time fighting the interface to get my solutions to work than I did actually thinking up solutions.

24200934.review:
Not as clever, challenging, or usable as TIS-100, but a fun assembly programming puzzle game nevertheless.

If you're a CS student that hasn't yet taken an assembly course, this is a great intro. The assembly language is very conventional (unlike TIS-100), so many of the skills and strategies you learn will be directly applicable to, say, MIPS or x86.

My chief complaints are about the interface:

1. The inability to type in text for register names and comments is really annoying. The game only supports mouse-based doodles.

2. The drag-and-drop interface for instructions, while useful in the early stages of learning the language, gets unweildy quickly. Jumps start looking like spaghetti, and the lack of sub-program copy-paste makes refactoring extremely painful.

For many of the later optimization challenges, I copied my program into a text editor, edited it there, and pasted it back (really useful feature!). However, this process makes the lack of text-based register names and comments doubly painful since they don't appear in a usable format in the textual representation.

24148271.review:
[b]My 10 bits: Cute little programming game which is fun but could have been much better.[/b]

[u]The Ones:[/u]
0001 Sorta cute
0010 Maybe educational
0011 Optimization is fun
0100 Achievements are easyish
0101 Weird cutscenes

[u]The Zeros:[/u]
1111 Very basic and tabletized, all pointy-draggy
1110 More levels please
1101 Can be tedious at times
1100 Achievements are easyish

Everyone will probably enjoy this game for a little while, if you like solving abstract problems and basic programming you’ll enjoy it more.

It really comes across as targeted for mobile/tablets; like many such games it really has only the basic features and nothing else. As an example, while you can cut and paste entire programs (and have to endure an explanation every time you do it), there’s no feature to cut and paste a section of a program. Another example - you have to ‘draw’ comments with your mouse or touch, you cannot type them in.

As an experienced programmer the optimisation challenges were mostly a little easy for me. On the other hand, the instruction set used in the game is often frustrating by design (e.g. I usually want to jump if positive, not negative! - or - I usually don’t want the bump instructions to replace what’s in my hands).

No story to speak of, but some strange little cutscenes to set the mood. Reminds me of my work.

Overall a short, easyish and moderately fun game. Get it if you like optimization-style puzzles... and let’s face it, who doesn’t.

HRM 是一款組合語言遊戲，不需要把 CODE 一行行打出來，只要把 CODE 拼成一條程式完成任務即可。

遊戲有三十幾關，後面大部份關卡要達成兩個條件
1. Command 數在一定數目以下
2. Step數在一定數目以下
兩個條件不需要同一組程式碼完成

這款比起 TIS-100 簡單很多，主因不是因為圖像化程式
而是在於記憶體的運用
HR 的記憶體，跟寫C/C++ 的 ARRAY 和 POINTER 差不多，每關的記憶體數量給得很大方，沒有不夠的情形
而 TIS-100 的每個 BLOCK 只有 ACC 和 一格暫存，要同時使用較多記憶體的時候，
便要借助相鄰的BLOCK，而BLOCK 與BLOCK 的同步會讓人很傷腦筋

總的來說，HR 是一款輕度程式遊戲，全成就大約需要十多小時
P.S. 裏面的BOSS 講話很賤
9/10

I fully expected to hate this game because it's clearly based on assembley language, and programming in assembley is frankly about as enjoyable as a root canal. Thankfully, HRM makes a number of abstractions and simplifications, mostly to how the "registers" are handled, and as a result the game is shockingly fun. The 15 minutes I expected to give it turned into 3 hours, and I came back for another 4 later in the day. If that's not an endorsement, I don't know what is. 

HRM is basically String Algorithms: The Game. If that means something to you, it was probably all you needed to know to make a decision. If it didn't, ask yourself whether solving seemingly straightforward problems with an incredibly limited toolset while aiming for maximum time and/or step count efficiency sounds enjoyable. The early levels should make up for lack of previous experience, so don't let unfamiliarty with programming stop you if the concept is appealing.

23945714.review:
This is a game to make you think like a programmer.  But not too much.  Using a limited choice of steps, you try to write efficient fast programs for various tasks.  It's starts simply, but ramps up to fiendishly difficult - I had to get help on the final level, and I still don't understand how their script worked to solve it.  And there's an even harder bonus level that I thought I had then discovered I my solution only encompassed half of the requirements. Of the 40 puzzles included, I solved less than half in a suitably efficient script length or performance steps, and it took me 7 hours to do that much.
That being said, when you do figure out how to best run the scripts, it's quite a buzz.  The difficulty is artificially spiked some by removing some very basic abilities that any programmer should have, making the knowledge less transferable than it could have been, And the story surrounding the game is weird at best and fairly minimal (it's by the same guys behind World of Goo and Little Inferno).
Bottom line; if you're not into programming, you'll hate this.  If you are, you'll get frustrated by it, but it should still trigger those same feelings you get when you write particularly good code. It's definitely a niche game.

dopo World of Goo e Little Inferno arriva HRC, identico nello stile grafico tipico della Tomorrow Corporation. verremo assunti come facchini/programmatori in una carriera che durerà ben 41 anni (fortunatamente virtuali) nei quali saremo messi alla prova come ottimizzatori di processi, dal tipico fai la somma dei numeri in entrata e restituisci il risulato in uscita al metti in ordine crescente i numeri in entrata e restituiscili ordinati in uscita sino a cose molto più complicate quali fattoriali, serie di fibonacci e così via.
i comandi non saranno totalmente a nostra scelta ma avremo un pacchetto di voci pre-assegnate attraverso le quali svolgere i vari oneri (inbox, outbox, copy to, copy from, add, jump, ....)
la difficoltà è un crescendo mostruoso, facendoci sentire programmatori provetti per i primi due capitoli, per distruggere i nostri sogni universitari e lavorativi con l'ultimo dove la difficoltà è sovraelevata e senza una guida non ne uscirete facilmente sani di mente. rimane un ottimo titolo che forse non va giocato tutto d'un sorso per non farselo andare di traverso. peccato davvero per l'enorme dislivello delle ultime richieste.

パズル形式で、プログラムの基本をステップバイステップに学べます。

代入 (copyfrom / copyto)
ループ (jump)
条件式 (jump if zero / jump if negative)
計算 (add by / subtract by / add 1 / subtract 1)
ポインタ (copyfrom address / copyto address)
コメント (comment)

プログラムの基礎がある人だと

23796105.review:
If you don't own the game, it's all about assembly code. The gameplay is good, but I'm not quite sure what niche it's meant to fill... Let me explain.

For people with some experience in programming, assembly, or maths, the end game is a bit too easy. Difficult concepts are never fully explored, and the hardest thing you do is basically prime factorisation and bubble-sort; I felt like the pace and difficulty curve up to the end was great, I just wished it was longer, and kept getting harder. For those people, I'd recommend TIS-100 or Spacechem, as both are much harder than this, even by the halfway point. For people without the programming experience, my guess would be that the difficulty curve is a bit too steep. It doesn't actually explain any of the logic concepts involved, and I think it'd be tough without at least a bit of prior programming experience. Moreover, while the coding system is fun, it does end up looking very convoluted, and the bulky comments system doesn't fix this. This works to make it harder for beginners, who don't have the experience at debugging and thinking in the abstract. So for those reasons, I think there are better introductions for beginners online.

Anyway, I enjoyed it, and was able to optimize at least one side of each program while I was working up the ladder, but I'm not going to be going back and optimizing everything.

23728974.review:
Human Resource Machine - это эмулятор ассемблера стилизованный под работника офиса.

Есть входной конвеер по которому двигаются бумаги, есть выходной конвеер. 
Нужно с помощью простых команд, типа "взять бумажку с конвеера", "положить в ячейку на полу", "Взять с пола", "прибавить 1", "вычесть 1", "сложить", "вычесть", "перейти если в руках ноль", "перейти если в руках отрицательное число", "положить бумажку на конвеер" и т.д. получить нужную последовательность.
Притом оценивается количество шагов, которые пробежал работник и количество команд в программе.

Всё начинается с простого перекладывания бумаг с место на место.
Потом добавляются математические действия.
Потом условия и ветвления.
А заканчивается всё появлением указателей и работы с массивами данных.

Всем интересующимся ассемблером и программированием настоятельно рекомендую.

Игра не сложная и проходится на 10-15 часов. На то, чтобы выполнить все достижения нужно будет еще 5-10 часов.

Кроме того, не стоит забывать про сюжет (который есть!) и музыку.

В общем 10/10.

23701285.review:
HRM is a puzzle game. Your job is to convert inputs into outputs using various commands (add, sub, copyto) to complete given obiective, like select smallest numbers or some job on strings ect. So, what do we have. Obiective tells you what to do, and they coniniously grow in difficulity, starting with simply moving Intputs to outputs, to eg.: Fibonacci sequence. With time, you recieve more commands, like jump if zero (if value picked is equal to zero, your code moves to different section). 
Coding itself comes down to picking aviable commands and putting them in order. Then running the "program" makes you avatar execute given commands, untill task is complete as intended, or any slight error ( manager in the top right corner have a big butthurt). In total, there are 42 levels, with coffee breaks, being progress of the story (yup, there is story, short and plain, so I wont mention it).

Overally, game is good. Makes programing looks fun. By this you know that i'm not programmer XD
If you want to try programming, give it a go. And if you get lost, there is a lot of community guides aviable, with easy to copy (Ctrl+C) solutions to levels.

23676663.review:
De los creadores de Little inferno llega Human Resource Machine:

TL DR: Me ha gustado muchísimo, ha valido completamente los 10 dolares.

[h1] ¿Qué es Human Resource Machine? [/h1]
A diferencia que Little inferno en Human Resource Machine [b]NO[/b] quemas cosas (además de tu cabeza), más bien es un juego donde programas las acciones de tu personaje con forme lo que te pide cada nivel; si te pide que sumes el primer valor por el segundo debes de decirle a tu personaje qué hacer con los comandos a tu disposición, paso a paso. Y no existen las trampas; cada vez que haces un cambio en el código las variables cambian.

[h1] Recomendaría este juego a la gente que: [/h1]
[list]
    [*]Le gusta la programación.
    [*]Es programadora.
    [*]Tiene tiempo de sobra.
    [*]Está estudiando programación (como yo).
    [*]O a la gente que quiere aprender del tema pero mirar una pantalla con códigos le confunde demasiado:
[/list]

Una de las cosas que me encantó de este juego es la manera de "simplificar" la programación para gente que no tiene ni idea de qué hacer con un pc, es muy fácil de entender y fácil de programar porque:
[list]
    [*]Cada tipo de comando tiene un color predeterminado.
    [*]Programar se limita a "Haz click y arrastra a el código".
    [*]No tienes que memorizar que hace cada cosa; puedes arrastrar el código al "+" que hay debajo de los códigos y te dice exactamente qué es lo que hace.
[/list]

Tengo que decir que llevo estudiando programación desde hace 2 años y este juego me ha destrozado completamente; mis conocimientos han bastado para completar hasta el nivel 20 y después me he quemado la cabeza pensando como mierdas hacer lo que me piden, después de mucho pensar consigo una solución y el tipo me dice "esta solución sólo funciona con estos valores!, te daré otros para que veas!"... y tenía razón.

[h1] Conclusión: [/h1]
Nunca había probado un juego parecido a este, pero que este sea "mi primera vez" con este género es como desvirgarse con un negrote musculoso con 30 cm's de orgullo; simple y llanamente lo mejor que te puede pasar, seas lo que seas.

23630294.review:
A nifty little 'engineer-a-solution' puzzler, along the likes of Spacechem, Infinifactory, etc., where the goal is to use simple tools to transform inputs A into outputs B.  In this case, the tools are analogous to basic assembly language computing code.  It also has the unique, morose-dystopian charm of the Tomorrow Company's usual works (World of Goo, Little Inferno), so there's that too.

Took me about 4 hours to solve every stage (I'm a little amazed), though I probably only got about 40% of the optimization scores in the process.  No formal background in programming/CS, but a lot of toying around with things as hobbies, and the game's also great at teaching the methods - it's just up to you to work your brain around how to put it all together for the pretty massive challenges of the last couple stages.

23629102.review:
Human Resource Machine is a shit teacher. It's a game about how you find a solution, not the solution itself, and the game's designers have no idea how to teach this.

I like to try and dabble in the puzzle genre on occasion, and reviews that claimed this game teaches programming fundamentals caught my attention. HRM does manage to remind me of an intro to C++ course I took a while ago, only there's no help or professor to give you a hand. Some of the attempts to aid the player are so bad they're laughable. 

For example, the first puzzle where I needed help only the required output was provided. No first steps, no suggested pieces, not even an idiot-level "do this" hint. Just an image of what the output to the puzzle would be, which would be obvious to anyone who can read instructions. I did find a solution in an online walkthrough, but I cannot explain why the solution in the walkthrough worked where my similiar ideas completely failed.

I tend to find puzzle games more work then fun, so the positive reviews are probably from people who actually enjoy puzzle game logic. Everyone else should be wary of this BS.

23619968.review:
Довольно необычный продукт от разработчиков игр, в которых люди проводили уйму времени ещё до стима. Ну что ж, так даже интереснее! Я с интересом смотрел на игру с момента релиза, т.к. давно ждал чего-нибудь подобного в удобном виде и приятном графическом стиле. И вот он, приятный сюрприз.

Игра знакомит нас с основами программирования: ввод/вывод, циклы, типы данных, сортировка, переменные и многое другое. Вообще, стоит рассматривать чем-то промежуточным между развлечением с головоломками и языком программирования в упрощенном виде. Конечно, если вы хотите научиться программировать, лучше заниматься определенным, существующим языком сразу. Но для тех, кто не уверен его это стихия или нет - вполне подойдет.

Туториала в игре, как писали другие обзорщики, действительно нет, но я не считаю это чем-то неправильным. Когда вы приходите на новую работу (как в игре) всем на вас пофиг (как в игре) и ваш прогресс зависит только от вашего желания и усидчивости (как в игре). Тут даже ачивки есть за базовые ошибки (переполнение, обращение к несуществующему объекту), неужели разработчики их добавили просто так? Ведь на работе вы тоже поначалу будете делать ошибки (угадайте фразу) и это нормально, на них учатся.

Отдельно хочу упомянуть музыкальное сопровождение, оно как всегда на высоте, игровые звуки и анимация сделаны гладко и наглядно. Глаз радуется. 10 отсортированных единиц из 10.

23616824.review:
For those willing to learn computer programming, the Human Resource Machine is a pretty and fun game that will teach you the wonders of, uhm, assembly language, and (starting at level 20 or so) force you to optimize the hell out of your code for size or speed. I only miss IP manipulation. And a stack. [strike]Indirect addressing and[/strike] bitwise operators wouldn't be bad either! [UPDATE: Indirect addressing appeared in level 29! Yay!]

I kid you not. I've read in a review that the game would be impossibly hard for nonprogrammers, and boring and trivial for those who already code. It's a lie! In the past 25 years I used many assemblers, wrote a lot of C code and learnt the ways of IDA Pro — I think I'm not a too lousy coder myself, yet I'm enjoying HRM. The optimization goals can actually be challenging, and you can always raise your personal bar if it's too easy. Oh, you can also go beyond the game itself, and write your own machine that understands HRM code. Or a compiler that generates HRM code. But I digress, these are not game features, but something you can do on your own if you're really interested.

How I would change it? I wish it could accept user-generated levels. Subroutines or library functions, as I mentioned earlier, would be interesting, as well as a stack for recursive code, but then we would soon have a real CPU simulator there, which is probably beyond the scope of a simple game. So let's say it's cool as it is, and user content would be a worthwhile addition. But the real importance of HRM, and the reason I liked it so much, is that It brings back to the world of the living a brief glimpse of the lost art of assembly programming — and I'm quite happy with that.

大多数关卡其实都挺简单的，少数一些要求对于一些基本算法有了解。要达成两个优化目标确实有难度，但如果目标只是通关的话，其实大概4个小时就够了。
