23588670.review:
A very simple and lacking assembly interpreter wrapped up as a video game.
Good Idea, badly executed. I hoped for much more.

70s programming/10

Edit: 

As requested in the comments the answer to: "What would you have added to the game to improve the "execution". If you had the opportunity." Here is my answer:

There are just so many things one could imrove, just for the start you could fix the touch-device centric ui design which results in odd things like being unable to write a comment using your keyboard (instead of using the mouse to draw your text) or the fact you can only see very few lines of your "code" at once, most of the screen is just filled with the background picture which doesn't do nothing at all.

A further point I do not understand is why the game is sticking with just the most primitive of commands and limitations of assembly throughout the gameplay. Take the task of implementing an algorithm to add two numbers without actually using the "add" function, it is fun at first but it would be perfectly ok, to say something like: 'You have unlocked the 'add' command!" so one could just use it from now on.
Or why the hell should I use gotos (aka 'jump to') instead of 'if'-clauses.
Or why is it impossible to define functions so i do not have to duplicate my commands all the time.
These are the most basic concepts in programming which would allow to introduce much more complex (and fun) tasks to solve instead of just playing assembly code golf.

The potential this game could have is nearly endless based on the premise that you are actually just programming using a very low-level language. Gamers with no affinity to programming whatsoever could be introduced to concepts like loops, conditions, functions or even patterns (producer/consumer pattern would fit perfectly) which could be a good basis to introducing a storyline.

Instead this game just feels like a rip-off, I assume it wouldn't take more than few weeks to put this thing together for a skilled game developer.

This game actually teaches you to program in Assembler in a fun and encouraging way.
Just getting through isn't that hard, but the optimization challenges require some hard thinking and tricky tweaking.
If you want to (and I needed to a few times) you can also use an external code editor to write your program, which is very useful if you've got JUMP instructions all over the place and the confusion sets in.

If you like to program - even just a little - or would like to be able to - this might be for you.

Should also be used in programming classes in schools, if you ask me - my younger self would have enjoyed this game, back in the days.

23467577.review:
[h1]卡通化可视化轻松编程：从入门到放弃[/h1]

前10关很轻松，很兴奋，编程界面卡通化，拖拽操作掩盖了难度，得到perfect兴奋得不要不要的，终于摆脱了大学里VB弃考的阴影，仿佛成为全栈工程师的人生巅峰就在眼前，指日可待。

当时同事群里有工程师安利这款游戏，我凑表脸地表示：「好巧我也在玩，通关了可以转开发吗？」
想必你也猜到了，能说出这种话的只能是该死的产品经理。

后来难度逐渐增强，开始卡关。
尝试努力自己解决，还是过不去。
尝试用创造性[strike]胡乱写[/strike]的解决方案，还是过不去。

然后请教工程师同事。被嘲笑。但好歹过关了。
再一次卡关。
jump循环以上过程。

我生气了。扪心自问，我为什么要花钱买bug。这是一个卡关就没有其他办法、只能干瞪眼被程序员嘲笑的编程游戏，游戏的负向反馈到后来越来越强烈，全栈的梦想也破灭了。自学JS，自学Python之类的计划，再delay几年吧。

23434946.review:
I purchased this game at a reduced price via a Humble Bundle.

Created by the same company as 2012's "Little Inferno", this puzzler might be described as "TIS-100 without tears": while it also teaches basic concepts of assembly language programming, it does so in a very polished visual style, and at a considerably lower level of difficulty.

This game would be a good starting point for those interested in the programming puzzler genre (TIS, Spacechem, etc) although be prepared to google if you don't have a background in computer science - an understanding of how computers multiply numbers, for example, would be a big advantage. Recommended.

23413711.review:
美工，音乐，背景设定，小幽默和调侃还是不错的，但核心玩法和UI非常烂。先说UI，作为一个编程游戏，代码框在界面中所占小的可怜，本来就只有1/4屏幕宽度，还只能同时显示不到15行代码，到后面代码一多要不停滚动严重影响阅读和思考；JUMP指令要占用两行，而且不是指定行号，而是有另一个框框拖过去要跳转到的行上方，还和JUMP指令有箭头连线，多用几次JUMP你的代码界面已经难以阅读了；玩了几关之后游戏提供注释功能，但不能输入字符（整个游戏都是纯GUI操作没有打字），要靠人手画图，本来代码框就小，加上硕大的注释能阅读的代码更少了，不如不写。再说说游戏内容，基本上照搬汇编基本指令，每一关都是给予一组输入，然后产生一组符合题目逻辑的输出，嘛这没有问题，但是每一关的问题太基础了，指令也很少，你可以做的就是线性输入这些指令，每一关能写出的代码都没啥优化空间，基本上就是和挑战里头最小指令数相同，即使不同，实现逻辑也是一样的，不存在什么奇巧淫技可以研究和使用，一点挑战的乐趣都没有；最小步数就更傻了，因为指令数没有优化空间，那么要优化步数基本就是靠展开循环（因为JUMP占用1步），然后把上面的代码拷贝一遍，直到省去的JUMP次数满足最小步数要求……这是哪门子的编程！

总之，除了小清新的包装，和满足一些人对编程的好奇心以外，没有可取之处，我甚至不认为这是一个游戏。同样以汇编为主题的TIS-100比这个好100倍，那个才是Game而不是刷leetcode，虽然界面不讨一般人喜欢就是了。4/10 不推荐。

TIS-100 is 100 times better than this as a coding 'Game', 4/10 not recommended.

23400320.review:
[h1]ОЦЕНКА ИГРЫ*[/h1]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=863758541

[h1]РАЗБОР ИГРЫ[/h1]

В [b]Human Resourch Machine[/b] мы выступаем в роли эдакого офисного работника, что всю свою жизнь (а точнее 42 года) отдаст на служение верой и правдой Фирме. Суть в том, что слева нам приходят некоторые данные, которые мы, в зависимости от задания, обработав должны направить на конвейерную ленту с другой стороны. 

Где-то отобрать только отрицательные числа, где-то из каждой пары выбрать наибольшее число и всё в том же духе. Тонкость в том, что всё управление в игре осуществляется не на прямую,  а по средствам команд из которых мы должны выстроить нужный для ситуации алгоритм.
Постепенно количество команд увеличивается, а задания становятся намного сложнее и интересней.

В игре не самый удобный редактор алгоритма так как любой алгоритм содержащий более 10 команд становиться трудночитаемым, лично я сначала все прописывал на бумаге. Но когда маленький человечек по твоему алгоритму выполняет всё правильно вызывает какие-то невероятные чувства блаженства.  Благо у игры очень забавный визуальный стиль и смотрится она, в общем, хорошо.

Обижает только отсутствие внятного туториала. В какой-то момент в игре стало необходимо вычитать буквы из букв, а я, черт возьми, так и не понял как это делать, даже скопировав алгоритм прохождения. [b]Tomorrow Corporation	[/b] словно боялись хоть как-то помочь игроку.

Результатом игра получилась очень требовательной. Это не простенькая головоломка, а именно сложное создание алгоритма, что вполне может стать отталкивающим фактором для многих игроков. 

Каждый уровень так же имеет дополнительные требования по лимиту строк в алгоритме и количеству действий, которые совершит работник выполняя его. В погоне за ними можно просидеть немало времени в попытках улучшить свой алгоритм. 

 [h1][b]Human Resourch Machine[/b] по своему интересная головоломка. Составлять алгоритмы интересно, а наблюдать за их исполнением одно удовольствие, но  отсутствие, порой, очень необходимых подсказок-примеров делает порог входа для игры несколько выше чем это нужно обычной казуалочке. [h1]

[url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=412623516]*Что значит каждая оценка[/url]

23305213.review:
[b]Human Ressource Machine[/b] von den Machern von World of Goo und Little Inferno ist ein Programmier-Spiel. In der To­­mor­­row-Cor­­po­­ra­­tion-Optik durchläuft ein Mann sein Arbeits­­leben als fremd­­­­be­­stimmer, programmierter kleiner Angestellter. Bei dem Namen und dem Thema frage ich mich ja, ob den Machern bei dem Begriff "Human Resources", wie unsere Personalabteilung in­­zwi­­schen heißt, derselbe kalte Schauer über den Rücken gelaufen ist wie mir.

Dem Spieler werden Programmieraufgaben gestellt. Die Spielfigur spult dann in witzigen Ani­­ma­­tio­­nen das Programm ab. Der Vorgang lässt sich zum Glück auch stark beschleunigen. Außerdem kann man Programme in einzelnen Schritten und sogar in Rückwärtsschritten ablaufen lassen. (Für Prog­­rammierer: Die Figur ist Akkumulator/Register und auf dem Boden finden sich ein paar Speicherzellen. Aus der Eingabe muss nach vorgegebenen Regeln die Ausgabe gebildet werden.)

Indirekt gibt es drei Schwierigkeitsgrade: Die normalen Rätsel, die man lösen muss, um das Spiel erfolgreich abzuschließen, zusätz­­liche Rätsel, die man auslassen könnte, aber nicht sollte, und als Krönung zu jeder Aufgabe optionale Optimierungsvorgaben für Ge­­schwin­­dig­­keit (durch­­schnitt­­liche Anzahl der benötigten Befehle pro Durch­­lauf) und Programm­­größe (Anzahl der Befehle im Programm). Häu­­fig braucht es zwei grundverschiedene Programme, um die je­­wei­­li­­gen Optimierungsziele zu erreichen.

Etwas unhandlich ist die Erstellung der Programme per Drag und Drop. Außerdem muss man in längeren Programmen viel scrollen und verliert schnell die Übersicht. Man möchte meinen, so ist das halt bei Ports von Mobil-Spielen - aber das Spiel gibt es er­­staun­­li­­cher­­wei­­se gar nicht für Tablets! [i](Nachtrag: [url=http://www.appgefahren.de/human-resource-machine-neues-spiel-der-macher-von-world-of-goo-171264.html]Inzwischen doch.[/url])[/i] Man kann Programme auch in die Zwischenablage kopieren und außerhalb des Spiels mit einem Edi­­tor seiner Wahl bearbeiten, aber das ist weder sonderlich hand­­lich noch hilft es mir bei der Immersion.

Macht so ein Spiel Nicht-Pro­­gram­­­­mierern Spaß? Ich weiß es nicht. Letztlich ist es Logik, ein Stück weit Mathematik. Wer also gern Rätselspiele spielt und beim Wort "Mathe" nicht gleich schreiend wegläuft, kann sich durchaus mal an so einem Spiel probieren. Wenn er keine Idee hat, was dieses "Pro­­gram­­mie­­ren" eigentlich ist, erhält er hier zusätzlich eine Vorstellung von den Grund­­lagen dieses Handwerks. Und wer die Lösungen aus dem Ärmel schüttelt, kann sich immer noch an TIS-100 probieren...

23301599.review:
Для начала финальный вывод: 10/10

Что это такое: это история про программирования. В которой надо программировать, естественно. Но все не так просто: коротенькие диалоги и «как бы видео-вставки» с тонкой иронией рисуют полную здорового и жизнерадостного кретинизма жизнь большой и сильно забюрокраченной конторы. Правда, для того чтобы оценить эти стилистические красоты нужно самому в такой конторе поработать. В остальном игра сводится к попыткам написать оптимальный (что важно) код на языке, сильно напоминающем первобытные вервии Basic-а.

Плюсы:
•	Полезность (это я про прививаемые навыки). Игрушка реально учит, причем не просто «языку» - язык там никакой практической значимости не имеет – но навыкам «правильного мышления».
•	Простота освоения.
•	Компактность (идет на любом антиквариате).
•	Стебный вид.

Минусы:
•	Язык нет просто простой, а очень простой. И основан на конструкции goto -> label – т.е. уровень не шибко современный. Также не ждите классов, подпрограмм и всякого такого безобразного результата объектно-ориентированного подхода.

23299142.review:
The robopocalypse is nigh!

The writing’s been on the wall for years, and yet we blindly stride forward toward a self-constructed doom. Despite warnings from CEOs, internet celebrities, and science fiction movies the world over, we the sheeple refuse to accept that our ravenous technological cravings have sealed our fate. The question is not if but when our new robot overlords will rise to power, eventually overtaking humanity and ushering in a new era of life on earth. As robotic life ascends we will watch, helpless, as they move in on our land, our loved ones, and especially, our jobs. Here, amidst the pandemonium, we will be reminded of Tomorrow Corporation, a tiny indie developer known for their aggressive cynicism and delightfully unsettling artwork. They tried to warn us, but alas their message came too late.

“How did they warn us,” you may ask yourself, as the metallic arms of a superior species crushes your spine like so many forests destroyed in the name of progress. Why, with entry level coding puzzles of course! Tomorrow Corporations’ 2015 follow up to 2012’s Little Inferno (also known as Schrödinger’s cutest and most flammable cat), Human Resource Machine is a programming focused puzzle game featuring everything you would expect from a studio that has seemingly fallen into an existential ditch and decided they liked it down there.

Human Resource Machine is two parts inscrutable “if-X-then-Y” coding conundrums, one part robotic doomsday sendoff to the white-collar worker, both delivered with as much self-aggrandizing snark as can be squeezed into the four or five hours the game takes to complete.

If you are expecting Human Resource Machine to offer you an introduction to real-world coding, you should probably look elsewhere. Rather than give you a crash course in any modern coding language, Human Resource Machine is a logic driven puzzler utilizing a simple drag-and-drop interface to order instructions for your worker to undertake (because aren’t we all just cogs in the capitalistic machine?). This approach does a lot to minimize the learning curve insofar as actually entering commands, and for the first few levels Human Resource Machine does a fantastic job of introducing basic order-of-operation sequences as it cycles in new commands and tasks you with completing tedious but oddly satisfying objectives.

Rather quickly though the steady difficulty curve Human Resource Machine begins to lead you down turns into a sharp incline. As one might expect from a game whose attempts at satire and metanarrative are as subtle as throwing someone out a window, Human Resource Machine is not the least bit interested in offering you a handhold when you come up against a puzzle that is utterly incomprehensible to those unfamiliar with coding logic. On the contrary, much of the game is predicated upon corporate enforced ignorance, with your boss overseeing you not for the sake of offering assistance but to mock your own inefficiency and inability to grasp what he assures you is basic at most.

Which, from what I have gleamed from actual coders who have played the game, is actually the truth. Though I wouldn’t have known from simply playing the game, Human Resource Machine is ostensibly among the least mentally taxing programming puzzlers currently out there (a genre made up of other obscure indie darlings, such as SpaceChem and TIS-100). This then makes it hard for me to understand who Human Resource Machine is for. As a non-coder I repeatedly found myself coming up against puzzles I hadn’t the slightest idea how to solve, forcing me to look outside the game for assistance, and even then often failing to understand how a solution worked therefore giving me little to go on for future puzzles. If Human Resource Machine was designed for accessibility, that goal was buried somewhere along the way and replaced with an inscrutable, unintuitive experience that is all the more aggravating because it apparently shouldn’t be as difficult as it is.

Even when I was able to solve a puzzle on my own, I was met with a halfhearted sense of accomplishment, as even having made progress there was no guarantee the next level wouldn’t be entirely impenetrable. The difficulty curve in Human Resource Machine is among the most erratic of any game I have ever played, alternating between patronizingly simplistic and excessively challenging with the regularity of an elderly man’s digestive track.

Upon progressing Human Resource Machine will occasionally interject with coffee break vignettes which flesh out what could loosely be called a narrative, but, more directly, serve to reiterate the game’s overarching message of impending robotic doom. Or maybe the take away is that all corporations are evil and are only keeping us around as long as we are still useful to them. Or maybe it’s that we will do anything, no matter how tedious and inane, if it’s framed as a game. I’m not sure I could say with certainty what Human Resource Machine is really trying to. From where I’m standing it seems generous to say it has much of a say on anything, and isn’t merely rattling off along the same “everything is meaningless” train of thought that began with (and was better executed in) Little Inferno.

Whether a warning, a joke, or an attempt to reignite the market for edutainment, Human Resource Machine accomplishes little beyond damaging itself for the sake of establishing a tone that doesn’t actually say anything strongly enough to be worth hearing. At times, Human Resource Machine is a dry but reluctantly satisfying puzzle game, and at others it exhausted me with its antagonistic approach to instruction and tedious structure. At this point I would almost welcome the robotic uprising, as at the very least they will surely have a better time at this than I did. The warning may have failed then, but so did my program loop.

[b]You can read more of my writing on [url=http://kritiqal.com/2016/05/30/human-resource-machine-review/]Kritiqal[/url].[/b]

23174311.review:
[u]此评测站在程序员视角，实际难度可能有偏差[/u]

这是一个简单的编程游戏。
这个游戏一大特点在于你可以看着你的小人根据你写的代码跑来跑去地干活，那种具现化的感觉，爽。
游戏中玩家使用的是一个很基础的语言，设计运算符计算，pointer的一些操作和jump循环，[b]没有while loop[/b]，要说的话有点像three address code。有的玩家可能会觉得没有while很蛋疼，[strike]确实很蛋疼，[/strike]就假装自己是一个编译器好了。

编程部分不难，关数也不多，通关之外还有两个额外挑战：速度优化和长度优化，比较有意思。[b]挑战是精髓[/b]
我没看攻略，没打草稿的情况下，除了最后一关的时候因为不小心把游戏删了没做完全挑战，其他关的双挑战都做完了。[strike]（游戏时间并没有显示的那么长，有一次挂着睡了一小觉）[/strike]

对于程序员来讲，这个游戏可以当作活动活动脑筋的优化谜题。对于没接触过编程的玩家，把这个游戏当作一个寓教于乐的解谜小游戏来玩也很不错。

[h1]优点：[/h1]
和little inferno,world of goo类似的友好又有点诡异的画风。
剧情上似乎也有承接，对于这种剧情不太重要的游戏，本作黑暗、抽象又有些可疑的剧情深得我心。
据说中文翻译还不错。
教程详尽，上手容易。
谜题+挑战难度设置合理，可玩性高。
配置要求低，在我的小破surface上也能玩。

[h1]缺点：[/h1]
题有点少。

[h1]推荐：[/h1]
喜欢解谜游戏的玩家，程序员，喜欢解谜游戏的程序员

23162146.review: It's the most fun assembler programming course there is.

23162020.review:
This game simulates simple programming concepts using a corporate mail room as the setting.  The player selects a list of actions that achieve a desired result.  For example, moving odd numbers from one side of a room to another or adding two numbers together and putting the result in the mail room's "outbox".  The concepts start fairly straightforward, but there are some particularly onerous (optional) challenges that make things interesting for the more experienced developers.  Most puzzles include at least 2 optimization challenges: use the least number of commands, and perform the task most efficiently.  I'm a programmer and I find some of these challenges difficult.  

The ambiance captures a satirical heartless corporation filled with clueless managers and soul-crushing orders from the executives.  The mood is kept light with colorful and cute characters, despite the dreary brown office interior.   Several "interludes" provide some brief comic relief.

In short, Human Resource Machine is a very enjoyable, casual game.  I highly recommend it for anyone who appreciates or wants to hone their programming skills.

23154920.review: I am a programmer, so i really liked the game. But if you don't have a programming background i think it would be harder to grasp the consept of some commands, it could have been explained a bit better. And I really liked the game in the beginning, pretty simple levels, got a bit harder for every level. But then later in the game there was a big spike in difficulty, i couldn't complete the last levels without watching a guide, exactly what i don't want to do while playing a puzzle game. If the levels didn't get so hard so quickly and there were some examples for how to solve some specific problems i would really recommend this game to my friends.

23152088.review:
It's a good puzzle game. I found it too quick and easy to finish (even doing all the optional assignments) but then again I've got a master in mathematics and computer science... However, those are definitely not needed at all, only some knowledge of mathematics is needed, and the game hints with wikipedia got you covered there.

The story is very simple and most cinematics are rather pointless, the levels don't really reflect what's going on, and the music is merely good rather than excellent. None of this is bad, but I was expecting better on these points from the creators of World of Good.

Overall, it's not an amazing classic like WoG, but it's still an enjoyable puzzle game for those who want to play at being a programmer.

23134716.review:
Este juego podría formar parte de las prácticas de 1º de la carrera de informática y no pondría ninguna pega al respecto.

Human Resource Machine es un juego que simula una pequeña unidad de computación con la que tendremos que procesar datos para obtener el resultado que nos digan (dividir números, ordenar series, descifrar textos...).

El interfaz es muy fácil de manejar y las operaciones son sencillas (se llega a introducir el concepto de punteros, que es posible que sea un poco más complejo de entender para los noveles en la materia).

Existe una ruta principal y unas rutas alternativas con problemas más complejos aunque en general asequibles, el programa más largo no supera las 30-40 instrucciones. Se premia el programa más corto y el programa más rápido, pero no se obliga a buscar la perfección.

Si alguna pega se le puede poner es que a veces la simulación lleva demasiado tiempo en los puzzles más grandes, y que al final el número de problemas es limitado.

En resumen, un interesante pasatiempo para programadores, no sé qué le parecerá al resto de mortales.

23133532.review:
Juego de puzles basados en programación con muchas más limitaciones que un lenguaje de alto nivel. 

Inicia desde cero y con niveles muy sencillos, pero los retos de optimización del código pronto añaden alicientes hasta llegar al tramo medio del juego donde el porcentaje de jugadores que los ha conseguido todos es escaso. El juego va incorporando nuevos elementos y lentamente complejidad en el objetivo básico de las pantallas hasta llegar al salto que supone la última.

Y si bien ese último nivel es el más difícil destacado de los necesarios para completar el juego y yo contaba con conocimientos de programación, creo que pasarlo sin conseguir los retos no es exageradamente difícil, al contrario de lo que parece decirse en otro análisis.


Yo lo recomendaría tanto a quienes les guste programar y no sean consumados expertos como a los que simplemente les atraigan los puzles.

23131454.review:
全成就达成~
[spoiler]虽然优化有几个可耻地看了别人的程序才写出来[/spoiler]

游戏很适合编程的初学者，甚至是没有任何编程基础的人也可以玩，玩了应该也会有帮助吧。难度并不高，最终关不过是排序而已，而且整个游戏几乎不涉及有难度的算法。
游戏刻意去除了乘法和除法，每次都要重新用循环来模拟，还是略微繁琐，第一次写出来之后给个函数就好啦，每次写只是麻烦而已，没有必要。
有趣的是，一方面游戏的数据很有限，很多题目都不用考虑大数据，但是游戏却严禁骗分，会让你重写还给个成就23333

游戏的背景非常有趣，叙述简洁，我很喜欢~

作为高中去NOIP打过酱油的文科生...已经有许多年没有碰过编程了，高中虽然学得漫不经心，但感觉写程序还是挺有趣的。不知道的是，如果那时比赛的得分再多一点，真的莫名成了程序猿，还会觉得编程有意思吗？因而对我而言，这个游戏竟然带上了些许情怀[spoiler]虽然情怀现在成了贬义词[/spoiler]。

总之强烈推荐~尤其是对不了解程序的人。程序猿的话，当作休息也可以玩玩？

这个游戏比较特别，就不进行评分了。

23083210.review:
[h1]Very nice puzzle game[/h1]

This game teaches the very basic of programming : Sequence, Selection, Iteration.
The puzzles are basic mathematic operation, and some are to process letters (strings).
If you have good logic and played many puzzle games, then you also can solve all the puzzles in this game even if you don't have programming experience.

[h1]Pros :[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Great and very friendly User Interface.
    [*]Can put a label to floors (variables) and workflow (code).
    [*]Dialogs are fun, and the objectives are clear & easy to understand (for me).
    [*]Can control the speed, step forward and backward to trace the program.
    [*]The puzzles are well made and leveled fairly. There are over 30 puzzles.
    [*]Each puzzle have many test cases, and the game is able to tell if our program doesn't work with other test, and even show you which test that doesn't work for your program.
    [*]Each puzzle have 2 challenges: Size Challenge (make the program with as few command as possible) and Speed Challenge (make the program to finish the job with less step). They make the game more fun.
    [*]The program you made can be copied and pasted to text editor such as Notepad, and can be pasted again to the game.
    [*]There are 3 tabs to put the workflow. I use it to make separate program for size challenge and speed challenge.
    [*]Easy achievements. Some are missable, but the achievement descriptions are very easy to understand.
    [*]Helpful community guide to solve all puzzles and 100% achievements. Thanks to whoever made it.
[/list]

[h1]Cons :[/h1]
[list]
    [*]The labels are drawing. It somehow annoying me to write labels by drawing with mouse. I prefer typing with keyboard.
    [*]No Steam Cloud Sync. I played it at my office PC, and couldn't load it from my home PC.
    [*]The puzzles especially above level 30 may be too hard for non-programmer players. If you able to play it till the end by yourself, then you are ready to become a programmer :D
[/list]

[quote] Don't worry if you've never programmed before - programming is just puzzle solving. If you strip away all the 1's and 0's and scary squiggly brackets, programming is actually really simple, logical, beautiful, and something that anyone can understand and have fun with! [/quote]

I'm sorry for my bad English. English is not my native language. Feel free to correct me.

Увага! Якщо ви - "дуже професійний" програміст з відсутнім почуттям гумору, в жоднім разі не купляйте цю гру, адже тоді ви про неї скажете щось на кшталт "Примітивні алгоритми! Гррр...". Всіх інших, хто хоче потренувати свій мозок, ласкаво просимо :)

23017995.review:
If you've never programmed before, HRM is essentially one of those drag the blocks coding tools, it will help you learn to program basic protocols taking inputs, processing them and outputing them.

If you have programmed before, HRM is an assembly language intepreter with challeneges for you to optimise certain tasks via fewest instructions or fewest steps.

First off, the graphics and general style matches up well with the other Tomorrow Corp Games. It's comical, doesn't take itself too seriously, it has an ominous feel, and provides a good framework to hide away the fact that this is really about computer science and code optimization.

Placed in an office building, you're given a simple drag the blocks code editor to build programs for your worker to solve. Your aim is to make these as simple or efficient as possible. Now, I should say that I despise drag the block code editors, so it came as a great surprise to me when I figured out that if you drag some blocks, hit 'copy' and then paste it in a notepad program, it's actually just assembly code. You can program it however you want. Great!

The tasks themselves start of pretty easy, but quickly grow in complexity. They range over your standard fare of beginner programming tasks, from string manupulation, sorting etc. to some more complex ideas such as using prime numbers towards the end. These definitely provide a challenge when optimizing, and some immense satisfaction when you can beat the targets.

Definitely worth playing if you're at all interested in computer science, or programming and logic in general. If you are less inclined towards this stuff, the game does a good job of easing you in, so you could give it a try too.

23006801.review:
I was hesitant to get this, due to some of the reviews I read, but I thoroughly enjoyed this game.

As far as programming games go, I'd say it's on the simpler side of the spectrum, but the difficulty and learning curve are very well done. I was a little disappointed with the limited commands in the game (There's no JNZ, for example), but happy to discover that some of the harder puzzles were basically built for more intricate commands. Because of this, you'll need to think outside the box more to find a solution, when you don't have the tools you'd usually have for such an issue.

I would not use this to [i]actually[/i] learn Assembly at all, but as a logic-building exercise (Which is a crucial skill in this field), it works quite well.

The challenges on each level (Solve with < x lines, or with < x steps) resulted in me finding multiple approaches to many of the levels, and they never felt unrealistic to me at all (As with some other programming games). You can always optimise the code more and more, but in real-world applications, past a certain point, this becomes trivial. So it's nice that you [i]can[/i] do this, but you don't actually need to.

Outside of the basic gameplay, the game has the same kind of whimsical-yet-heavy storytelling that Kyle Gabler's games so often have, and it doesn't beat you over the head with it. It's just kind of... there, offering you some speculative fodder and setting the tone for the game- Which it does very nicely.

If you're even idly interested in programming or code-based games, this is a good one.

22972768.review:
Voto: 6/10

Sono stato davvero vicino ad abbandonare questo gioco, ma poi hoi avuto una nuova idea e sono tornato in azione. 

E potete immaginare facilmente come mi sono sentito quando dopo aver completato l'ultimo livello il gioco ha detto che "la mia soluzione andava bene solo per una questione di fortuna. Prova questi altri numeri e vedrai che non funziona!" 

Però di nuovo dopo qualche minuto ho avuto una nuova idea (e mi ci è voluto UN SACCO per metterla in pratica)

Quindi...

Questo gioco è fatto dai creatori di Little Inferno, un gioco casual  tenero e breve che avevo già giocato e gradito. 

Human Resource Machine è stato fin da subito più difficile, ma pensavo che sarei riuscito a gestirlo facilmente... La sfida diventa più intensa nell'ultima parte nel gioco.... e l'ultimo livello è stato UNA MATTONATA. 

Il gioco ti richiede di completare alcuni compiti usando comandi come "aggiungi uno" "prendi da qui" "metti là" "sottrai questo", ecc. , quindi è un po' come programmare (anche se io non l'ho mai fatto). 

E dunque posso ben capire adesso come mai alcuni programmatori adorano il proprio lavoro... e anche perché altri lo odiano. 

La difficoltà non sarà così intensa per chi è abituato a quel tipo di ragionamenti, ma per noi comuni mortali sarà davvero impegnativo. 

E l'ultimo livello... mi ci è voluto più tempo per quello che per tutti gli altri messi insieme! 

Ma se riesci a farcela, specialmente se non hai familiarità con la programmazione, potresti sentirti figo e intelligente come un ingegnere (solo che tu hai lavorato gratis e anzi a dirla tutta hai pure pagato per farlo ;) )

In definitiva... se vuoi giocare HRM sai cosa aspettarti. 

+ Musiche leggere e carine
+ Grafica ABBASTANZA carina
+ Il gioco è molto intelligente
+ Impegnativo
+ Un tocco di umorismo

- Alla fine troppo difficile- Eventually too hard
- L'ultimo livello ha un enorme incremento di difficoltà
- I livelli bonus sono molto difficili così come lo sono le sfide per ogni livello.

Most people say that this game teaches you programming basics. In my opinion it teaches you how NOT to be a programmer.
Sure, you get an introduction about how a computer thinks, but the game makes you find the most complicated solutions for the easiest problems which gives you a false view on how programming really works.
For example, you get the task to multiply two numbers. Instead of just multiplying them (like you would do in a real code) you have to store them (like variables), add them and keep checking and changing the variables until you've done the multiplying process. And then repeat it.
I realize that a lot of important "codes" are missing in order to make the game more challenging, but that's not what I expected from reading the reviews.

22930170.review:
A lot of the negative reviews are from programmers who already know how to code who say it's too easy. I am not a programmer. Here is my review.

You play an office drone in the mailroom of a large corporation, tasked with menial jobs like sending boxes from the inbox to the outbox, adding numbers to them, subtracting numbers, reordering them, sending only primes, alphabetizing, etc. along the way. As you progress, there are little bits of "story" that just seem cute at first but then become hilarious as you realize the world outside is changing in strange ways as you while away the years in an office. I was pleasantly surprised that this game even had a story at all.

As for the coding itself. You have a limited amount of commands, so your code is never going to be super efficient. (Ex. You have to divide quite often, but a divide command is unavailable, so you have to do an excessive amount of subtraction to get the same effect). A lot of the fun comes from trying to figure out non-obvious ways of achieving tasks that are simple in the real world with what you have. There are also challenges for optimizing your code, either with the minimum amount of steps or the minimum amount of commands. The coding style is with little boxes that you arrange in a list (no typing code), some with arrows to redirect your sequence. It's most similar to the coding system Scratch, for reference.

Pros:
+Great art style
+Good music (although repetitive, but I never got sick of it)
+Speed/efficiency challenges for each level add replayability
+Harder bonus levels that you can skip if you don't want the challenge
+Cute little story
+Slick UI, with only minor issues (see Cons)

Neutral:
~Minimal story, so don't expect one and you won't be disappointed. In fact, I was pleasantly surprised at what there was.
~Mouse only. This isn't really too big of an issue, but there are ways to add notes to your code to help you keep track of what you're doing, but you have to write them by had with your mouse, which is kind of annoying. Definitely not game breaking, and it also allows you to draw pictures if you want, which did come in handy at times.

Cons:
(None of these are game-breaking. Just little annoyances)
-Code is very inefficient, so you end up with really long bits and it's easy to forget what parts of the code are doing what. You either need to use the note function to remind yourself what you're doing or debugging your code will be a nightmare. When changing one thing led to tons of errors, I often just deleted everything and started from the beginning just because it was easier than figuring out what I had done.
-No way to select chunks of code for easy delete. If you wanted to get rid of half of your 40-command-long-code, you had to delete each command by hand, or just delete the entire thing at once and start from scratch.

Overall: 9/10. If you're a programmer, you might find this too easy. Go play SpaceChem instead. For the average gamer who likes logical arguments or amateur coding, you'll find this to be a hoot. Cute little game. Overall playtime for me: 15 hours, all levels (without doing optimization challenges).

22904631.review:
Ça y est. On en est (enfin ?) là. Le fantasme absolu de Pierre Gattaz. Pour se distraire, la plèbe, lassée du pain et des jeux, s'achète des simulations d'employé de bureau pour occuper son temps libre. Et elle aime ça. Les Chinois, qui ont décidément toujours deux trains de retard, rêvent de travailler moins pendant que l'Occident s'amuse à travailler plus.

Human Resource Machine nous plonge dans le costume à cravate un peu trop ample de l'un de ces vilains ingénieurs qui ont la colonne vertébrale en U et l'oeil ruiné par leur petit bureau de travail surmonté d'un nordinateur. L'un de ces anciens ados qui, à défaut d'avoir été escroqué comme les autres par une conseillère d'orientation qui ne savait pas trop quoi en faire, s'est laissé séduire par les rêves qu'il travaillait sur l'oreiller de devenir lui-même un jour le concepteur du nouveau Donjons & Dragons, persuadé que c'est avec de grosses lunettes aux verres triple épaisseur et des conversations de geek qu'on attrape les filles. Rêver d'être un artiste aussi génial, créatif, libre, populaire et punk qu'un guitariste au cheveu gras pour in fine passer ses après-midi à dégueuler du code sur un tabouret. Ces grands cassos de la vie qui ne font pas leurs soldes à Celio mais sur topachat qui, devenus adultes, gagnent plus d'argent que moi à un âge où les plus belles femmes s'achètent. Comme quoi la roue finit toujours par routourner.

À défaut de goûter leur salaire, Human Machine Resource nous initie au codage et à ses logiques, à ses plaisirs mathématiques, nous inculque le soucis de l'optimisation sans jamais cesser de nous amuser. Les journées de notre employé aussi fidèle à son entreprise qu'un salaryman japonais n'ont rien de monotone : les énigmes ne se ressemblent pas mais s'articulent toujours autour d'un objectif nouveau qui nous obligera à comprendre de nouvelles solutions. La difficulté, stimulante mais pas frustrante, renouvelle puzzle après puzzle notre envie d'avancer. Le monde d'Human Resource Machine, limité à la façade de son usine, à la prison des quatre murs de la salle de travail avec pour seule promenade les alentours de la machine à café, est peuplé de silhouettes grises et de visages en désordre. Des formes rigolotes qui vivent et vieillissent dans un univers terne. L'ambiance, dont on ne sait pas si elle est trognonne ou déprimante, est un petit régal qui s'amuse de la tristesse d'une vie répétitive sans jamais nous en faire ressentir le poids, trop occupés que l'on est à relever de nouveaux défis. Un jeu amusant d'un bout a l'autre qui sait nous piquer gentiment autant que nous fait rire. Finie cette enfance où l'on passait son mercredi après-midi à jouer aux cowboys et aux aventuriers LU en attendant que maman se décide à tartiner de nutella deux tranches de pain de mie, Human Resource Machine est un jeu qui donne l'envie de passer des Nuits Debout à faire semblant de travailler avec la calvitie pour seule hâte.

Parfaitement jouable depuis une tablette.

22897539.review:
Human Resource Machine is a puzzle game that requires you to program in a language similar to assembly code. You give a worker instructions on how to operate on inputs and storage to achieve the desired outputs. The game has an appropriate learning curve and slowly eases the complex mechanics onto the player. However near the end, casual players may need to research algorithms in order to complete the task.

In addition, there are optimization goals which challenge your program's speed and size. This, at times, requires out of the box thinking which challenge you on program compression. Fantastic stuff.

For the non-programmer, this is a great introduction to programming assembly. 
For the programmer, this a great exercise to test your skills on.

10/10.

En effet, la liberté qu'offre le jeu est totale et les multiples commandes à notre disposition permettent à tout à chacun d'aboutir à sa propre solution, aussi bancale et inélegante soit-elle. Comme en vrai quoi...

22896016.review:
I'm a professional software engineer. I like programming games. Human Resource Machine was... okay. I like the graphics, I like that one can add comments and labels, and I like the music. But let's talk about the core gameplay: the puzzles.

The puzzles are pretty simple for the most part, with the exception of the side-branches (which are nicely hard, and optional), and the final puzzle, which is literally a second-year computer science exercise in writing a sort algorithm in assembler. It's rather a big leap from all the other puzzles you've been working on. It would make a great side-branch challenge, but it's a rather brutal challenge for a typical player.

If you've got a programming background, you can knock the main branch (and "win the game") in about 3-4 hours, which means the content feels a bit lacking. If you don't have a programming background, the last puzzle will be crushingly hard, which means endless frustration when you can't win the game. This leaves Human Resource Machine not well-placed for *either* audience. I'd love to say the storyline makes up for this, but unfortunately it doesn't.

Instead of playing Human Resource Machine, I would recommend:

- TIS-100, if you've got a programming background. It's *very* well done.
- SpaceChem, regardless of your background. It has lots of challenges and will really make you think.
- Little Inferno, if you don't want a programming game at all, but do want an awesome story from Tomorrow Corporation.

Maybe grab this if it's on sale, but try one of the games above first instead of paying full-price.

22882951.review:
Dans [i][b]Human Resource Machine[/b][/i], vous incarnez [strike]un larbin[/strike] une personne fraîchement recrutée par une entreprise de... d'on ne sait trop quoi, en réalité. Qu'importe, votre mission est la suivante : utiliser les éléments qui arrivent à gauche de l'écran (inbox), selon les instructions données par votre supérieur hérarchique, afin d'envoyer les résultats appropriés à droite (outbox). Le tout grâce aux fonctions très simples qui seront introduites au fur et à mesure des 40 étages que compte l'immeuble de votre employeur.

Vous disposerez donc des fonctionnalités inbox et outbox, que j'ai déjà évoquées. Mais aussi de copyto et copyfrom, afin de copier une valeur dans ou à partir d'une case ; add et sub pour additionner ou soustraire ; bump+ et bump- pour incrémenter ; et enfin jump, qui permet d'aller à un endroit, parfois sous certaines conditions. Vous l'aurez compris, [i][b]Human Resource Machine[/b][/i] est un jeu de programmation, à base d'algorithmes, qui nécessite de temps à autre des notions mathématiques élémentaires : opérations, rang des chiffres, décomposition, nombres premiers, suite de Fibonacci, pour ne citer que ceux qui me viennent tout de suite à l'esprit.

Toujours est-il que la difficulté est savamment dosée. Pourvu que l'agorithmique ne vous soit pas étrangère, ce que de toute façon le jeu se charge de vous enseigner (avec beaucoup d'intelligence), rares sont les énigmes qui vous retiendront longtemps. Autre détail appréciable, le joueur dispose d'une liberté certaine dans leur résolution : plusieurs programmes mènent au bon résultat, le reste n'étant qu'affaire d'optimisation. C'est d'ailleurs là où le jeu devient plus intéressant encore ! Minimiser le nombre de fonctions ou d'étapes est un exercice qui oscille entre supplice et délice - oui, je sais, j'ai un problème... Il faut cependant reconnaître que la simplicité et le peu de fonctions disponibles engendre souvent dans le code un bordel sans nom.

Bref, je n'ai pas aimé [i][b]Human Resource Machine[/b][/i], j'ai tout simplement adoré !

[h1]Verdict : 4,5/5 - Excellent, à acheter les yeux fermés ![/h1]

22879599.review:
ASM-ohjelmointia pelin muodossa. 

[u]Pelimekaniikka[/u]
Ohjelmointia tehdään vetämällä käskyjä listaan, jotka sitten ajetaan nappia painamalla. ASM-käskyt ovat varsin karsittuja, ja operaatioita tehdään kokonaisluku- ja kirjaintasolla bittien sijaan, joka tuo oman mausteensa mm. XOR-operaarioiden tekemiseen. 

Muista ominaisuuksista mukana on eräänlainen debug-ominaisuus jolla voi mennä käskyjä askel kerrallaan, mutta koodiriveihin asetettavat breakpointit loistavat poissaolollaan. Pikakelaus löytyy, mutta se ei ole lähellekään tarpeeksi etenkään loppupäässä kun ohjelmoiden kestot mitataan sadoissa käskyissä. 

Itse ohjelmointipuzzlet olivat pääosin sopivan vaikeuksisia, ja oppaita löytyy pelin steam-foorumeilta ihan kiitettävästi, joista voi jumiin jäädessä itse valita haluaako vain pientä tönäisyä oikeaan suuntaan vain mallivastauksen. Plussaa siitä että koodia voi kopioida pelin ulkopuolelta ja liittää pelissä käskylistaan; myös toisinpäin toimii.

[u]Muuta[/u]
Tarina, animaatio ja musiikki olivat World of Goosta ja Little Infernosta tuttua tasoa - ei niin kamalaa etteikö kestäisi muttei tule ikäväkään.

tl;dr: Ihan mukava puzzle-peli, suosittelen kokeilemaan jos ohjelmointiongelmat kiinnostavat.

22874442.review:
Human Resource Machine
For the PC
Played using Mouse
Overall Rating: C


Human Resource Machine is a puzzle game – or more accurately, a programming game. You are given a very limited set of coding instructions which expand over the course of the game, and your goal is to solve all of the puzzles within a certain number of instructions or a certain number of lines executed. You have some basic looping commands (basically, GOTO and GOTO IF 0 and GOTO IF < 0), addition and subtraction, variables, pointers, and comments.

The goal is basically to take inputs and output according to the instructions. There are 41 levels in all.

There… honestly is little to be said about this game. It is pretty much a pure programming game, and while it might be an interesting puzzle for a lot of folks to solve, on the other hand, I feel like if you didn’t understand programming, a lot of this game would be very inaccessible, despite its supposedly easy interface. Writing programs in it is a process of click and drag, there’s no real ability to create subroutines, and sometimes it can feel a bit tedious when you realize you’ve barely exceeded the necessary parameters and are going to have to take an entirely new approach.

Honestly, if you’re going to spend six hours messing around with programming, you might as well spend that time messing around with a real programming language. The story here is at best vague and at worst obtuse and self-contradictory; are you working for robots? Are you a robot yourself? Who knows, and who cares? The whole thing ends up feeling rather pointless in the end.

I really enjoyed this programming simulator and I recommend it to anyone (except to, maybe, actual programmers :P).

It works because they keep it simple, with a user friendly interface and an appropriate learning curve.

It will make you think, debug and improve. Sometimes you will feel frustrated but also very rewarded when you get to solve a problem your own.

There is even challenge for the 'experts', as in each task there are goals regarding iterations and number of instructions to optimize code.

The most complicated task might bee too hard for people who have never been into programming before, but you can always look for help or solutions in the forums or the Internet.

One of the things I don't like about it is that, as many have mentioned, it doesn't support Steam Cloud, which would be great to save your code. I hope they'll implement it eventually. Also I miss more game modes (like with different instruction sets), leaderboards and even a Workshop implementation where users could create tasks that others download and try to solve.

All in all, a pleasant surprise that made me look for similar games that have to do with programming.

22862652.review:
It's always exciting to see a new game from the creators of World of Goo. In some aspects, HR Machine doesn't disappoint: the audiovisuals are at their quirky best, and the user interface is slick as hell - as usual. All is not well in the gameplay, unfortunately.
HR Machine is a design puzzle game, where you actually have to write simple programs. The early levels teach the basic programming concepts, and then it's on to more complicated tasks. In theory, the early levels should be great for eduction, and the later ones should keep seekers of challenge happy. In reality, the early levels do almost but not quite a great job, while the later ones are mostly disappointing.

The game does a good job of introducing load / store, loops and simple arithmetics, but I sorely miss comparison and proper branching - doing branching based on subtraction and jump-if-zero is not how I'd like to explain programming to my kids. I'll see if it will work eventually, but I sense a missed opportunity here.

The later levels are... well, not challenging. The tasks are rather straightforward, and the optimization challenges don't work well - the toolset is insufficient to do creative size optimizations, and speed optimizations too often turn into exploding loops to save on the jump instruction. For which the game is not very well equipped, so it's also time consuming without merit.
If someone grinds through the game, then he will eventually be rewarded by two excellent puzzles (Digit Exploder and Prime Factory) - if there'd be 10 more of these, I'd be quite happy.

All in all, HR Machine is an interesting game, and I can recommend it - but probably only under 3-4 EUR.

Pro：

+美术风格很讨喜，而且小人的操作直观反映了代码运作过程，非常适合编程初学者熟悉代码

Con：

-不支持mod或者题目编辑器，导致耐玩度略有不足

总体来说是一款比TIS100更易上手更讨喜但挑战性有所下降的编程型Puzzle类游戏，推荐所有解谜游戏爱好者尝试

Short answer: It's basicaly a RISC assembler for kids. I like it, event when there are few tedious levels.

Long answer: The middle part of the game was annoying a bit until all concepts were unlocked to be used. I would do few things differently, allow to change font sizes, allow type things on keyboard (you have to drag n drop everything, even comments you need to draw, can't type), or some shortcuts space for playing the simulation and [ ] to adjust speed would help. The visual jumps are nice when there is 3 of them, but when you have more of them they just annoy you. There is copy and paste and probably I enjoyed typing it manualy in other application and paste it back. I would allow CALL, RET instructions which would create routines / libaries, maybe allowing people carry over some libraries they made before. Now you have to start from scartch every time, one level checks for duplicates in memory, where the mem is already populated, next level is basicaly the same but you need to populate the memory yourself now. having nice common routines you could focus on problem solving and not the tedious work. What i enjoyed are the optimalisation parts a lot where you need to push limits of the architecture to the max. Definitely they should fix few things and create second game. I liked the backstory but was bit dark and maybe bit depresing for kids (but other games are much worse).

Definitely worth trying or even giving it to kids to experiment with coding.

22835233.review:
[h1]Positives[/h1]
+Quirky aesthetic
+Some nice music

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
-Music gets repetitive
-Puzzles are extremely difficult, with next to no guidance as to how to complete them
-Puzzles simply are not fun
-The story elements are uninteresting and never go anywhere

[h1]Summary[/h1]
As someone who immensely enjoyed World of Goo and Little Inferno, I was really excited to try the developers' next game, Human Resource Machine. Upon starting the game, I was glad to see that it retained the unique aesthetic sense from the previous titles, but that feeling was quickly overtaken by a sense of frustration and apathy. After the first few stages the puzzles increased in difficulty in such a sharp and dramatic manner that I felt blindsided.

Each stage of the game represents a year of employment and entails solving a programming problem involving some form of alphanumeric input and using your set of basic instructions to manipulate the data to conform to a desired form of output that your in-game boss communicates to you. You must construct a basic program using such tools as commands to pick items up from the input conveyor, copying to and from designated spaces, adding, subtracting, setting jump points useful for repeating sections of code and making conditional operations based on the data you happen to be working with at the moment. The puzzles start out easy enough, and it's simply a matter of arranging the commands at your disposal. After a short while though, the puzzles become exponentially more complicated and the game expects the player to take the few simple tools it gives, and use them to perform operations that the game makes little to no effort to explain. It felt as though since the game has established that you are capable of performing subtraction, you must therefore also be capable of not only division, but taking the products of multiple division operations, sorting them, and outputting them in a particular order – all using only the most basic of mathematical tools. Is it possible to accomplish these tasks? Yes. But the game doesn't establish the link between the simple and the complex, and doesn't prepare the player for the challenges it puts to them.

I spent a period of time that I felt was sufficient with each puzzle and while the first quarter of the game was doable, after a while it became apparent that I wasn't going to be able to solve the rest of these puzzles on my own. Since I wasn't particularly enjoying the experience I decided I would follow a guide and at lease see if the story held any value. Unfortunately, what story is there is merely window dressing. Whereas the previous titles World of Goo and Little Inferno had stories that shed some light on their dystopian surrealist worlds, the world of Human Resource Machine is never particularly enriched. Apparently a machine army is taking over and nobody in the game seems to notice or care. Nor is it relevant to the challenges you are facing. The Kafkaesque setting and characters led me to believe that there was probably a message in here, but by the end I found I didn't know what, if any, message was meant to be conveyed and I no longer particularly cared.

In the end, I can only recommend this game to people that enjoy this very narrow type of programming-based logic puzzle. Anyone else will likely be frustrated and bored, and unfortunately the charming graphics and music won't be enough to keep the player's interest.

My head hurts and I'm obviously sooo not up to the task but I'm liking it!

The game invites you to do a whole bunch ...well, a whole building's-worth of simple inbox->outbox sorting puzzles with just a handful of basic commands at your disposal - copying numbers & letters hither and thither, adding, subtracting, and comparing to your heart's content. 

You get to drag-and-drop the commands into a tower of code, strangle it with a spaghetti tangle of jumps and then watch it fail miserably on execture in the most 20-20 hindsight way possible, your little office worker running around sticking those numbers and letters where you definitely didn't mean them to be stuck. There's the extra challenges of refining your code to the smallest overall size or fewest steps to complete but yeah, they're mostly beyond me too.

Thankfully, it starts slow, drip-feeding a new command every few puzzles or so. It's a head-scratcher for me, to be sure but the game rides that wonderful balance between you knowing exactly what it is you have to do and you managing to weave your solution from the commands and floor space on hand.

It's cleanly presented but with that lovely Tomorrow Corporation artstyle and vibe. If you're a regular little brainbox with a passion for logic, you'll probably love this game.

What a massive dissapointment this was! I've loved pretty much all the programming games I've played.... SpaceChem, Manufactoria, The Codex of Alchemical Engineering, Lightbot, TIS-100... there are probably more that I can't remember.

I also really like the style of Tomorrow Corporation games, I thought World of Goo and Little Inferno had some really great aesthetics, even if they were way too expensive for what you got.

But this is just an awful, awful programming simulator. I think's probably trying to be friendly to non-programmers by leaving out as many of the niceties of a programming language as possible, hoping that that reduces complexity. Actually, all it means is that your programs become unreadable very, very quickly, lost behind a mess of arrows.

I did wonder for a little bit if it was trying to make some clever point about how when you program for a job in real life, time pressures and unrealistic specifications lead to the production of unreadable code... but I think that's me being very generous.

The final straw came trying to solve a level full of letters. I tried 'bumping' the value of one of the letters, which means adding one to it. 'Don't be stupid!!!' Said the game. 'What would that even mean??'. It didn't seem to have a problem with letting me subtract the letter 'B' from the letter 'A', giving me the result -1.

If you want a programming game, buy SpaceChem instead, or play The Codex of Alchemical Engineering free on various flash gaming sites...

22484555.review:
I simply have to write a review for game, even though I'll probably echo what everyone here already said.

This is a fantastic programming puzzle game. You program a little worker by clicking together a program for him to execute. The game is a fantastic visualization of programming's simple concept - input/computation/output by mapping it onto a little office worker that fetches boxes from an input conveyor belt, varying storage capabilities and comparison operations and a final output coneveyor belt.

Each level gives you a different task starting from very simple operations to increasingly more complex mechanics mirroring real-world techniques (pointers, zero-terminated strings anyone?). The tasks itself never feel repetitive, each one is a different challenge in itself. The learning curve is extremely well done and every level is a unique challenge. It just feels perfect in a way that you're never overwhelmed nor bored because of the available mechanics, all the while keeping the problems them simple and short enough to be done in a handful of steps.

For people that look for bigger challenges, there are optional side tasks (and they really become challenging), as well as special achievments for solving the regular and optional levels in as few as possible instructions (small program), or in as few as possible steps per input (small runtime).

I really find it hard to put into words how excellent this game is. Great art work, great puzzles, absolutely polished feel, great sound track.

If you're curious about programming or an actual programmer - give it a try!

Human Resource Machine is a fun little title that challendes you to think like a programmer. You'll look at basic input and output algorithms using simple programming buttons like "Inbox" , "Outbox", "sub", "add" and many more. 

It will slowly up the difficulty as you climb the corporate ladder so to speak. It's challenging enough to keep you nitpicking your code until you get it just right. There are challenges for those that seem to fly through it that forces you to optimize your code on a previously defeated challenge which is easier said then done sometimes.

The graphics are cute and the audio is nice and crisp and suits the title. The game's music can get a little repetitive after a while but just listen to your own tunes and program away. The game has an incredibly small footprint too, so even older and space strapped machines should be able to run this easily. 

I am currently nearly about half way through (not including optimization) and can honestly say that it is an excellent game. Requires some mathematics and some head scratching but it's good fun.

22359106.review:
"Assembler programming game" is an extremely small sub-niche in an already tiny corner of the puzzle game-space that is "puzzle games that you have to think really hard about". 

And Human Resource Machine is a good assembler programming game. The presentation is adorable, the UI is functional (although liable to drive anyone with real-world coding experience to distraction), the puzzles are smart, and the difficulty progression is measured. 

So why aren’t I more enthused with it? I think that the problem lies with me. I’ve dabbled with code over the years, I took an Assembler 101 course in college (which literally involved solving many of the exact puzzles provided in this game), and I’ve played other games that did the same job better. And by that, I mean that I’m a fan of Zachtronics’ games. Between SpaceChem, TIS-100 and Infinifactory, I’ve solved much harder and more complex coding problems. By contrast, Human Resource Machine is a bit of a snoozefest. 

And therein lies the problem. Human Resource Machine is an excellent coding game FOR PEOPLE THAT AREN’T EXPERIENCED CODERS. For folk with any degree of serious software chops, this isn’t going to stretch them. Of course, there’s some scope for chasing the optimization dragon, with in-game goals for lines of code and cycles to complete, but given the extremely simple nature of the puzzles, often those goals don’t even provide much of a stretch.

22290862.review:
I love puzzles, I love logic.  Ergo, I love logic puzzles.

Human Resource Machine is a cleverly hidden bit of education disguised as a fun puzzle game, teaching players just what exactly it is that computers do billions of times a second nowadays.

Your little employee avatar is tasked to program him/herself into taking whatever sequence of data is given and sending out whatever the current function is.  Can't do that directly, though, you have to program yourself using the most rudimentary commands: get an input, put whatever you're holding into a carpet memory cell, add, subtract, send out whatever you're holding, jump somewhere else in your program, among others.
It reminds me of an assembly-language course I took in college, but don't let that intimidate.  The interface is simple drag-and-drop, and you watch (and can step-trace) your little guy following your program in every detail, even when things go wrong.  Especially when things go wrong.

But make sure you do your own work.  Much of the satisfaction comes from a good debugging.  And if that's not enough, bonuses are given for optimizing program length and/or runtime.

If you want to learn a bit of programming logic, play this game.
If you like a challenging series of puzzles, play this game.

21856121.review:
This is one of the rare games that gets your brain in motion, keeps it thinking for solutions when you are not playing, and makes you feel smarter after you've played it.

It's about making short simple programs, with very limited tools. For example, you can copy, paste, add or substract but you can't multiply or divide. At the beginning you just need to add 2 and 2, but this rapidly escalates to making divisions (still without a division tool!), sorting data in alphabetical order, and extracting prime numbers!

It will require quite some creativity, experimentation and debugging to achieve, but you will be surprised and amazed how simple the solution always is.

It's about programming and yet it's not actual programming. It just teaches you how how to "think" like a machine. If you actually have programming skills you will possibly find this game too easy, or frustrating. 

Otherwise Human Resource Machine is a really challenging experience; it will require you to imagine and conceptualize your programs beyond what's displayed on the screen, until you find one of the solutions. There are many ways to solve each puzzle. Sometimes you think you've got it, and the game will throw an error message and then kindly feed you a different sequence to demonstrate how your program was flawed.

If this prospect doesn't scare you, go ahead and dive head in; I warmheartedly recommend Human Resource Machine!

21833696.review:
Je joue à ce jeu depuis environ 1 semaine. Le jeu est basé sur la logique; vous devez programmer une unité centrale de traitement offrant seulement 9 commandes: SUB, ADD, COPYFROM, COPYTO, JMP, JNEG, JZ plus INBOX et OUTBOX. Les programmes sont très variés: ils vont de la copie simple de l'entrée vers la sortie, d'une copie avec filtres (ne pas sortir les nombres négatifs, par exemple), à des programmes plus complexes comme  les suites Fibonacci ou le tri de chaînes de caractères.

Le meilleur qualificatif que je pourrais donner au jeu est "silly"! Je suis un développeur professionel, et je m'amuse bien dans ce jeu. Le nombre d'instructions disponible étant limité, il faut user d'imagination et de combinaisons surprenantes afin de créer un programme correct.

L'interface est très simple d'utilisation: un simple cliquer / glisser pour placer nos instructions. Les graphiques sont comiques et admirables. J'aime beaucoup les niveaux interstitiels un peu fêlés. Ce sont de petits "cut scenes" sans but réel, mais qui font rire.

J'ai deux filles, l'une de 11 ans et l'autre de 8 ans. Ma fille de 11 ans n'a pas du tout aimé le jeu. Elle n'a tout simplement pas embarqué dans le jeu. Elle a tout de même résolu les 4 premiers niveaux. La plus jeune par contre a bien aimée. Elle a résolu les 5 premiers niveaux. Elle a eu besoin d'un peu d'aide, surtout au niveau de la langue: sont vocabulaire anglais ne lui permet pas de comprendre les mnémoniques des instructions de l'unité centrale de traitement. Mais une fois qu'elle connaît le sens de l'instruction, elle l'utilise bien.

Je recommande chaudement ce jeu à tout personnes qui veulent introduire des enfants à la programmation, d'une façon simple et comique. Beau travail, Tomorrow Corporation!

21684675.review:
Human Resource Machine is by far the best puzzle game I have ever played. 

[h1]Learning Curve[/h1]
This is what the game does best in its class. It starts out extremly simple to introduce you to the concept. It then slowly increases the complexity to levels you would not believe.

The cool thing: It is completely new. Like your first time playing [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/400/]Portal[/url], you have to figure everything out yourself from the ground up.

[h1]Adapting to you[/h1]
These puzzle games sometimes manage to leave you behind or don't progress quickly enough for you. Human Resource Machine comes with optional branches of difficult puzzles based on ideas you solved in the main branch.

You are also motivated to go back and optimize your puzzles with two goals. Faster execution or small instruction count. Both are extreme opposites and feel very different to work towards.

[h1]Educational[/h1]
You will never see programming like this. This game teaches you nothing practical.

And [b]that's the point[/b]. Like Portal it tries to introduce you to something completely fresh and unheard of, forcing you to rethink how to solve the simplest problems.

[h1]Story[/h1]
There is no story. It is a puzzle game with the occasional short cut-scene teasing that something is happening in this world but you won't care. Characters are cute though.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Anyone can start playing this game and enjoy it. It does require you to follow along as it ramps up the difficulty. It doesn't progress too quickly and offers optional challenging puzzles to accommodate all.

Completion time is somewhere at 8h. I spent 10h on optimizing all puzzles, having spent a number of hours out of the game to rethink my approach.

[h1]Other[/h1]
[url=https://tomorrowcorporation.com/humanresourcemachine]Website[/url]
[quote=official Website]Ordering here directly from the developer gives the highest percentage of proceeds to the creators, and also gets you a Steam key as well as cross platform DRM-free versions. Also available on Steam, GOG, and Humble Store.[/quote]

It does not support Steam-Cloud-Saves, but it is DRM-free.
Achievements are a mixture of fun-achievements and completionist-achievements. Allows for 100%.

21297733.review:
This is my favourite game in my Steam library and I've been quite obsessed with it for 2 weeks or so. Every day, I would wake up, drink some tea, open up the game and just try to clear a level or two before I did anything else. It was entertaining and felt very fullfilling. Sometimes I would go to sleep and think about how to clear a level and then wake up like "I GOT IT!". 

I'm a very laidback gamer, so I don't play a lot of games. At all. So I find it impressive that this game managed to keep me entertained for 10+ hours and even made me think of it outside of those hours. Usually I just stick to sudokus, nonograms, etc. But this felt a lot more fun than those mundane puzzles.

I don't have anything bad to say. The game explains the mechanics well at the beginning and it's clear what your goals are. Obviously, the first levels are very easy. It just keeps stepping it up a nodge. I do remember clearing the first 19 levels very quickly, then being stuck at level 20 for an hour. It was funny how big the leap was for me, but I could overlook it. I was very glad to have these kind of tough challenges thrown at me after I got into it.

The game was worth every cent to me. I love this game to bits and it's exactly what I would look for in a puzzle game. You don't need to be a programming genius to succeed at this game.

I haven't finished the game yet, but it is without a doubt one of the best games I have ever played; and it delivers if you want to learn math/programming/life.

Очередная игра-эксперемент от Tomorrow Corporation, причем в хорошем смысле этого слова. Многие, должно быть, помнят, если не самобытный Little Inferno, то, хотя бы, шедевральный World of Goo - стилистика картинки не сильно изменилась, и если Вам нравилось оформление прошлых игр, то определенно понравится и внешний вид HRM.
Игра по своей сути является настоящим симулятором ассемблера для простенького процессора, роль которого выполняет Ваш подопечный работник - именно для него Вы и будете, используя набор примитивных команд вроде копирования, сложения и вычитания, составлять алгоритмы: от алгоритма банального переноса информации с входа на выход, до алгоритмов умножения двух чисел и поиска наименьшего числа в последовательности (которые в рамках процессора отнюдь не так тривиалены, как может сначала показаться). Те, кто в своё время обучался программированию на ассемблере, определенно увидят много знакомых заданий в этой игре, но при этом, справившись с поставленными задачами, не всегда смогут быстро понять, как же добиться максимальной оптимизации по количеству команд или по скорости выполнения "программы". К счастью, выполнение заданий оптимизации совершенно необязательно, так что быть матерым программистом микроконтроллеров для прохождения этой игры ни к чему. Те же, кто ни слухом, ни духом к программированию не относится, могут рассматривать игру, как очень специфичную и качественную головоломку - благо Tomorrow Corporation постарались сделать интерфейс максимально интуитивным, а про каждую задачу или термин подробно расскажет Ваш "начальник".

8 команд безусловного перехода из 10

21021473.review:
While I did like this game I am not sure it has the same appeal somehting like Little Inferno and World of Goo has. I can see however this being some younger teachers attempt to make low level programming appealing to his students, but if completing a puzzles isn't enough reward for you then I'm not sure you're going to get much more out of that. 

It has a very niche appeal that I appreciated, but I would have liked maybe a bit more window dressing. Especially regarding the ending which for me is the thing I am working towards in games from this company. 
I thought the last segment in Little Inferno did a good job at giving you just a little bit extra for your time and I could see a scenario where you get a bit more of a glimpse of what you, the employee, have brought upon this world with your optimizations.

I initially wondered if this was a good tool to get friends into programming and it is for some aspects, but it is not comprehensive and I think by the time they reach the end they will be too frustrated and not finish it. I think the critical path ramps up a bit too much and some of the later puzzles should have been on the side branches to avoid frustration. Maybe a hint system that gave you a bit more info would have helped. Letting the player adjust their own difficulty.

To sum it up, this game is a great teaching tool and refresher for computer scientists and people wanting to be, however do not give this to your friends and expect them to finish it on their own without previous programming experience.

Soldan al, sağa koy. Lakin, hele bir dur! Bu şartı da sağla.

Oyunun özü bir şirkette işe yeni başlamış bir karakteri yapması gereken görev için programlamak. Yani istenilen görevi ne şekilde yapacağını komutlar kullanarak belirlemek (al, şunu şunu yap, koy gibi).

Oyunda görevi tamamlamak için kullanılan komut ve yapılan hareket sayısı da dikkate alınıyor. Görevi tamamlarken belli sayıda komut ve hareket sayısını geçmemek gerekiyor. Bazen şartları sağlayıp görevi tamamlasanız da daha iyi bir çözüm (daha az komut ya da hareket sayısıyla tamamlamak) için kendisiyle rekabet ediyor insan.

Eğer biraz programlama bilginiz varsa oyunun mantığını zaten biliyorsunuz demektir. Programlama hakkında bilginiz yoksa analitik düşünme yeteneğinize göre oyunun mantığını kolayca ya da biraz deneme yanılmayla anlayabilirsiniz. Hatta, bence, oyun analitik düşünme becerisini geliştirmeye de yarıyor.

18 TL uygun bir fiyat mı derseniz, bence biraz yüksek. İndirim zamanında alınıp oynanabilecek, güzel, (çok basit olmayan) eğlencelik bir oyun.

Ekleme: 
Uzun bir süreden sonra tekrar oynamak istediğimde oyun yerel diskte yüklü olmasına rağmen "oyna" yerine "yükle" düğmesi görünüyordu. Sorunu çözemedim, tekrar yükledim. Maalesef oyunu kaldığım seviyeden değil en baştan başlattı. Tüm o seviyeleri tekrar geçmek durumunda kaldım. 

Yine de azıcık kafa yorayım demek için güzel bir oyun.

İyi oyunlar.

20776998.review:
One of the most unique puzzle games I've ever played.

 As someone who does understand programming language, I thought the mechanics of the game were really interesting, and I loved playing around with different solutions. That being said, the mechanics are introduced in a way that teaches the mechanics in an easy to understand manner, while still being interesting, providing challenges to players that have more experience in solving puzzles in this way, but some wiggle room for players who are still learning. The levels are presented in a way that encourages players to think about the level and figure out the puzzle for themselves, instead of just looking for a walkthrough, which I’ll admit to being guilty of in the past.

 I loved the quirky art style and the amusing, if simple, plot, but that really takes a backseat to the gameplay. I'm not saying that's a bad thing, not for me, but if you're someone who plays games just for the plotlines you might be dissapointed. 

Definitely check it out if you’re a fan of coding or puzzles, and are looking for a challenge that makes you want to keep trying, instead of just quitting or getting someone else to solve it for you.

20769865.review:
I knew I'd love this game from the moment my wife pointed it out to me on Steam, and I was right. The art style and mood of the game is equal parts Nightmare Before Christmas and Paper Mario. It's amusing and friendly, and makes assembly language programming really accessible. And that last point is really what makes this game great. As a professional programmer, I'm always happy to see new pathways for entering the field.

One of my most memorable childhood experiences that led to my love of programming was an exerise we did in school where the students gave the teacher step-by-step instructions to make a peanut butter & jelly sandwich. For example, a student might say, put the knife in the peanut butter jar, but if the lid was closed, the teacher would just bang the knife against the lid a bit to the sounds of raucus laughter.

Human Resource Machine is probably the best embodiment of those ideas I've ever seen, and you'd be forgiven if you thought it was just another puzzle game at first. However, the puzzles can get pretty challenging, especially if you are going towards the optimization goals.

Any programmers who don't have much exposure to low level coding should get this game. It will give you a much better intuition of what's going on under the hood in your programs. This is especially true with the way the animations play out. Watching your toon wander around the play space, picking up data from boxes, moving them to other boxes, etc. helps you identify unnecessary/duplicate work, and other possibilities for optimization.

As a final point to drive this home, I spent last April and May doing a job search. At least 50% of my interviews/code tests involved problems with the exact same structure as many of these puzzles. If you can do well at this game and haven't done any programming before, you might want to consider a career change. ;)

THAT SAID

While this was released as a desktop-only game, the UI was clearly designed for mobile (or at least by mobile designers), and it's rather painful:
[list]
   [*]ALL input is done with the left mouse button, including writing comments and labels. You have to draw them with your mouse which is annoying to begin with, but the only editing tool is "undo" which removes the last stroke you made. This makes it really tedious to make minor changes to an exsting program, and also means that when you copy/paste the code to share, it adds a bunch of base64 encoded binary data rather than a nice, textual comment in context with the code.
   [*] There are absolutely no options besides "toggle fullscreen" and "toggle music". The lack of volume control makes sense on mobile where you're only doing one thing at a time, but desktop games should always have their own control. I'm glad Windows offers app-specific volume controles these days, but I shouldn't have to resort to that.
[/list]

Anyway, those gripes are nothing compared to everything that is good and wonderful about this game. You should buy it right now.

Logic is a core part of human education that was pulled out of the norm, you are doing yourself a favor when you purchase this game.

If you enjoy higher maths and analytical thinking, then likely logic has something to do with that.  It is fun.

I discovered this not from Human Resource Machine, but from a semester course in college. 

The beauty does not entirely come across quickly unless you realize the game is showing you ways to see the universe early on, even though it is still fun.

Later on, both in class and in the game, if you do not think mechanically enough or fully understand a conjunction then you can spend a few minutes or hours looking for a ray of hope.  This can either be calming or boring, depending on your mindset.
 
 If you learn from the experience (eventually), then you will benefit even if it was not fun, so I recommend the game anyway.

If you have an oppurtunity to learn First Order Logic from a person with a background in Philosophy, I recommend it, since they will likely spend more time with what some proofs and conjunctions mean about our world.

This game was made by game developers, and uses a system that works best on computers even if it is harder for people to read, so there is another reason to supplement.

It fills my heart to be doing this again.

20730814.review:
In this game, you design workflows for your character to complete in-game goals. If Scratch and World of Goo had a child, this would be it. It has all the Kyle-Gabler-y fun and feel in the spriting and music, and it kept the Obsessive Completion Distinctions, straight outta World of Goo. 

The Sign Painter is no more (I presume; your supervisors now deliver those strange, cryptic messages), and you have moved to an office building where you manipulate inputs and control the outputs. I love it and I've played it as much as I can in my spare time. 

Once you've beaten the game, (I'm not even halfway yet, coming up on 10 hours) there is tremendous replay value. As with most puzzle games, you may solve one problem in tons of different ways. You might replay a puzzle to fulfill a Size Challenge or Efficiency Challenge, or to snag a Steam Achievement. To design your solutions, you are given extra documents to create these workflows on, and to test different prototypes. 

Would I recommend this game? Ohhhh yes. If you loved World of Goo, you owe it to yourself to play this. 

The only thing I would ask for, Tomorrow Corporation, is a sandbox!

(PS. Play World of Goo!)
