18523324.review:
Interested in seeing some gameplay? see below!

https://youtu.be/PCkK8FAouqA

TL:DR: If you like some complex logic puzzles then grab this game! 9/10

[h1] Review [/h1]

Human Resource Machine is a logic based puzzle game in which you play as a lowly employee of a large corporation slowly rising through the ranks of the company by automating each job. Automation of each job is achieved through the use of simple one line commands which combine to to create a sequential programming language. This game is both a challenging puzzle game and a great way to help new programmers into the world of programming.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
[list]
   [*] Challenging gameplay
   [*] Cute story
   [*] Replayability in the form of optimizing your code.
   [*] Great music and sound, appropriate for the environment.
   [*] Super cute graphics.
[/list]

[h1] Cons [/h1]
[list]
   [*] Only uses sequential programming, where modern programming uses much more object oriented.
   [*] Very logic based, definitely not everyones cup of tea for a puzzle game.
   [*] While the music is great, there is very little variation in songs, so it can get a little repetitive.
[/list]

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Whether you're new to the world of programming or a veteran coder this game is fun and offers varying levels of challenge for everyone. The  cute graphics, very "corporate" soundtrack and  [spoiler] relatively dark	[/spoiler] storyline all combine to create an amazing little game with a good amount of content for its price. Definitely worth picking up for anyone who enjoys programming or puzzles in general.

9/10

18522939.review:
This is not a game about programming, it is about logical operations. If you know a little or a lot about coding, I can't recommend this. Too often you feel like you're trying to walk with your legs cut off at the knees - you see a problem & know immediately how to solve it, but the tools required are not available. 

Example: Multiplying two numbers without knowing what they are beforehand. Easy - just multiply a by b.
No - no multiply function. Okay, So I store a, then store b, then add a to a b times.
No - you can't use variables like that. You have to store a, then b, then add a to a, store it as c, then take one from b, check if b = 0, then add a to c, then take one from b, check if b = 0, then add a to c, then take one from b, check if b = 0, then add a to c, then take one from b, check if b = 0...

You will have to do each of these steps manually, with a mouse, just to do basic multiplication. Bubble sort? Two's Complement? There are infinitely saner ways to learn about this, and there is almost no handholding. Quite literally the only advice you will get sometimes is like this: "This procedure is called XOR. You make look it up online if you wish to do further study." Well, if you enjoy learning about Exclusive Or et al., skip the game & watch Computerphile on YouTube.

Even with labels, complex functions are too unwieldy to see as there are only 16 or so lines of commands are visible at once, and loops/jumps take up two lines so if you need recursion (and look at what you have to do just to multiply, so you will need it), finding where changes happen is nightmareish. This is why we indent our code!

The story is there, but not even as close to engaging as Little Inferno, let alone World of Goo. The graphics style is just like 2D Boy/Tomorrow Corporation's other work, familiar & quite enjoyable. The soundtrack is pleasant at first but will rapidly grate. 

This game will teach you about logical operations in a curiously if not particularly intuitive fashion - it will NOT teach you how to program!

This is a fun little game about logic and puzzle solving. It has the same quirky look and feel of World of Goo (by the same developers), and a very nice streamlined interface. The game starts you off with simple puzzles to help you get to grips with the basics, and gradually ramps up the difficulty until you get to the point where you look at every puzzle saying: "Surely this is impossible, how the hell am I meant to solve this!?"

While this game is challenging, you'll eventually find sollutions to every puzzle with a bit of patience and head-scratching. It also gives you that feeling of satisfaction that all great puzzles games leave you with after solving a puzzle. There's nothing like coming up with an elegant sollution to a problem that seemed unsolvable.

At 10$ this one is well worth the full price! I bought a razor yesterday that was more expensive than this game. So my consumer advice is keep your beard and buy this game, that way you'll have a fun afternoon and you can stroke your magnificent beard while you're trying to figure out how to solve the  more difficult puzzles.

P.S. For the record I'm not a hardcore programmer, although I've certainly dabbled with programming at various points in my life. That said, for me the appeal of this game lies in solving logic puzzles and I would have probably enjoyed it irrespective of how closely (or not) it resembles actual programming.

18512336.review:
I guess you can say I’m quite a fan of the work done by Tomorrow Corporation and it’s hard not to be after some really awesome Indie games (World of Goo & Little Inferno).

Following on from the beautiful art style of their previous games I was happy to see they’ve continued it. As well the graphically style they have also kept the fun little playful sound effects.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

You use a series of commands to build a program which tells your worker what they have to do. It’s a very basic drag and drop system that lends itself nicely to new comers as you have to complete a serious of challenges to pass each area.

The game also introduces new elements for your programs as you progress, so where-as when you start out and you simplify have inbox and outbox, you soon unlock jump (which is a repeater), then later the ability to copy and paste to your boxes.

make sure to read everything in the note on the programming area, I know it may seem like common sense, but all the answers are hidden within it.

The levels gain in differently pretty quickly, but it’s all just logic and common sense, however when you start to get engrossed in it’s easy to forget and just jump straight into each puzzle.

I’m a big fan of logic and puzzles so it’s very refreshing to pick up an indie game which is all about that and to enjoy it so much. It really does have a nice balance of lovely artwork along with a great game.

It let’s you try countless times so you can get your head around the maniacs the game is trying to lend itself to.

[h1]Little Extras[/h1]

You can use a slider to make your worker walk faster but I really enjoy the animation style of this game so tend not to use it.

You can also choice different paths along the way of your progression, it’s a sort of hard vs harder, but I’m always up for a challenge so I took them head on.

If the game hasn’t given you enough challenges at this stage then you’ll be happy to know that each level can be completed in numerous ways

If you've played World of Goo or Little Inferno, then you know what brilliance to expect here. The puzzles are satisfying, the visuals and music are captivating, and the writing keeps you interested until the very end. The gameplay is essentially a simulation of a simple computer. You are given a set of instructions of what to output at each level, and a collection of commands to create a program that accomplishes this. While the late game does get fairly complex, you are weaned into it one concept at a time from the very basics. The base story sits at a reasonable difficulty, but World of Goo players won't be surprised to hear that 100% completion is fiendishly difficult.

While the theme of the gameplay might seem unappealing or too unfamiliar to people who aren't experienced in programming, I would say that the presentation sits at a perfect medium; everything is set up in a way that anybody can enjoy the main game regardless of experience, but the challenge of the optional levels and optimization challenges remains for skilled programmers and completionists alike.

Игра основана на Алгоритмах.
Как обычно, с начала все легко, а потом... Идет СУЩИЙ АД.

Сложная, да, она действительно сложная, Надо составлять алгоритмы, что бы в некоторых случаях не было багов, а те кто хотят пройти на 100%, то им будет "Приятный" сюрприз, он заключается в том, что, для того что бы пройти уровень полностью, нужно действительно постаратся, Что бы не привысть кол-во комманд и шагов.

18498534.review:
Human Resource Machine is a really fun indie game that consists of a series of programming puzzles with a fairly simple set of what amount to CPU instructions (aka programming in simplified assembly language).

I learned at least 100 times more about assembly playing that game than I did in my couple of brief excursions looking through a couple of ebooks on assembly.

The prime factorization puzzle alone probably had me going for over an hour. But I actually got quite a sense of accomplishment for writing a successful program to find the prime factorization of integers. In assembly. I'm also a bit proud of myself for implementing insertion sort. Again: in assembly.

The most annoying part of the game is that while you can comment your state diagrams (that represent your code), you technically can't type comments in. Instead, you have to write them with the mouse as if you were using MS Paint. Also, the ability to create functions/subroutines would have been nice, as well (although the lack of that feature is understandable, since this *is* simplified assembly, after all).

At first glance, I thought this game looked cute. "Eh, what the hell, let's give it a shot", I said to myself.

Eight hours later, I've completed all of the levels in the game (albeit not all of the challenges), and I'm already chomping at the bit for a sequel.

10/10

I hate to give this game a negative review, but... As someone who has played most of the programming games that are out there, this is (by /far/) the weakest of them.  Note that this isn't a *bad* game, just a significantly below average game in its genre.

FYI: My time in game is inaccurate -- I originally purchased, installed, and completed (all but one optional puzzle) the game from the Humble Bundle store, spending about 5 hours in doing so.

1) The game is extremely short
2) The UI is awful -- writing comments and labeling variables /by writing with the mouse/ (and, no, typing on the keyboard isn't an option) isn't fun at all.  No functions or subroutines doesn't help either.
3) The puzzles are very straightforward  -- if you've taken a CS101 class, most of the puzzles could have been taken directly out of your textbook.
4) The optimization puzzles are trivial -- a side-effect of #2 (the obvious algorithm is the best algorithm in all but a few cases)
5) The story is trite, even by the standards of the genre.

[table][tr][th][h1][b]FR[/b][/h1][/th][th][h1][u]Découverte[/u] : [/h1][/th][th]v. 1 -[/th][/tr][/table]
Human Resource Machine est un petit titre [edit] d'un des créateurs de World of Goo (2008, l'un des tous premiers 'indé' - 2 ans avant Super Meat Boy ou Limbo).
Le développeur, Tomorrow Coporation reste fidèle à la ligne artistique de son passé, de grands yeux blancs excentrés, un style un enfantin, pour de petits êtres à l'air à la fois loufoque et absurde mais servant toujours un propos critique sur la société. Ils me font rire, mais je peux me voir en eux, assailli par le consumérisme ou la bureaucratie.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=535687098 Human Resource Machine vous expédie dans la peau d'un de ses 'automates de bureaux' vous ne travaillez pas à la chaine sur des pièces détachées, mais c'est tout comme. 
Le but est simple, transformez selon un énoncé très concis l'information entrée pour la renvoyer à l'expéditeur.
Je ne vais pas jouer les mystérieux plus longtemps : une INPUT, un OUTPUT et un traitement à appliquer entre les 2, c'est trait pour trait une analogie du langage de programmation connu sous le nom 'ASM' ou Assembleur. C'est un langage extrêmement simple, extrêmement "bas niveau" pour vous donnez l'adjectif précis en usage en programmation. 

Ce langage se prête très bien aux jeux vidéo pour 2 raisons, a) Le rapport entre sa simplicité et sa puissance est gigantesque. C'est un concept qu'un enfant, capable d'addition/soustractions (et un peu d'abstraction), peut s'approprier. b) La courbe d'apprentissage qu'il implique est très stimulante. Comprenez que vous allez utiliser un ensemble d'instructions limité et simple mais qui se combine pour former de fabuleux leviers. 

Par ailleurs, l'ASM c'est toujours d'actualité non pas qu'il soit encore utilisé aujourd'hui, mais plutôt qu'il est à l'oeuvre partout et tout le temps pour les machines informatique). Tout programme fini tôt ou tard décomposé en ASM, qui lui est utilisé quasi directement par votre machine, son processeur, sa mémoire vive. (je schématise, l'assembleur a des variantes, des équivalents et même si son 'jeu d'instructions' est simple il s'est enrichit au fil du temps d'opérations subtiles et profondément abstraites).

Les énoncés en questions sont toujours très clair et très simple. Une fenêtre offre les opérations disponibles, glissez et déposez ses opérations dans le fil d'exécution, ordonnez les, lancez la simulation en appuyant sur 'Play' et vous verrez votre avatar débonnaire se promener et effectuer visuellement les opérations que vous venez de planifier.

[quote][u]exemple d'énoncé[/u] : Pour chaque couple de valeurs dans l'Inbox, faites-en la somme et déposez le résultat dans l'Outbox. (Il a l'air triviale mais vous aurez des surprises lorsque vous mettre en place l'exécution). Plus on avance, plus vous devrez réfléchir pour définir un cycle qui une fois répété en boucle effectuera l'opération sans faillir. 
Concrètement, un tapis roulant à votre gauche vous amène des 'dossiers' marqués d'une lettre ou d'un chiffre. A droite un second tapis attends le résultat 'de sortie' et entre ces tapis, c'est à vous d'opérer. De traiter l'entrée en respectant les règles et faites suivre le résultat de la transformation. [/quote]

Si le concept vous rappelle quelque chose, c'est normal. Le développeur Zachtronics (Infinifactory) a déjà créé 2 titres selon le même concept (TIS-100 et Spacechem — Le premier est tout récent et hardcore, le second est assez vieux, plus simple d'approche mais toujours très exigeants. Ce dernier se focalise d'abord sur l'efficacité et la complexité algorithmique). HRM lui fait pareil mais avec une expérience vraiment 'user friendly', ce qui signifie que c'est plus abordable et plus ludique (et plus simple aussi). Mais son animation permet de repérer plus vite ses erreurs et facilité l'apprentissage.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=535720485 Si l'ASM vous parle déjà un peu, vous retrouverez classique 'Input', 'output', 'add', 'sub', 'jump', 'jumpif*, copy*' avec même des commentaires et un mini mode "debug". Pour les autres vous les comprendrez en moins de 10min chrono garanti :) 
Human Resource Machine est totalement traduit en français (menu/sous-titres, il reste quelques courts dialogues vocaux) mais les traducteurs et les développeurs ont eu le bon sens de ne pas traduire les instructions (puisque c'est sous ce nom que vous les retrouverez dans le langage lui-même.

Human Resource Machine est génial, agréable et bien poli. Ses vertus pédagogiques sont évidentes et même si l'informatique/programmation vous laisse froid, le jeu se refuse à basculer dans le jargon ou dans l'abstraction complète. Il constitue aussi un excellent prélude à Spacechem et TIS. Par ailleurs tout comme dans ces derniers, HRM inclus votre efficacité. Un niveau implique plusieurs manière de faire mais dans le jeu (tout comme dans la réalité) votre efficience compte beaucoup, donc HRM comptera en combien d'opérations vous êtes parvenu à résoudre le problème, ou le nombre total d'instructions dont vous avez eu besoin. Cela ne manquera de lui donner un peu de rejouabilité. L'univers de fond est moins vaste et construit que celui de World of Goo mais le titre reste sympathique. 
[quote][h1]N'hésitez pas à réagir, que ce soit pour une question ou pour signaler une erreur[/h1][/quote]

18490093.review:
If you have been looking for a good "programming" puzzle game, I think Human Resource Machine may be it. 

Human Resource Machine is a puzzle game where you need to direct your worker to complete tasks. This is done by dragging and dropping commands that direct the worker to perform certain "programming functions". While the game doesn't really teach you any actual programming, it does a good job teaching programming concepts and makes it easy enough for people without programming experience to understand.

While the early levels are pretty easy, the later levels can get quite challenging especially for people without experience programming. The puzzles are pretty interesting but you need to think like a programmer to solve a lot of them. This might be challenging for people who haven't programmed before. For people who have programmed before I would say that the game is moderately difficult. 

Having some programming experience I actually had a lot of fun with the game. It is probably one of the best puzzle games that I have played recently. It has taken me around eight hours to complete all but one of the puzzles so the game is probably nine to ten hours long. With more programming experience you could take less time and with less experience it will likely take you longer. 

The game won't be for everyone. If you have no interest in programming or puzzle games, you probably won't like Human Resource Machine. Otherwise I think you could really enjoy the game. 

Note: I received a free review copy of the game from the developer.

[url=http://www.geekyhobbies.com/human-resource-machine-indie-game-review/] Read My Full Review [/url]

18490054.review:
Human Resource Machine is a game that teaches you how to program in a fun and satisfying way
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q-Dn78q_IPk
The game helps you wrap your head around the way programming logic works. All the stuff it teaches you is actually applicable to the real world, yet the puzzles are done in a fun way. There's nothing more satisfying than scratching your head at a puzzle, shouting at the screen that it's impossible, only to solve it in the next 5 minutes and feeling like a God. That is also a taste of what programming feels like.

There are a few optional challenges in levels which encourage you to optimize your programs so that you use less commands, or complete the task in fewer steps. Even that, is a useful skill the game helps you learn for real programming.

As you progress, you unlock new commands that you can incorporate into your program, as well as labels to remember what some sections you've created are. Within each level, you even have a few pages to work through, in case you want to try out a new program to solve the task, but don't want to scrap your current one in case you want to go back to it. The UI is also very easy to use. Everything is streamlined and reacts the way you'd expect it to.

I love the world the game is set in as well. The art style is reminiscent of World of Goo and Little Inferno. It's go that adorable yet creepy and sad undertone. I feel like everyone thinks they're happy, but are actually miserable. The music is beautiful as well.

Overall, I really love this game. I think it's fantastic, and I can't wait to 100% all the levels. It's incredibly satisfying, and really gets you into the groove of programming while giving you some knowledge on the subject you can apply to the real world.

18489492.review: Human Resource Machine is a game about programmatically sorting tiles, and about climbing the corporate ladder. As you progress, business conditions will change, and your character will gain seniority. You will gain access to greater sorting functionality, and you will be entrusted with more sophisticated sorting tasks. Optional side content exists for those seeking greater difficulty. Those seeking to extend their playtime may choose to optimize their sorting methods. I recommend this game for people who enjoy puzzles of moderate difficulty.

18489414.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
By simply taking a look at the screenshots you’ll know exactly who is behind this seemingly-casual-but-still-harder-than-expected puzzle/programming game: the Tomorrow Corporation! Better known as the developers of Little Inferno and World Of Goo. Is Human Resource Machine (HRM) just as brilliant as those games or is it maybe even better? Or, God forbid…*gulp* worse?

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Let me reassure you: HRM is absolutely great. It might not necessarily be better than their previous games, but I enjoyed this just as much (and at times even a bit more), but it’s still a unique game that tries to teach you the basics of programming. It can be fun for actual programmers and people who have never even attempted it before, although it speaks for itself that it will be more challenging for this group.

You start at the bottom of the company, where the level number is relative to your years in service of the company. It starts off rather linear with only one way to go up, but after level six you can choose to play more advanced puzzles, and these branch off the otherwise linear path. These are usually more difficult versions of the levels you’ve already played and they are entirely optional.
There seem to be 33 levels, by the way, and this is excluding the optional puzzles. In total there are around 44 levels.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=531839482
The first few puzzles can be solved with relative ease, but the game always wants you to use your brain. You might make some progress by just trying things. You might even be able to finish a few levels this way, but ultimately things just become too complex. If you haven’t paid attention to the game’s mechanics then you’re going to have a hard time finishing it.
The learning curve is good; you’ll start off with the absolute basics and then just work your way through the levels, gaining more and more functions as you go. There are 11 functions in total and these functions will apparently simulate most of a computer’s algorithm, which I was actually unaware of. You learn something new every day!

You can start and stop a puzzle, fast-forward as well take steps backward and forward. The sound can be muted in the level itself and there are also buttons to delete, copy and undo functions and use three sheets. You also have a clear button that removes all of your used functions so that you can quickly start over again. This is sometimes more useful than just rearranging everything and also gives a better overview if things are not going your way.

If you’re looking for more advanced programming puzzles then I’m sorry to have to disappoint you. Even casual gamers can eventually finish this game with a little patience. And to be honest, I don’t think the game would’ve been as fun if the puzzles would’ve been even more difficult. If you want advanced programming lessons then I suggest you go read a book or follow a training course. 
In fact, I think that there will be plenty of players who might want to give programming a try after having played this, either as a hobby or a study/job.

Where I normally don’t get a sense of accomplishment whenever I manage to solve a tough puzzle, in HRM this is a completely different story. Solving the puzzles felt rewarding and great. I felt… smart. That’s not normally a feeling I get when I play games. It’s maybe because these are logical (to-the-point) puzzles whereas other puzzles usually require a bit trial-and-error gameplay because things aren’t always clear(ly explained) and are shown in an entirely different context, relative to the game’s story and atmosphere. And no, this doesn’t apply to *all* puzzle games, of course.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=531839455
After finishing a puzzle you will be shown a results screen (called Optimization Challenges) that shows you have many steps (speed) and functions (size) you should have used and how many you used to actually finish the level. Since sometimes you can do (much) better this is a good incentive to go and replay a level. Plus, you will ultimately learn to program more efficiently this way. And the levels are also usually just a few minutes long (and previous attempts are saved you when exit the level), which is another kind of bonus I guess.

[h1]Audio & Visuals[/h1]
With such a relaxing game you will need relaxing audio as well, right? You are absolutely correct and thankfully the music that has been implemented suits the game well. It remains in the background and doesn’t become the focus of attention. Other than that there are some relatively basic sound effects: similar to the sound effects used in their previous games.

The visuals of HRM are instantly recognizable as Tomorrow Corporation’s work. There’s no doubt about it: the weird looking big lipped and/or big eyed characters and the brownish color palette. It’s all part of the developer’s famous art style. Everything looks stylish and sharp, the animations are done well, although the animations in general are quite limited. But then again, this isn’t a game about the visuals, but about the gameplay. The graphics are there so you know you’re dealing with a game here, but underneath it all is actually a basic programming tool. One that has just been dressed up.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=531839406
[h1]Length/Replay Value[/h1]
Fortunately there are more than enough puzzles to be solved. There are 44 levels in total and while they start off by showing you the absolute basics the difficulty will increase not long after you have started. Add to this the optional, more advanced puzzles and you should be able to finish it in 10-30 hours. All of this naturally depends on your current programming knowledge and intelligence, though (hence the big gap).

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
They have done it again: the people of Tomorrow Corporation have managed to surprise me once more. HRM has become a beautiful, little educative game that shows everyone can have fun programming… as long as it’s a little dressed up. 
I’ve had tons of fun playing it, even if it’s at times frustratingly hard/difficult/complex. But try to keep going, though, it’s worth it for the feeling of accomplishment alone. 
In any case, I suggest you add this to your cart right now and press that big ‘Buy’ button immediately. Trust me!*

(*Just don’t hold me responsible if you end up not liking the game ;))

[h1]Too long, didn’t read[/h1]
Pros:
+ Famous Tomorrow Corporation art style
+ You’ll learn the basics of programming in a fun, but still challenging way
+ Plenty of puzzles
+ Optional, advanced puzzles
+ Optimization Challenges make you want to do better and be more efficient

Mixed:
+/- If you want to learn/know more about advanced programming functions you will have to look further

Cons:
- Even though it has a good difficulty curve it may still prove too difficult for people with little or no interest in PC's (e.g. casual users).

18489251.review:
[u] [h1] [b] Human Resource Machine Review. [/b] [/h1] [/u]

[b]Developer: [/b] Tomorrow Corporation.
[b]Genre: [/b] Puzzle Sloving, Indie, Programming.
[b]Price: [/b] 9.99$
[b]Played on:[/b] GTX 650 2GB OC Edition, Core i3 4130 3.4 Ghz at 1920x1080 Res.

 [i] [h1] "Welcome new employee to Human Resource Machine!" [/h1] [/i]

[u] [b] Gameplay: [/b] [/u]
Well ain't this game lovely? You get to program your little guy to do all kinds of things using the commands the game game gives you. You can do anything from basic inbox to outbox all the way to crazy infinite mathmatical loops. Gameplay is as promised, basiclly programming, you need to build a program that works for each floor to continue to the next and get promoted so you can do more puzzles with ocassional coffee breaks. The game is actually really challenging, I haven't gotten extremely far as of writing this review, but maybe that's just because I've never done programming. 

Each level or "floor" has it's own unique problem to solve, the game gets harder and harder and there are even extra side puzzles for the employees doing the best job! The game really combines programming and puzzle solving almost perfectly, very enjoyable. I currentlly only made it to level 14 just because the game seriously melts my brain on each time I open it, is that a bad thing? No, not really, because I enjoy getting my brain destroyed while trying to solve the puzzles that this game throws at me. Although you do not [i] need [/i] to know how to program, it does help. 

The only thing I'd really like to say is if you are used to getting angry over frustrating games, then there is no point to picking this game up. This game [i] will not [/i] be for everyone! It starts off easy and gets harder, and harder, and harder.

Tomrrow Corp. as usual still leave that charming sense of... creepiness. There is always someone watching, something happening in the background that they don't tell you about but you [i] know [/i] is happening. Always a pair of eyes staring or a gear cracking or a.... is that a robot arm on the floor?

[u] [b] Story: [/b] [/u]
Storywise, the game dosen't offer a whole lot but it's a puzzle solving game, what did you expect? All the story really is, is you going floor to floor progressing up the HRM corporate food chain as whatever character you've picked out of the 4 avaliable options. The game dosen't need it's own storyline, the story is built into the gameplay, which works very, very well for a game that's all programming.

If you are really looking for a story I'd recommend Tomorrow Corp.'s [i] "Little Inferno" [/i] which does have a sweet little story attached to it. 

[u] [b] Artstyle: [/b] [/u]
Keeping it classing Tomorrow Corp. stuck to their usual rough drawn-like artstyle. Like in their other 2 games, it looks as lovely as ever. The game looks really nice, taking the wacky fun Tomorrow Corp. models we love and mixing it with a clean, colourful UI. Vibrant colours and shapes everywhere all the way from the programming buttons to the floor tiles.

[u] [b] Soundtrack: [/b] [/u]
Despite the slight creepiness of the game (See: "Gameplay") the game has a upbeat, happy soundtrack like all other Tomorrow Corp. games. In my opinion not being [i] as [/i] good as Little Inferno's soundtrack, the game's OST is still really sweet and quiet adorable.

[u] [b] Performance: [/b] [/u]
Obviously the game runs at a smooth 60 FPS no matter what's going on since the requirements are basiclly any computer past the year 2005 even if it isn't built for gaming. I still note performance because it's really important to know no matter what game it is. 

[u] [b] Additonal Notes: [/b] [/u]
- The game dosen't have a crazy large amout of levels but they take ages to beat so it shouldn't matter that much.
- Extremely frustrating, not saying it's a good or a bad thing, just leaving a note of it.
- Your boss for each floor tells you what the output is suppose to look like, so you know how [i] beat [/i] the level, just not how to solve it.

[u] [b] Summary: [/b] [/u]
It's fun, it's frusting, it makes me feel stupid, but it's loveable and most importantly it's really, really great. Highly recommended.

[b] Rating: 8.5/10. [/b]

[b] [i] Review key provided by developer but does not change my opinion about the game in any way.[/i] [/b]

[b] For more reviews like this, check out my curation page [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11615466/] here! [/url] [/b]

18489207.review:
[h1]Introduction [/h1]

[b]Mind numbingly difficult but oh so satisfying. [/b]

Human Resource Machine is a challenging puzzle-based programing game from the devs who brought us Little Inferno and World of Goo. In HR Machine you’re presented with tasks to complete and in order to complete said tasks you need to program your little office worker to complete whatever steps need to be taken in order to complete it. As you’d expect the puzzles get harder as you progress through the game but they’re not exactly easy to begin with, making this one of the most challenging games I’ve come across.

I’ve never done any kind of programing before and while the game is very good at explaining how to do it within the game it is still pretty tough to wrap your head around. If you do have programing experience you may find it slightly easier but there are bonus levels along the way to test the best!

[h1]Presentation [/h1]

HR Machine brings back the style that Little Inferno and World of Goo had and as expected it looks great and fits perfectly with the game. There’s not much else to say about this other than the fact that it’s a great looking game. All the models are good, the UI is clean, simple and easy to use as is the menu.

[h1]Gameplay [/h1]

[b]Management is watching. [/b]

Starting the game with two different commands you’ll gradually work your way up to eleven different commands, making up a simple language. Using this language you’ll program your little office worker to complete tasks set by the management. Each task has its own floor, completing the task will earn you a promotion to the next floor and a harder task to complete. While the main objective is of course to complete each task, the management are also looking to see how many commands you use and how many steps it takes for you to complete the task. While these aren’t tied to progression they add an extra challenge if you wish to push yourself though it’s not always possible to complete them both in one program.

The tasks set are of a wide variety but they always involve taking items (numbers at the beginning but letters are introduced later on) from the inbox and then manipulating them somehow before moving them to the outbox. Some tasks involve taking items from the inbox before subtracting them from the next item in the inbox, some involve multiplying a number by itself x number of times etc. 

All of the levels with tasks have spaces on the floor where you can copy inbox items to/from. These are used in pretty much all of the tasks in order to manipulate the items or swap their order etc.

As I mentioned earlier there are bonus tasks which provide a challenge for even the best programmers! The different tasks are displayed as what looks like an elevator floor control. Every so often you’ll come across a branch that breaks away from the rest of the levels, generally about four or five levels. The tasks given to you on these levels are incredibly challenging, I found the regular tasks mind numbing but these take it to a whole new level of mind numbingness! So whether you’re a programming wizard or a complete newcomer there’s something here to get your grey matter going.

[h1]Audio [/h1]

Audio is great across the board for HR Machine. The music fits nicely with the game and it’s reasonably subtle so it doesn’t steal the show from the game itself. Sound effects are also fitting and sound pretty good.

[h1]Miscellaneous [/h1]
[list]
[*]While it’s definitely not the main point of the game, HR Machine does have a storyline running through it which is rather amusing and provides a nice occasional break from the game itself.
[*]HR Machine features forty-two levels, enough to keep you going for quite some time though not all of the levels have tasks to complete, six of the levels are coffee breaks, i.e. the levels where you’re presented with the story.
[*]Really the only thing I didn’t like about HR Machine is that it’s pretty difficult to write out the comments. Comments are unlocked a few levels in and allow you to split up your code (you can also label spots on the floor later on) but they have to be ‘hand-written’ with the mouse, personally I would have preferred to just type them.      
[*]You’re able to run your program step-by-step which is incredibly helpful for fine tuning it as well as weeding out any issues with it to correct them.
[/list]

[h1]Verdict [/h1]

[b]Essential Purchase.[/b]

Human Resource Machine is a truly fantastic puzzle-based programing game with a charming aesthetic and challenging puzzles. If you’re a fan of puzzle games or just like a good challenge, do yourself a favour and buy this game.

[b]Review Copy Provided. [/b]

[i]No drama, [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/justreviews]Just Reviews.[/url][/i]

El K.

18489052.review:
[I] This key was obtained from the developer for the purposes of the review. [/i]

[u] Summary: [/u]
Ever wanted a glimpse into the world of logic and assembly programming? That's what Human Resource Machine does: translates the world of some assembly based programming into a corporate like infrastructure in a puzzle like format. And they've done it rather well, allowing for teaching the concepts and ideas behind logical programming in a way that people can understand, at least coming from a software engineers perspective. It still captures the Tomorrow Corporation's aesthetic and goofy nature rather well, and while it's a game that will frustrate others with no hint system, it's countered by the use of the “debugger” to see what's going on. A good teaching tool and glimpse into the world, while still challenging those who want a puzzle challenge.

[b] Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5h_yAHu3eqg [/b]

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]+:[/b]
[list]
[*] Fantastic translation of the material to a core concept that people can understand. While I had a headstart with my background, I felt it taught the material well enough to get a basic understanding, but held back enough so that people would still be challenged.
[*] Good extra objectives to teach concepts of optimization. Feel like this would do well in a classroom to teach basic ideas. Shows some of the struggles behind code length and efficiency.
[*] Captures the Tomorrow Corporation's aesthetic rather well. Goofy, with a hint of seriousness, and a good element of little charms.
[*] Good introduction of new mechanics just as you finishing getting a handle of the other one.
[*] Allowed for multiply solution areas so that you can attempt certain different ways without messing up your current one.
[*] Giving examples for those who get confused was a good move.
[/list]

[b]-:[/b]
[list]
[*] No hint system will frustrate people on some solutions that they may not just get.
[*] Some information should have been displayed on the screen as opposed to submenus for clarity sake. There was enough room and ways to fit it in thematically.
[*] May be short for some, but honestly, I feel it's the right amount for a game like this.
[/list]
